During this time that Jurgis was looking for work occurred the death of little Kristoforas, one of the children of Teta Elzbieta.

Both Kristoforas and his (man) brother, Juozapas, were cripples, the latter having lost one leg by having it run over, and Kristoforas having congenital dislocation of the hip, which made it impossible for him (man) ever to walk.

He (man) was the last of Teta Elzbieta's children, and perhaps he (man) had been intended by nature to let her (Elzbieta) know that she (Elzbieta) had had enough.

At any rate he (man) was wretchedly sick and undersized; he (man) had the rickets, and though he (man) was over three years old, he (man) was no bigger than an ordinary child of one.

All day long he (man) would crawl around the floor in a filthy little dress, whining and fretting; because the floor was full of drafts he (man) was always catching cold, and snuffling because his (man) nose ran.

For his (man) mother, with unnatural perversity, loved him (man) best of all her (mother) children, and made a perpetual fuss over him (man)--would let him (man) do anything undisturbed, and would burst into tears when his (man) fretting drove Jurgis wild.

Perhaps it was the smoked sausage he (man) had eaten that morning--which may have been made out of some of the tubercular pork that was condemned as unfit for export.

At any rate, an hour after eating it, the child had begun to cry with pain, and in another hour he (man) was rolling about on the floor in convulsions.

Little Kotrina, who was all alone with him (man), ran out screaming for help, and after a while a doctor came, but not until Kristoforas had howled his (doctor) last howl.

This made him (doctor) a nuisance, and a source of endless trouble in the family. And now he (doctor) died. No one was really sorry about this except poor Elzbieta, who was inconsolable.

Jurgis announced that so far as he (doctor) was concerned the child would have to be buried by the city, since they had no money for a funeral; and at this the poor woman almost went out of her (woman) senses, wringing her (woman) hands and screaming with grief and despair.

Her (woman) child to be buried in a pauper's grave! And her (woman) stepdaughter to stand by and hear it said without protesting!

If it had come to this, they might as well give up at once, and be buried all of them together! ...

In the end Marija said that she (woman) would help with ten dollars; and Jurgis being still obdurate, Elzbieta went in tears and begged the money from the neighbors, and so little Kristoforas had a mass and a hearse with white plumes on it, and a tiny plot in a graveyard with a wooden cross to mark the place.

The poor mother was not the same for months after that; the mere sight of the floor where little Kristoforas had crawled about would make her (mother) weep.

It was enough to make Ona's father rise up out of his (father) grave to rebuke her (Ona)! He (father) had never had a fair chance, poor little fellow, she (Ona) would say.

If only she (Ona) had heard about it in time, so that she (Ona) might have had that great doctor to cure him (doctor) of his (doctor) lameness! ...

Some time ago, Elzbieta was told, a Chicago billionaire had paid a fortune to bring a great European surgeon over to cure his (surgeon) little daughter of the same disease from which Kristoforas had suffered.

And because this surgeon had to have bodies to demonstrate upon, he (surgeon) announced that he (surgeon) would treat the children of the poor, a piece of magnanimity over which the papers became quite eloquent.

Elzbieta, alas, did not read the papers, and no one had told her (Elzbieta); but perhaps it was as well, for just then they would not have had the carfare to spare to go every day to wait upon the surgeon, nor for that matter anybody with the time to take the child.

All this while that he (surgeon) was seeking for work, there was a dark shadow hanging over Jurgis; as if a savage beast were lurking somewhere in the pathway of his (surgeon) life, and he (surgeon) knew it, and yet could not help approaching the place.

There are all stages of being out of work in Packingtown, and he (surgeon) faced in dread the prospect of reaching the lowest.

He (surgeon) had been handicapped from his (surgeon) birth. There is a place that waits for the lowest man--the fertilizer plant! The men would talk about it in awe-stricken whispers.

Not more than one in ten had ever really tried it; the other nine had contented themselves with hearsay evidence and a peep through the door.

They would ask Jurgis if he (surgeon) had worked there yet, and if he (surgeon) meant to; and Jurgis would debate the matter with himself.

As poor as they were, and making all the sacrifices that they were, would he (surgeon) dare to refuse any sort of work that was offered to him (surgeon), be it as horrible as ever it could?

Would he (surgeon) dare to go home and eat bread that had been earned by Ona, weak and complaining as she (Ona) was, knowing that he (surgeon) had been given a chance, and had not had the nerve to take it?--And

yet he (surgeon) might argue that way with himself all day, and one glimpse into the fertilizer works would send him (surgeon) away again shuddering.

He (surgeon) was a man, and he (surgeon) would do his (surgeon) duty; he (surgeon) went and made application--but surely he (surgeon) was not also required to hope for success!

There were some things worse than even starving to death. The fertilizer works of Durham's lay away from the rest of the plant.

Few visitors ever saw them, and the few who did would come out looking like Dante, of whom the peasants declared that he (Dante) had been into hell.

To this part of the yards came all the

``tankage'' (men women children)
and the waste products of all sorts; here they dried out the bones,--and in suffocating cellars where the daylight never came you might see men and women and children bending over whirling machines and sawing bits of bone into all sorts of shapes, breathing their lungs full of the fine dust, and doomed to die, every one of them, within a certain definite time.

Here they made the blood into albumen, and made other foul-smelling things into things still more foul-smelling. In the corridors and caverns where it was done you might lose yourself as in the great caves of Kentucky.

In the dust and the steam the electric lights would shine like far-off twinkling stars--red and blue-green and purple stars, according to the color of the mist and the brew from which it came.

For the odors of these ghastly charnel houses there may be words in Lithuanian, but there are none in English. The person entering would have to summon his (person) courage as for a cold-water plunge.

He (person) would go in like a man swimming under water; he (person) would put his (person) handkerchief over his (person) face, and begin to cough and choke; and then, if he (person) were still obstinate, he (person) would find his (person) head beginning to ring, and the veins in his (person) forehead to throb, until finally he (person) would be assailed by an overpowering blast of ammonia fumes, and would turn and run for his (person) life, and come out half-dazed.

On top of this were the rooms where they dried the

``tankage,'' (unknown)
the mass of brown stringy stuff that was left after the waste portions of the carcasses had had the lard and tallow dried out of them.

This dried material they would then grind to a fine powder, and after they had mixed it up well with a mysterious but inoffensive brown rock which they brought in and ground up by the hundreds of carloads for that purpose, the substance was ready to be put into bags and sent out to the world as any one of a hundred different brands of standard bone phosphate.

And then the farmer in Maine or California or Texas would buy this, at say twenty-five dollars a ton, and plant it with his (farmer) corn; and for several days after the operation the fields would have a strong odor, and the farmer and his (farmer) wagon and the very horses that had hauled it would all have it too.

In Packingtown the fertilizer is pure, instead of being a flavoring, and instead of a ton or so spread out on several acres under the open sky, there are hundreds and thousands of tons of it in one building, heaped here and there in haystack piles, covering the floor several inches deep, and filling the air with a choking dust that becomes a blinding sandstorm when the wind stirs.

The month of May was an exceptionally cool one, and his (thousands) secret prayers were granted; but early in June there came a record-breaking hot spell, and after that there were men wanted in the fertilizer mill.

The boss of the grinding room had come to know Jurgis by this time, and had marked him (boss) for a likely man; and so when he (man) came to the door about two o'clock this breathless hot day, he (man) felt a sudden spasm of pain shoot through him (man)--the boss beckoned to him (man)!

In ten minutes more Jurgis had pulled off his (man) coat and overshirt, and set his (man) teeth together and gone to work.

It was to this building that Jurgis came daily, as if dragged by an unseen hand. Here was one more difficulty for him (man) to meet and conquer!

Before him (man) was one of the vents of the mill in which the fertilizer was being ground--rushing forth in a great brown river, with a spray of the finest dust flung forth in clouds.

Jurgis was given a shovel, and along with half a dozen others it was his (man) task to shovel this fertilizer into carts.

That others were at work he (man) knew by the sound, and by the fact that he (man) sometimes collided with them; otherwise they might as well not have been there, for in the blinding dust storm a man could not see six feet in front of his (man) face.

When he (man) had filled one cart he (man) had to grope around him (man) until another came, and if there was none on hand he (man) continued to grope till one arrived.

In five minutes he (man) was, of course, a mass of fertilizer from head to feet; they gave him (man) a sponge to tie over his (man) mouth, so that he (man) could breathe, but the sponge did not prevent his (man) lips and eyelids from caking up with it and his (man) ears from filling solid.

He (man) looked like a brown ghost at twilight--from hair to shoes he (man) became the color of the building and of everything in it, and for that matter a hundred yards outside it.

The building had to be left open, and when the wind blew Durham and Company lost a great deal of fertilizer.

Working in his (Company) shirt sleeves, and with the thermometer at over a hundred, the phosphates soaked in through every pore of Jurgis' skin, and in five minutes he (Company) had a headache, and in fifteen was almost dazed.

The blood was pounding in his (Company) brain like an engine's throbbing; there was a frightful pain in the top of his (Company) skull, and he (Company) could hardly control his (Company) hands.

Still, with the memory of his (Company) four months' siege behind him (Company), he (Company) fought on, in a frenzy of determination; and half an hour later he (Company) began to vomit--he (Company) vomited until it seemed as if his (Company) inwards must be torn into shreds.

A man could get used to the fertilizer mill, the boss had said, if he (boss) would make up his (boss) mind to it; but Jurgis now began to see that it was a question of making up his (boss) stomach.

His (boss) labor took him (boss) about one minute to learn. At the end of that day of horror, he (boss) could scarcely stand.

Most of the men, when they came out, made straight for a saloon--they seemed to place fertilizer and rattlesnake poison in one class.

But Jurgis was too ill to think of drinking--he (boss) could only make his (boss) way to the street and stagger on to a car.

He (boss) had a sense of humor, and later on, when he (boss) became an old hand, he (boss) used to think it fun to board a streetcar and see what happened.

Now, however, he (boss) was too ill to notice it--how the people in the car began to gasp and sputter, to put their handkerchiefs to their noses, and transfix him (boss) with furious glances.

Jurgis only knew that a man in front of him (man) immediately got up and gave him (man) a seat; and that half a minute later the two people on each side of him (man) got up; and that in a full minute the crowded car was nearly empty--those passengers who could not get room on the platform having gotten out to walk.

He (man) had to catch himself now and then, and lean against a building and get his (man) bearings. Of course Jurgis had made his (man) home a miniature fertilizer mill a minute after entering.

The stuff was half an inch deep in his (man) skin--his (man) whole system was full of it, and it would have taken a week not merely of scrubbing, but of vigorous exercise, to get it out of him (man).

As it was, he (man) could be compared with nothing known to men, save that newest discovery of the savants, a substance which emits energy for an unlimited time, without being itself in the least diminished in power.

He (man) smelled so that he (man) made all the food at the table taste, and set the whole family to vomiting; for himself it was three days before he (man) could keep anything upon his (man) stomach--he (man) might wash his (man) hands, and use a knife and fork, but were not his (man) mouth and throat filled with the poison?

In spite of splitting headaches he (man) would stagger down to the plant and take up his (man) stand once more, and begin to shovel in the blinding clouds of dust.

And so at the end of the week he (man) was a fertilizer man for life--he (man) was able to eat again, and though his (man) head never stopped aching, it ceased to be so bad that he (man) could not work.

It was a summer of prosperity, all over the country, and the country ate generously of packing house products, and there was plenty of work for all the family, in spite of the packers' efforts to keep a superfluity of labor.

They were again able to pay their debts and to begin to save a little sum; but there were one or two sacrifices they considered too heavy to be made for long

And still Jurgis stuck it out! So there passed another summer. --it was too bad that the boys should have to sell papers at their age.

It was utterly useless to caution them and plead with them; quite without knowing it, they were taking on the tone of their new environment.

They were learning to swear in voluble English; they were learning to pick up cigar stumps and smoke them, to pass hours of their time gambling with pennies and dice and cigarette cards; they were learning the location of all the houses of prostitution on the

``Levee,'' (police)
and the names of the
``madames'' (police)
who kept them, and the days when they gave their state banquets, which the police captains and the big politicians all attended.

If a visiting

``country customer'' (him)
were to ask them, they could show him (them) which was
``Hinkydink's'' (him)
famous saloon, and could even point out to him (them) by name the different gamblers and thugs and
``hold-up men'' (thugs)
who made the place their headquarters.

What was the use, they would ask, of wasting time and energy and a possible carfare riding out to the stockyards every night when the weather was pleasant and they could crawl under a truck or into an empty doorway and sleep exactly as well?

And worse yet, the boys were getting out of the habit of coming home at night. So long as they brought home a half dollar for each day, what mattered it when they brought it?

But Jurgis declared that from this to ceasing to come at all would not be a very long step, and so it was decided that Vilimas and Nikalojus should return to school in the fall, and that instead Elzbieta should go out and get some work, her (Elzbieta) place at home being taken by her (Elzbieta) younger daughter.

Little Kotrina was like most children of the poor, prematurely made old; she (Elzbieta) had to take care of her (Elzbieta) little brother, who was a cripple, and also of the baby; she (Elzbieta) had to cook the meals and wash the dishes and clean house, and have supper ready when the workers came home in the evening.

She (Elzbieta) was only thirteen, and small for her (Elzbieta) age, but she (Elzbieta) did all this without a murmur; and her (Elzbieta) mother went out, and after trudging a couple of days about the yards, settled down as a servant of a

``sausage machine.

Elzbieta was used to working, but she (Elzbieta) found this change a hard one, for the reason that she (Elzbieta) had to stand motionless upon her (Elzbieta) feet from seven o'clock in the morning till half-past twelve, and again from one till half-past five.

For the first few days it seemed to her (Elzbieta) that she (Elzbieta) could not stand it--she (Elzbieta) suffered almost as much as Jurgis had from the fertilizer, and would come out at sundown with her (Elzbieta) head fairly reeling.

Besides this, she (Elzbieta) was working in one of the dark holes, by electric light, and the dampness, too, was deadly--there were always puddles of water on the floor, and a sickening odor of moist flesh in the room.

The people who worked here followed the ancient custom of nature, whereby the ptarmigan is the color of dead leaves in the fall and of snow in the winter, and the chameleon, who is black when he (chameleon) lies upon a stump and turns green when he (chameleon) moves to a leaf.

'' (a servant)

The men and women who worked in this department were precisely the color of the
``fresh country sausage'' (women)
they made.

The sausage-room was an interesting place to visit, for two or three minutes, and provided that you did not look at the people; the machines were perhaps the most wonderful things in the entire plant.

Presumably sausages were once chopped and stuffed by hand, and if so it would be interesting to know how many workers had been displaced by these inventions.

On one side of the room were the hoppers, into which men shoveled loads of meat and wheelbarrows full of spices; in these great bowls were whirling knives that made two thousand revolutions a minute, and when the meat was ground fine and adulterated with potato flour, and well mixed with water, it was forced to the stuffing machines on the other side of the room.

The latter were tended by women; there was a sort of spout, like the nozzle of a hose, and one of the women would take a long string of

``casing'' (the women)
and put the end over the nozzle and then work the whole thing on, as one works on the finger of a tight glove.

This string would be twenty or thirty feet long, but the woman would have it all on in a jiffy; and when she (woman) had several on, she (woman) would press a lever, and a stream of sausage meat would be shot out, taking the casing with it as it came.

In front was a big pan which caught these creatures, and two more women who seized them as fast as they appeared and twisted them into links.

This was for the uninitiated the most perplexing work of all; for all that the woman had to give was a single turn of the wrist; and in some way she (woman) contrived to give it so that instead of an endless chain of sausages, one after another, there grew under her (woman) hands a bunch of strings,

Thus one might stand and see appear, miraculously born from the machine, a wriggling snake of sausage of incredible length. all dangling from a single center.

It was quite like the feat of a prestidigitator--for the woman worked so fast that the eye could literally not follow her (woman), and there was only a mist of motion, and tangle after tangle of sausages appearing.

In the midst of the mist, however, the visitor would suddenly notice the tense set face, with the two wrinkles graven in the forehead, and the ghastly pallor of the cheeks; and then he (visitor) would suddenly recollect that it was time he (visitor) was going on.

The woman did not go on; she (woman) stayed right there--hour after hour, day after day, year after year, twisting sausage links and racing with death.

It was piecework, and she (woman) was apt to have a family to keep alive; and stern and ruthless economic laws had arranged it that she (woman) could only do this by working just as she (woman) did, with all her (woman) soul upon her (woman) work, and with never an instant for a glance at the well-dressed ladies and gentlemen who came to stare at her (woman), as at some wild beast in a menagerie.

With one member trimming beef in a cannery, and another working in a sausage factory, the family had a first-hand knowledge of the great majority of Packingtown swindles.

For it was the custom, as they found, whenever meat was so spoiled that it could not be used for anything else, either to can it or else to chop it up into sausage.

With what had been told them by Jonas, who had worked in the pickle rooms, they could now study the whole of the spoiled-meat industry on the inside, and read a new and grim meaning into that old Packingtown jest--that they use everything of the pig except the squeal.

Jonas had told them how the meat that was taken out of pickle would often be found sour, and how they would rub it up with soda to take away the smell, and sell it to be eaten on free-lunch counters; also of all the miracles of chemistry which they performed, giving to any sort of meat, fresh or salted, whole or chopped, any color and any flavor and any odor they chose.

In the pickling of hams they had an ingenious apparatus, by which they saved time and increased the capacity of the plant--a machine consisting of a hollow needle attached to a pump; by plunging this needle into the meat and working with his (they) foot, a man could fill a ham with pickle in a few seconds.

And yet, in spite of this, there would be hams found spoiled, some of them with an odor so bad that a man could hardly bear to be in the room with them.

To pump into these the packers had a second and much stronger pickle which destroyed the odor--a process known to the workers as

``giving them thirty per cent.

Chapter 14 '' (the workers)

Also, after the hams had been smoked, there would be found some that had gone to the bad.

Formerly these had been sold as

``Number Three Grade,'' (some person)
but later on some ingenious person had hit upon a new device, and now they would extract the bone, about which the bad part generally lay, and insert in the hole a white-hot iron.

The packers were always originating such schemes--they had what they called

``boneless hams,'' (The packers)
which were all the odds and ends of pork stuffed into casings; and
``California hams,'' (The packers)
which were the shoulders, with big knuckle joints, and nearly all the meat cut out; and fancy
``skinned hams,'' (The packers)
which were made of the oldest hogs, whose skins were so heavy and coarse that no one would buy them--that is, until they had been cooked and chopped fine and labeled
``head cheese!

After this invention there was no longer Number One, Two, and Three Grade--there was only Number One Grade. '' (The packers)

It was only when the whole ham was spoiled that it came into the department of Elzbieta.

Cut up by the two-thousand-revolutions-a-minute flyers, and mixed with half a ton of other meat, no odor that ever was in a ham could make any difference.

There was never the least attention paid to what was cut up for sausage; there would come all the way back from Europe old sausage that had been rejected, and that was moldy and white--it would be dosed with borax and glycerine, and dumped into the hoppers, and made over again for home consumption.

There would be meat that had tumbled out on the floor, in the dirt and sawdust, where the workers had tramped and spit uncounted billions of consumption germs.

There would be meat stored in great piles in rooms; and the water from leaky roofs would drip over it, and thousands of rats would race about on it.

It was too dark in these storage places to see well, but a man could run his (man) hand over these piles of meat and sweep off handfuls of the dried dung of rats.

These rats were nuisances, and the packers would put poisoned bread out for them; they would die, and then rats, bread, and meat would go into the hoppers together.

This is no fairy story and no joke; the meat would be shoveled into carts, and the man who did the shoveling would not trouble to lift out a rat even when he (man) saw one--there were things that went into the sausage in comparison with which a poisoned rat was a tidbit.

There was no place for the men to wash their hands before they ate their dinner, and so they made a practice of washing them in the water that was to be ladled into the sausage.

There were the butt-ends of smoked meat, and the scraps of corned beef, and all the odds and ends of the waste of the plants, that would be dumped into old barrels in the cellar and left there.

Under the system of rigid economy which the packers enforced, there were some jobs that it only paid to do once in a long time, and among these was the cleaning out of the waste barrels.

Every spring they did it; and in the barrels would be dirt and rust and old nails and stale water--and cartload after cartload of it would be taken up and dumped into the hoppers with fresh meat, and sent out to the public's breakfast.

Some of it they would make into

``smoked'' (unknown)
sausage--but as the smoking took time, and was therefore expensive, they would call upon their chemistry department, and preserve it with borax and color it with gelatine to make it brown.

All of their sausage came out of the same bowl, but when they came to wrap it they would stamp some of it

``special,'' (unknown)
and for this they would charge two cents more a pound.

Such were the new surroundings in which Elzbieta was placed, and such was the work she (Elzbieta) was compelled to do. It was stupefying, brutalizing work; it left her (Elzbieta) no time to think, no strength for anything.

She (Elzbieta) was part of the machine she (Elzbieta) tended, and every faculty that was not needed for the machine was doomed to be crushed out of existence.

There was only one mercy about the cruel grind--that it gave her (Elzbieta) the gift of insensibility. Little by little she (Elzbieta) sank into a torpor--she (Elzbieta) fell silent.

She (Elzbieta) would meet Jurgis and Ona in the evening, and the three would walk home together, often without saying a word.

Ona, too, was falling into a habit of silence-- Ona, who had once gone about singing like a bird. She (Ona) was sick and miserable, and often she (Ona) would barely have strength enough to drag herself home.

And there they would eat what they had to eat, and afterward, because there was only their misery to talk of, they would crawl into bed and fall into a stupor and never stir until it was time to get up again, and dress by candlelight, and go back to the machines.

They were so numbed that they did not even suffer much from hunger, now; only the children continued to fret when the food ran short.

Yet the soul of Ona was not dead--the souls of none of them were dead, but only sleeping; and now and then they would waken, and these were cruel times.

The gates of memory would roll open--old joys would stretch out their arms to them, old hopes and dreams would call to them, and they would stir beneath the burden that lay upon them, and feel its forever immeasurable weight.

It was a thing scarcely to be spoken--a thing never spoken by all the world, that will not know its own defeat.

They could not even cry out beneath it; but anguish would seize them, more dreadful than the agony of death. They were beaten; they had lost the game, they were swept aside.

It was not less tragic because it was so sordid, because it had to do with wages and grocery bills and rents.

They had dreamed of freedom; of a chance to look about them and learn something; to be decent and clean, to see their child grow up to be strong.

Six years more of toil they had to face before they could expect the least respite, the cessation of the payments upon the house; and

And now it was all gone--it would never be! They had played the game and they had lost. how cruelly certain it was that they could never stand six years of such a life as they were living!

They were lost, they were going down--and there was no deliverance for them, no hope; for all the help it gave them the vast city in which they lived might have been an ocean waste, a wilderness, a desert, a tomb.

; she (it) would lie, afraid of the beating of her (it) own heart, fronting the blood-red eyes of the old primeval terror of life.

So often this mood would come to Ona, in the nighttime, when something wakened her (Ona) Once she (Ona) cried aloud, and woke Jurgis, who was tired and cross.

After that she (Ona) learned to weep silently--their moods so seldom came together now! It was as if their hopes were buried in separate graves.

He (their) had never spoken of it, nor would he (their) allow any one else to speak of it--he (their) had never acknowledged its existence to himself.

Jurgis, being a man, had troubles of his (man) own. There was another specter following him (man). Yet the battle with it took all the manhood that he (man) had--and once or twice, alas, a little more.

He (man) was working in the steaming pit of hell; day after day, week after week--until now, there was not an organ of his (man) body that did its work without pain, until the sound of ocean breakers echoed in his (man) head day and night, and the buildings swayed and danced before him (man) as he (man) went down the street.

He (man) could forget the pain, he (man) could slip off the burden; he (man) would see clearly again, he (man) would be master of his (man) brain, of his (man) thoughts, of his (man) will.

His (man) dead self would stir in him (man), and he (man) would find himself laughing and cracking jokes with his (man) companions--he (man) would be a man again, and master of his (man) life.

Jurgis had discovered drink. And from all the unending horror of this there was a respite, a deliverance--he (man) could drink! It was not an easy thing for Jurgis to take more than two or three drinks.

With the first drink he (man) could eat a meal, and he (man) could persuade himself that that was economy; with the second he (man) could eat another meal--but there would come a time when he (man) could eat no more, and then to pay for a drink was an unthinkable extravagance, a defiance of the age-long instincts of his (man) hunger-haunted class.

One day, however, he (man) took the plunge, and drank up all that he (man) had in his (man) pockets, and went home half

``piped,'' (he)
as the men phrase it.

He (man) was happier than he (man) had been in a year; and yet, because he (man) knew that the happiness would not last, he (man) was savage, too with those who would wreck it, and with the world, and with his (man) life; and then again, beneath this, he (man) was sick with the shame of himself.

Afterward, when he (man) saw the despair of his (man) family, and reckoned up the money he (man) had spent, the tears came into his (man) eyes, and he (man) began the long battle with the specter.

It was a battle that had no end, that never could have one. But Jurgis did not realize that very clearly; he (man) was not given much time for reflection.

Steeped in misery and despair as he (man) was, merely to walk down the street was to be put upon the rack.

There was surely a saloon on the corner--perhaps on all four corners, and some in the middle of the block as well; and each one stretched out a hand to him (man)

Going and coming--before sunrise and after dark--there was warmth and a glow of light, and the steam of hot food, and perhaps music, or a friendly face, and a word of good cheer.

Jurgis developed a fondness for having Ona on his (man) arm whenever he (man) went out on the street, and he (man) would hold her (Ona) tightly, and walk fast.

He (man) simply knew that he (man) was always fighting. each one had a personality of its own, allurements unlike any other. It was pitiful to have Ona know of this

--it drove him (man) wild to think of it; the thing was not fair, for Ona had never tasted drink, and so could not understand.

Sometimes, in desperate hours, he (man) would find himself wishing that she (Ona) might learn what it was, so that he (man) need not be ashamed in her (Ona) presence.

So there came a time when nearly all the conscious life of Jurgis consisted of a struggle with the craving for liquor.

They might drink together, and escape from the horror--escape for a while, come what would. He (man) would have ugly moods, when he (man) hated Ona and the whole family, because they stood in his (man) way.

It was all because he (man) was a married man that he (man) was compelled to stay in the yards; if it had not been for that he (man) might have gone off like Jonas, and to hell with the packers.

He (Jonas) was a fool to have married; he (Jonas) had tied himself down, had made himself a slave. There were few single men in the fertilizer mill--and those few were working only for a chance to escape.

Meantime, too, they had something to think about while they worked,--they had the memory of the last time they had been drunk, and the hope of the time when they would be drunk again.

As for Jurgis, he (Jonas) was expected to bring home every penny; he (Jonas) could not even go with the men at noontime--he (Jonas) was supposed to sit down and eat his (Jonas) dinner on a pile of fertilizer dust.

This was not always his (Jonas) mood, of course; he (Jonas) still loved his (Jonas) family. But just now was a time of trial.

Poor little Antanas, for instance--who had never failed to win him (Antanas) with a smile--little Antanas was not smiling just now, being a mass of fiery red pimples.

He (Antanas) had had all the diseases that babies are heir to, in quick succession, scarlet fever, mumps, and whooping cough in the first year, and now he (Antanas) was down with the measles.

but Kotrina; there was no doctor to help him (doctor), because they were too poor, and children did not die of the measles--at least not often.

Now and then Kotrina would find time to sob over his (doctor) woes, but for the greater part of the time he (doctor) had to be left alone, barricaded upon the bed.

There was no one to attend him (doctor) The floor was full of drafts, and if he (doctor) caught cold he (doctor) would die.

At night he (doctor) was tied down, lest he (doctor) should kick the covers off him (doctor), while the family lay in their stupor of exhaustion.

He (doctor) would lie and scream for hours, almost in convulsions; and then, when he (doctor) was worn out, he (doctor) would lie whimpering and wailing in his (doctor) torment.

He (doctor) was burning up with fever, and his (doctor) eyes were running sores; in the daytime he (doctor) was a thing uncanny and impish to behold, a plaster of pimples and sweat, a great purple lump of misery.

Yet all this was not really as cruel as it sounds, for, sick as he (doctor) was, little Antanas was the least unfortunate member of that family.

He (Antanas) was quite able to bear his (Antanas) sufferings--it was as if he (Antanas) had all these complaints to show what a prodigy of health he (Antanas) was.

He (Antanas) was the child of his (Antanas) parents' youth and joy; he (Antanas) grew up like the conjurer's rosebush, and all the world was his (Antanas) oyster.

In general, he (Antanas) toddled around the kitchen all day with a lean and hungry look--the portion of the family's allowance that fell to him (Antanas) was not enough, and he (Antanas) was unrestrainable in his (Antanas) demand for more.

It seemed as if he (Antanas) had taken all of his (Antanas) mother's strength--had left nothing for those that might come after him (Antanas).

Ona was with child again now, and it was a dreadful thing to contemplate; even Jurgis, dumb and despairing as he (Antanas) was, could not but understand that yet other agonies were on the way, and shudder at the thought of them.

Antanas was but little over a year old, and already no one but his (Antanas) father could manage him (Antanas). For Ona was visibly going to pieces.

She (Ona) had had a trace of it ever since that fatal morning when the greedy streetcar corporation had turned her (Ona) out into the rain; but now it was beginning to grow serious, and to wake her (Ona) up at night.

Even worse than that was the fearful nervousness from which she (Ona) suffered; she (Ona) would have frightful headaches and fits of aimless weeping; and sometimes she (Ona) would come home at night shuddering and moaning, and would fling herself down upon the bed and burst into tears.

In the first place she (Ona) was developing a cough, like the one that had killed old Dede Antanas. Several times she (Ona) was quite beside herself and hysterical; and then Jurgis would go half-mad with fright.

Elzbieta would explain to him (Antanas) that it could not be helped, that a woman was subject to such things when she (woman) was pregnant; but he (Antanas) was hardly to be persuaded, and would beg and plead to know what had happened.

It was the life she (woman) had to live, the accursed work she (woman) had to do, that was killing her (woman) by inches.

She (woman) was not fitted for it--no woman was fitted for it, no woman ought to be allowed to do such work; if the world could not keep them alive any other way it ought to kill them at once and be done with it.

She (woman) had never been like this before, he (Antanas) would argue--it was monstrous and unthinkable. They ought not to marry, to have children; no workingman ought to marry--

So he (Antanas) would carry on, becoming half hysterical himself, which was an unbearable thing to see in a big man; Ona would pull herself together and fling herself into his (man) arms, begging him (man) to stop, to be still, that she (Ona) would be better, it would be all right.

So she (Ona) would lie and sob out her (Ona) grief upon his (man) shoulder, while he (man) gazed at her (Ona), as helpless as a wounded animal, the target of unseen enemies.

if he (man), Jurgis, had known what a woman was like, he (man) would have had his (man) eyes torn out first. Chapter 15

The beginning of these perplexing things was in the summer; and each time Ona would promise him (man) with terror in her (Ona) voice that it would not happen again--but in vain.

Each crisis would leave Jurgis more and more frightened, more disposed to distrust Elzbieta's consolations, and to believe that there was some terrible thing about all this that he (man) was not allowed to know.

Once or twice in these outbreaks he (man) caught Ona's eye, and it seemed to him (man) like the eye of a hunted animal; there were broken phrases of anguish and despair now and then, amid her (Ona) frantic weeping.

But he (man) never thought of it, except when he (man) was dragged to it--he (man) lived like a dumb beast of burden, knowing only the moment in which he (man) was.

It was only because he (man) was so numb and beaten himself that Jurgis did not worry more about this. The winter was coming on again, more menacing and cruel than ever.

It was necessary for the packing machines to grind till late at night to provide food that would be eaten at Christmas breakfasts; and Marija and Elzbieta and Ona, as part of the machine, began working fifteen or sixteen hours a day.

It was October, and the holiday rush had begun. There was no choice about this-- whatever work there was to be done

they had to do, if they wished to keep their places; besides that, it added another pittance to their incomes. So they staggered on with the awful load.

They would start work every morning at seven, and eat their dinners at noon, and then work until ten or eleven at night without another mouthful of food.

Jurgis wanted to wait for them, to help them home at night, but they would not think of this; the fertilizer mill was not running overtime, and there was no place for him (they) to wait save in a saloon.

Each would stagger out into the darkness, and make her (they) way to the corner, where they met; or if the others had already gone, would get into a car, and begin a painful struggle to keep awake.

When they got home they were always too tired either to eat or to undress; they would crawl into bed with their shoes on, and lie like logs.

If they should fail, they would certainly be lost; if they held out, they might have enough coal for the winter.

A day or two before Thanksgiving Day there came a snowstorm. It began in the afternoon, and by evening two inches had fallen.

Jurgis tried to wait for the women, but went into a saloon to get warm, and took two drinks, and came out and ran home to escape from the demon; there he (demon) lay down to wait for them, and instantly fell asleep.

When he (demon) opened his (demon) eyes again he (demon) was in the midst of a nightmare, and found Elzbieta shaking him (demon) and crying out.

At first he (demon) could not realize what she (Elzbieta) was saying--Ona had not come home. What time was it, he (demon) asked. It was morning--time to be up.

Ona had not been home that night! And it was bitter cold, and a foot of snow on the ground. Jurgis sat up with a start.

Marija was crying with fright and the children were wailing in sympathy--little Stanislovas in addition, because the terror of the snow was upon him (demon).

Jurgis had nothing to put on but his (demon) shoes and his (demon) coat, and in half a minute he (demon) was out of the door.

Then, however, he (demon) realized that there was no need of haste, that he (demon) had no idea where to go. It was still dark as midnight, and the thick snowflakes were sifting down

--everything was so silent that he (demon) could hear the rustle of them as they fell. In the few seconds that he (demon) stood there hesitating he (demon) was covered white.

He (demon) set off at a run for the yards, stopping by the way to inquire in the saloons that were open.

When he (demon) got to the place where she (they) worked he (demon) inquired of one of the watchmen--there had not been any accident, so far as the man had heard.

At the time office, which he (man) found already open, the clerk told him (man) that Ona's check had been turned in the night before, showing that she (Ona) had left her (Ona) work.

After that there was nothing for him (man) to do but wait, pacing back and forth in the snow, meantime, to keep from freezing.

Already the yards were full of activity; cattle were being unloaded from the cars in the distance, and across the way the

``beef-luggers'' (unknown)
were toiling in the darkness, carrying two-hundred-pound quarters of bullocks into the refrigerator cars.

Before the first streaks of daylight there came the crowding throngs of workingmen, shivering, and swinging their dinner pails as they hurried by.

Jurgis took up his (man) stand by the time-office window, where alone there was light enough for him (man) to see; the snow fell so quick that it was only by peering closely that he (man) could make sure that Ona did not pass him (man).

Ona might have been overcome on the way; or else she (Ona) might have met with an accident in the machines. Seven o'clock came, the hour when the great packing machine began to move.

Jurgis ought to have been at his (man) place in the fertilizer mill; but instead he (man) was waiting, in an agony of fear, for Ona.

It was fifteen minutes after the hour when he (man) saw a form emerge from the snow mist, and sprang toward it with a cry.

It was she (Ona), running swiftly; as she (Ona) saw him (man), she (Ona) staggered forward, and half fell into his (man) outstretched arms. '' What has been the matter?

'' he (man) cried, anxiously. '' Where have you been? '' It was several seconds before she (Ona) could get breath to answer him (man).

'' I couldn't get home,'' she (Ona) exclaimed. '' The snow--the cars had stopped.'' '' But where were you then?'' he (man) demanded.

Jurgis drew a deep breath; but then he (man) noticed that she (Ona) was sobbing and trembling--as if in one of those nervous crises that he (man) dreaded so.

'' I had to go home with a friend,'' she (Ona) panted--

``with Jadvyga. '' (she)
'' But what's the matter? '' he (man) cried.

'' What has happened?''

``Oh, Jurgis, I was so frightened! '' (she)
she (Ona) said, clinging to him (man) wildly. '' I have been so worried!

'' They were near the time station window, and people were staring at them. Jurgis led her (Ona) away. '' How do you mean?

'' he (man) asked, in perplexity. '' I was afraid-- I was just afraid! '' sobbed Ona. '' I knew you wouldn't know where I was, and I didn't know what you might do.

I tried to get home, but I was so tired. Oh, Jurgis, Jurgis! '' He (man) was so glad to get her (Ona) back that he (man) could not think clearly about anything else.

It did not seem strange to him (man) that she (Ona) should be so very much upset; all her (Ona) fright and incoherent protestations did not matter since he (man) had her (Ona) back.

He (man) let her (Ona) cry away her (Ona) tears; and then, because it was nearly eight o'clock, and they would lose another hour if they delayed, he (man) left her (Ona) at the packing house door, with her (Ona) ghastly white face and her (Ona) haunted eyes of terror.

Christmas was almost come; and because the snow still held, and the searching cold, morning after morning Jurgis half carried his (man) wife to her (wife) post, staggering with her (wife) through the darkness; until at last, one night, came the end.

There was another brief interval. It lacked but three days of the holidays. About midnight Marija and Elzbieta came home, exclaiming in alarm when they found that Ona had not come.

The two had agreed to meet her (Ona); and, after waiting, had gone to the room where she (Ona) worked; only to find that the ham-wrapping girls had quit work an hour before, and left.

There was no snow that night, nor was it especially cold; and still Ona had not come! Something more serious must be wrong this time.

She (Ona) must have gone home again with Jadvyga, he (Ona) said; Jadvyga lived only two blocks from the yards, and perhaps she (Ona) had been tired.

They aroused Jurgis, and he (Ona) sat up and listened crossly to the story. Nothing could have happened to her (Ona)--and even if there had, there was nothing could be done about it until morning.

Jurgis turned over in his (Ona) bed, and was snoring again before the two had closed the door. In the morning, however, he (Ona) was up and out nearly an hour before the usual time.

Jadvyga Marcinkus lived on the other side of the yards, beyond Halsted Street, with her (Ona) mother and sisters, in a single basement room--for Mikolas had recently lost one hand from blood poisoning, and their marriage had been put off forever.

The door of the room was in the rear, reached by a narrow court, and Jurgis saw a light in the window and heard something frying as he (Ona) passed; he (Ona) knocked, half expecting that Ona would answer.

Instead there was one of Jadvyga's little sisters, who gazed at him (Ona) through a crack in the door. '' Where's Ona?

'' he (Ona) demanded; and the child looked at him (Ona) in perplexity. '' Ona?'' she (Ona) said. '' Yes,'' said Jurgis,

``isn't she (Ona) here?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

'' No,'' said the child, and Jurgis gave a start. A moment later came Jadvyga, peering over the child's head. When she (Ona) saw who it was, she (Ona) slid around out of sight, for she (Ona) was not quite dressed.

Jurgis must excuse her (Ona), she (Ona) began, her (Ona) mother was very ill-- '' Ona isn't here?'' Jurgis demanded, too alarmed to wait for her (Ona) to finish.

'' Why, no,'' said Jadvyga. '' What made you think she (Ona) would be here? Had she (Ona) said she (Ona) was coming?'' ''

No,'' he (Ona) answered. '' But she (Ona) hasn't come home--and I thought she (Ona) would be here the same as before. '' ''

As before?'' echoed Jadvyga, in perplexity. '' The time she (Ona) spent the night here,'' said Jurgis. '' There must be some mistake,'' she (Ona) answered, quickly.

'' Ona has never spent the night here. '' He (Ona) was only half able to realize the words. '' Why--why--'' he (Ona) exclaimed.

'' Two weeks ago. Jadvyga! She (Ona) told me so the night it snowed, and she (Ona) could not get home.''

``There must be some mistake,'' (the girl)
declared the girl, again;
``she (girl) didn't come here.

He (Ona) steadied himself by the door-sill; and Jadvyga in her (girl) anxiety--for she (girl) was fond of Ona--opened the door wide, holding her (Ona) jacket across her (Ona) throat.

'' (the girl)

'' Are you sure you didn't misunderstand her (Ona)? '' she (Ona) cried. '' She (Ona) must have meant somewhere else. She (Ona)--'' ''

She (Ona) said here,'' insisted Jurgis. '' She (Ona) told me all about you, and how you were, and what you said. Are you sure?

You haven't forgotten? You weren't away?''

``No, no! '' (she)
she (Ona) exclaimed--and then came a peevish voice--
``Jadvyga, you are giving the baby a cold.

Jurgis stood for half a minute more, stammering his (Ona) perplexity through an eighth of an inch of crack; and then, as there was really nothing more to be said, he (Ona) excused himself and went away.

Shut the door!'' (she)

He (Ona) walked on half dazed, without knowing where he (Ona) went. Ona had deceived him (Ona)! She (Ona) had lied to him (Ona)!

He (Ona) could hardly grasp the thing--much less try to solve it; but a hundred wild surmises came to him (Ona), a sense of impending calamity overwhelmed him (Ona).

And what could it mean--where had she (Ona) been? Where was she (Ona) now? Because there was nothing else to do, he (Ona) went back to the time office to watch again.

He (Ona) waited until nearly an hour after seven, and then went to the room where Ona worked to make inquiries of Ona's ``forelady.

The

``forelady,'' (he)
he (Ona) found, had not yet come; all the lines of cars that came from downtown were stalled--there had been an accident in the powerhouse, and no cars had been running since last night.

'' Meantime, however, the ham-wrappers were working away, with some one else in charge of them. The girl who answered Jurgis was busy, and as she (girl) talked she (girl) looked to see if she (girl) were being watched.

Then a man came up, wheeling a truck; he (man) knew Jurgis for Ona's husband, and was curious about the mystery. ''

Maybe the cars had something to do with it,'' he (man) suggested--

``maybe she (Ona) had gone down-town.'' (he)
'' No,'' said Jurgis,
``she (Ona) never went down-town.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

``Perhaps not,'' (the man)
said the man. Jurgis thought he (man) saw him (man) exchange a swift glance with the girl as he (man) spoke, and he (man) demanded quickly.

'' What do you know about it? '' But the man had seen that the boss was watching him (boss); he (boss) started on again, pushing his (boss) truck.

'' I don't know anything about it,'' he (boss) said, over his (boss) shoulder. '' How should I know where your wife goes?

'' Then Jurgis went out again and paced up and down before the building. All the morning he (boss) stayed there, with no thought of his (boss) work.

About noon he (boss) went to the police station to make inquiries, and then came back again for another anxious vigil. Finally, toward the middle of the afternoon, he (boss) set out for home once more.

He (boss) was walking out Ashland Avenue. The streetcars had begun running again, and several passed him (boss), packed to the steps with people.

The sight of them set Jurgis to thinking again of the man's sarcastic remark; and half involuntarily he (man) found himself watching the cars--with the result that he (man) gave a sudden startled exclamation, and stopped short in his (man) tracks.

That rusty black hat with the drooping red flower, it might not be Ona's, but there was very little likelihood of it.

Then he (man) broke into a run. For a whole block he (man) tore after the car, only a little ways behind. He (man) would know for certain very soon, for she (Ona) would get out two blocks ahead.

He (man) slowed down, and let the car go on. She (Ona) got out: and as soon as she (Ona) was out of sight on the side street

: he (man) saw her (Ona) turn the corner near their home, and then he (man) ran again, and saw her (Ona) as she (Ona) went up the porch steps of the house.

After that he (man) turned back, and for five minutes paced up and down, his (man) hands clenched tightly and his (man) lips set, his (man) mind in a turmoil.

Jurgis broke into a run. Suspicion was rife in him (man) now, and he (man) was not ashamed to shadow her (Ona) Then he (man) went home and entered.

As he (man) opened the door, he (man) saw Elzbieta, who had also been looking for Ona, and had come home again. She (Ona) was now on tiptoe, and had a finger on her (Ona) lips.

Jurgis waited until she (Ona) was close to him (man). '' Don't make any noise,'' she (Ona) whispered, hurriedly. '' What's the matter'? ''

he (man) asked. '' Ona is asleep,'' she (Ona) panted. '' She (Ona)'s been very ill. I'm afraid her (Ona) mind's been wandering, Jurgis. She (Ona) was lost on the street all night, and I've only just succeeded in getting her (Ona) quiet.''

``When did she (Ona) come in? '' (he)
he (man) asked. '' Soon after you left this morning,'' said Elzbieta. '' And has she (Elzbieta) been out since?''

'' No, of course not. She (Elzbieta)'s so weak, Jurgis, she (Elzbieta)-- '' And he (man) set his (man) teeth hard together. '' You are lying to me,'' he (man) said.

Elzbieta started, and turned pale.

``Why!'' (she)
she (Elzbieta) gasped. '' What do you mean? '' But Jurgis did not answer. He (man) pushed her (Elzbieta) aside, and strode to the bedroom door and opened it.

Ona was sitting on the bed. She (Ona) turned a startled look upon him (man) as he (man) entered. He (man) closed the door in Elzbieta's face, and went toward his (man) wife.

She (Elzbieta) had her (Elzbieta) hands clasped tightly in her (Elzbieta) lap, and he (man) saw that her (Elzbieta) face was as white as paper, and drawn with pain.

'' Where have you been? '' he (man) demanded. She (Elzbieta) gasped once or twice as she (Elzbieta) tried to answer him (man), and then began, speaking low, and swiftly.

'' Jurgis, I--I think I have been out of my mind. I started to come last night, and I could not find the way.

I walked --I walked all night, I think, and--and I only got home--this morning.''

``You needed a rest,'' (he)
he (man) said, in a hard tone.

He (man) was looking her (Elzbieta) fairly in the face, and he (man) could read the sudden fear and wild uncertainty that leaped into her (Elzbieta) eyes.

'' Why did you go out again? '' '' I--I had to go to--to the store,'' she (Elzbieta) gasped, almost in a whisper,

``I had to go--'' (she)

``You are lying to me,'' (she)
said Jurgis. Then he (man) clenched his (man) hands and took a step toward her (Elzbieta). '' Why do you lie to me?

'' he (man) cried, fiercely. '' What are you doing that you have to lie to me?''

``Jurgis!'' (she)
she (Elzbieta) exclaimed, starting up in fright.

'' Oh, Jurgis, how can you?''

``You have lied to me, I say! '' (he)
he (man) cried. '' You told me you had been to Jadvyga's house that other night, and you hadn't.

You had been where you were last night--somewheres downtown, for I saw you get off the car. Where were you? ''

For half a second she (Elzbieta) stood, reeling and swaying, staring at him (man) with horror in her (Elzbieta) eyes; then, with a cry of anguish, she (Elzbieta) tottered forward, stretching out her (Elzbieta) arms to him (man).

It was as if he (man) had struck a knife into her (Elzbieta). She (Elzbieta) seemed to go all to pieces. But he (man) stepped aside, deliberately, and let her (Elzbieta) fall.

She (Elzbieta) caught herself at the side of the bed, and then sank down, burying her (Elzbieta) face in her (Elzbieta) hands and bursting into frantic weeping.

There came one of those hysterical crises that had so often dismayed him (man). Ona sobbed and wept, her (Ona) fear and anguish building themselves up into long climaxes.

Furious gusts of emotion would come sweeping over her (Ona), shaking her (Ona) as the tempest shakes the trees upon the hills; all her (Ona) frame would quiver and throb with them--it was as if some dreadful thing rose up within her (Ona) and took possession of her (Ona), torturing her (Ona), tearing her (Ona).

This thing had been wont to set Jurgis quite beside himself; but now he (man) stood with his (man) lips set tightly and his (man) hands clenched--she (Ona) might weep till she (Ona) killed herself, but she (Ona) should not move him (man) this time--not an inch, not an inch.

Because the sounds she (Ona) made set his (man) blood to running cold and his (man) lips to quivering in spite of himself, he (man) was glad of the diversion when Teta Elzbieta, pale with fright, opened the door and rushed in; yet he (man) turned upon her (Elzbieta) with an oath.

And then, as she (Elzbieta) stood hesitating, about to speak, he (man) seized her (Elzbieta) by the arm, and half flung her (Elzbieta) from the room, slamming the door and barring it with a table.

``Go out! '' (he)
he (man) cried,
``go out! '' (he)
Then he (man) turned again and faced Ona, crying--
``Now, answer me!'' (Ona/Little Ona)
Yet she (Ona) did not hear him (man)--she (Ona) was still in the grip of the fiend.

Jurgis could see her (Ona) outstretched hands, shaking and twitching, roaming here and there over the bed at will, like living things; he (fiend) could see convulsive shudderings start in her (Ona) body and run through her (Ona) limbs.

She (Ona) was sobbing and choking--it was as if there were too many sounds for one throat, they came chasing each other, like waves upon the sea.

Then her (Ona) voice would begin to rise into screams, louder and louder until it broke in wild, horrible peals of laughter.

Jurgis bore it until he (fiend) could bear it no longer, and then he (fiend) sprang at her (Ona), seizing her (Ona) by the shoulders and shaking her (Ona), shouting into her (Ona) ear:

``Stop it, I say! Stop it!'' (her)
She (Ona) looked up at him (fiend), out of her (Ona) agony; then she (Ona) fell forward at his (fiend) feet.

She (Ona) caught them in her (Ona) hands, in spite of his (fiend) efforts to step aside, and with her (Ona) face upon the floor lay writhing.

It made a choking in Jurgis' throat to hear her (Ona), and he (fiend) cried again, more savagely than before:

``Stop it, I say!

This time she (Ona) heeded him (fiend), and caught her (Ona) breath and lay silent, save for the gasping sobs that wrenched all her (Ona) frame.

For a long minute she (Ona) lay there, perfectly motionless, until a cold fear seized her (Ona) husband, thinking that she (Ona) was dying.

'' (he)

Suddenly, however, he (husband) heard her (Ona) voice, faintly:
``Jurgis! Jurgis! '' (he)
'' What is it? '' he (husband) said. He (husband) had to bend down to her (Ona), she (Ona) was so weak.

She (Ona) was pleading with him (husband), in broken phrases, painfully uttered:

``Have faith in me! Believe me!'' (him)
``Believe what?'' (he)
he (husband) cried. ''

Believe that I--that I know best--that I love you! And do not ask me--what you did. Oh, Jurgis, please, please! It is for the best--

it is-- '' He (husband) started to speak again, but she (Ona) rushed on frantically, heading him (husband) off. '' If you will only do it!

If you will only--only believe me! It wasn't my fault-- I couldn't help it--it will be all right --it is nothing--it is no harm.

She (Ona) had hold of him (husband), and was trying to raise herself to look at him (husband); he (husband) could feel the palsied shaking of her (Ona) hands and the heaving of the bosom she (Ona) pressed against him (husband).

She (Ona) managed to catch one of his (husband) hands and gripped it convulsively, drawing it to her (Ona) face, and bathing it in her (Ona) tears.

Oh, Jurgis--please, please!'' '' Oh, believe me, believe me! '' she (Ona) wailed again; and he (husband) shouted in fury,

``I will not!

'' (he)

But still she (Ona) clung to him (husband), wailing aloud in her (Ona) despair:
``Oh, Jurgis, think what you are doing! It will ruin us--it will ruin us!

Oh, no, you must not do it! No, don't, don't do it. You must not do it! It will drive me mad--it will kill me--no, no, Jurgis, I am crazy--it is nothing.

You do not really need to know. We can be happy--we can love each other just the same. Oh, please, please, believe me!

'' (him)

Her (it) words fairly drove him (me) wild. He (me) tore his (me) hands loose, and flung her (it) off. '' Answer me,'' he (me) cried.

'' God damn it, I say--answer me!'' She (it) sank down upon the floor, beginning to cry again. It was like listening to the moan of a damned soul, and Jurgis could not stand it.

He (God) smote his (God) fist upon the table by his (God) side, and shouted again at her (it),

``Answer me!'' (her)
She (it) began to scream aloud, her (it) voice like the voice of some wild beast:
``Ah!

Ah! I can't! I can't do it!'' (She)

``Why can't you do it? '' (he)
he (God) shouted. '' I don't know how!'' He (God) sprang and caught her (it) by the arm, lifting her (it) up, and glaring into her (it) face.

``Tell me where you were last night! '' (he)
he (God) panted. '' Quick, out with it!'' Then she (it) began to whisper, one word at a time:
``I--was in--a house--downtown--'' (she)
``What house?

What do you mean? '' (she)

She (it) tried to hide her (it) eyes away, but he (God) held her (it). '' Miss Henderson's house,'' she (Henderson) gasped.

And then suddenly, as in an explosion, the horrible truth burst over him (God), and he (God) reeled and staggered back with a scream.

He (God) did not understand at first. '' Miss Henderson's house,'' he (God) echoed. He (God) caught himself against the wall, and put his (God) hand to his (God) forehead, staring about him (God), and whispering,

``Jesus!

Jesus! '' (him)

An instant later he (Jesus) leaped at her (Henderson), as she (Henderson) lay groveling at his (Jesus) feet. He (Jesus) seized her (Henderson) by the throat.

She (Henderson) tried to get away, making him (Jesus) furious; he (Jesus) thought it was fear, of the pain of his (Jesus) clutch--he (Jesus) did not understand that it was the agony of her (Henderson) shame.

``Tell me!'' (he)
he (Jesus) gasped, hoarsely. '' Quick! Who took you to that place?'' Still she (Henderson) answered him (Jesus),
``Connor.'' (him)
``Connor,'' (he)
he (Connor) gasped.

'' He (Connor) tightened his (Connor) grip, in his (Connor) frenzy, and only when he (Connor) saw her (Henderson) eyes closing did he (Connor) realize that he (Connor) was choking her (Henderson).

'' Who is Connor?''

``The boss,'' (she)
she (Henderson) answered. '' The man-- Then he (Connor) relaxed his (Connor) fingers, and crouched, waiting, until she (Henderson) opened her (Henderson) lids again.

His (Connor) breath beat hot into her (Henderson) face.

``Tell me,'' (he)
he (Connor) whispered, at last,
``tell me about it. '' (he)
She (Henderson) lay perfectly motionless, and he (Connor) had to hold his (Connor) breath to catch her (Henderson) words.

'' I did not want--to do it,'' she (Henderson) said;

``I tried--I tried not to do it. I only did it--to save us.

It was our only chance. '' (she)

Again, for a space, there was no sound but his (Connor) panting. Ona's eyes closed and when she (Ona) spoke again she (Ona) did not open them.

'' He (Connor) told me--he (Connor) would have me turned off. He (Connor) told me he (Connor) would--we would all of us lose our places.

Jurgis' arms were shaking so that he (Connor) could scarcely hold himself up, and lurched forward now and then as he (Connor) listened.

We could never get anything to do--here--again. He (Connor)--he (Connor) meant it--he (Connor) would have ruined us. '' '' When--when did this begin? ''

he (Connor) gasped. '' At the very first,'' she (Ona) said. She (Ona) spoke as if in a trance. '' It was all--it was their plot--Miss Henderson's plot.

She (Henderson) hated me. And he (Connor)--he (Connor) wanted me. He (Connor) used to speak to me--out on the platform. Then he (Connor) began to--to make love to me.

He (Connor) offered me money. He (Connor) begged me--he (Connor) said he (Connor) loved me. Then he (Connor) threatened me. He (Connor) knew all about us, he (Connor) knew we would starve.

He (Connor) knew your boss--he (Connor) knew Marija's. He (Connor) would hound us to death, he (Connor) said--then he (Connor) said if I would--if I-- we would all of us be sure of work--always.

Then one day he (Connor) caught hold of me--he (Connor) would not let go--he (Connor)--he (Connor)-- ''

``Where was this?'' (he)
``In the hallway--at night--after every one had gone.

I could not help it. I thought of you--of the baby--of mother and the children. I was afraid of him (Connor)--afraid to cry out.

'' (unknown)

A moment ago her (mother) face had been ashen gray, now it was scarlet. She (mother) was beginning to breathe hard again.

Jurgis made not a sound. '' That was two months ago. Then he (Connor) wanted me to come--to that house. He (Connor) wanted me to stay there.

He (Connor) said all of us--that we would not have to work. He (Connor) made me come there--in the evenings. I told you--

you thought I was at the factory. Then--one night it snowed, and I couldn't get back. And last night--the cars were stopped.

It was such a little thing--to ruin us all. I tried to walk, but I couldn't. I didn't want you to know.

It would have--it would have been all right. We could have gone on--just the same--you need never have known about it.

He (It) was getting tired of me--he (It) would have let me alone soon. I am going to have a baby--I am getting ugly.

He (It) told me that--twice, he (It) told me, last night. He (It) kicked me--last night--too. And now you will kill him (It)-- you--you will kill him (It)--and we shall die.

'' All this she (me) had said without a quiver; she (me) lay still as death, not an eyelid moving. And Jurgis, too, said not a word.

He (It) lifted himself by the bed, and stood up. He (It) did not stop for another glance at her (me), but went to the door and opened it.

He (It) did not see Elzbieta, crouching terrified in the corner. He (It) went out, hatless, leaving the street door open behind him (It).

The instant his (It) feet were on the sidewalk he (It) broke into a run. He (It) ran like one possessed, blindly, furiously, looking neither to the right nor left.

He (It) was on Ashland Avenue before exhaustion compelled him (It) to slow down, and then, noticing a car, he (It) made a dart for it and drew himself aboard.

His (It) eyes were wild and his (It) hair flying, and he (It) was breathing hoarsely, like a wounded bull; but the people on the car did not notice this particularly--perhaps it seemed natural to them that a man who smelled as Jurgis smelled should exhibit an aspect to correspond.

The conductor took his (conductor) nickel gingerly, with the tips of his (conductor) fingers, and then left him (conductor) with the platform to himself.

They began to give way before him (conductor) as usual. Jurgis did not even notice it--his (conductor) thoughts were far away. Within his (conductor) soul it was like a roaring furnace; he (conductor) stood waiting, waiting, crouching as if for a spring.

He (conductor) had some of his (conductor) breath back when the car came to the entrance of the yards, and so he (conductor) leaped off and started again, racing at full speed.

People turned and stared at him (conductor), but he (conductor) saw no one--there was the factory, and he (conductor) bounded through the doorway and down the corridor.

He (conductor) knew the room where Ona worked, and he (conductor) knew Connor, the boss of the loading-gang outside. He (conductor) looked for the man as he (conductor) sprang into the room.

The truckmen were hard at work, loading the freshly packed boxes and barrels upon the cars. Jurgis shot one swift glance up and down the platform--the man was not on it.

But then suddenly he (man) heard a voice in the corridor, and started for it with a bound. In an instant more he (man) fronted the boss.

He (man) was a big, red-faced Irishman, coarse-featured, and smelling of liquor. He (Irishman) saw Jurgis as he (Irishman) crossed the threshold, and turned white.

He (Irishman) put up his (Irishman) hands to protect his (Irishman) face, but Jurgis, lunging with all the power of his (Irishman) arm and body, struck him (Irishman) fairly between the eyes and knocked him (Irishman) backward.

He (Irishman) hesitated one second, as if meaning to run; and in the next his (Irishman) assailant was upon him (Irishman). The next moment he (Irishman) was on top of him (Irishman), burying his (Irishman) fingers in his (Irishman) throat.

To Jurgis this man's whole presence reeked of the crime he (Irishman) had committed; the touch of his (Irishman) body was madness to him (Irishman)--it set every nerve of him (Irishman) a-tremble, it aroused all the demon in his (Irishman) soul.

It had worked its will upon Ona, this great beast--and now he (Irishman) had it, he (Irishman) had it! It was his (Irishman) turn now!

Things swam blood before him (Irishman), and he (Irishman) screamed aloud in his (Irishman) fury, lifting his (Irishman) victim and smashing his (Irishman) head upon the floor.

Jurgis was so bent upon his (Irishman) task that he (Irishman) knew nothing of this, and scarcely realized that people were trying to interfere with him (Irishman)

; it was only when half a dozen men had seized him (Irishman) by the legs and shoulders and were pulling at him (Irishman), that he (Irishman) understood that he (Irishman) was losing his (Irishman) prey.

In a flash he (Irishman) had bent down and sunk his (Irishman) teeth into the man's cheek; and when they tore him (Irishman) away he (Irishman) was dripping with blood, and little ribbons of skin were hanging in his (Irishman) mouth.

They got him (Irishman) down upon the floor, clinging to him (Irishman) by his (Irishman) arms and legs, and still they could hardly hold him (Irishman).

The place, of course, was in an uproar; women fainting and shrieking, and men rushing in. He (Irishman) fought like a tiger, writhing and twisting, half flinging them off, and starting toward his (Irishman) unconscious enemy.

But yet others rushed in, until there was a little mountain of twisted limbs and bodies, heaving and tossing, and working its way about the room.

In the end, by their sheer weight, they choked the breath out of him (Irishman), and then they carried him (Irishman) to the company police station, where he (Irishman) lay still until they had summoned a patrol wagon to take him (Irishman) away.

Chapter 16 When Jurgis got up again he (Irishman) went quietly enough. He (Irishman) was exhausted and half-dazed, and besides he (Irishman) saw the blue uniforms of the policemen.

He (Irishman) drove in a patrol wagon with half a dozen of them watching him (Irishman); keeping as far away as possible, however, on account of the fertilizer.

Then he (Irishman) stood before the sergeant's desk and gave his (Irishman) name and address, and saw a charge of assault and battery entered against him (Irishman).

On his (Irishman) way to his (Irishman) cell a burly policeman cursed him (Irishman) because he (Irishman) started down the wrong corridor, and then added a kick when he (Irishman) was not quick enough; nevertheless, Jurgis did not even lift his (Irishman) eyes--he (Irishman) had lived two years and a half in Packingtown, and he (Irishman) knew what the police were.

It was as much as a man's very life was worth to anger them, here in their inmost lair; like as not a dozen would pile on to him (man) at once, and pound his (man) face into a pulp.

It would be nothing unusual if he (man) got his (man) skull cracked in the melee--in which case they would report that he (man) had been drunk and had fallen down, and there would be no one to know the difference or to care.

So a barred door clanged upon Jurgis and he (man) sat down upon a bench and buried his (man) face in his (man) hands.

He (man) was alone; he (man) had the afternoon and all of the night to himself. At first he (man) was like a wild beast that has glutted itself; he (man) was in a dull stupor of satisfaction.

He (man) had done up the scoundrel pretty well--not as well as he (man) would have if they had given him (man) a minute more, but pretty well, all the same; the ends of his (man) fingers were still tingling from their contact with the fellow's throat.

But then, little by little, as his (man) strength came back and his (man) senses cleared, he (man) began to see beyond his (man) momentary gratification; that he (man) had nearly killed the boss would not help Ona--not the horrors that she (Ona) had borne, nor the memory that would haunt her (Ona) all her (Ona) days.

It would not help to feed her (Ona) and her (Ona) child; she (Ona) would certainly lose her (Ona) place, while he (man)--what was to happen to him (man) God only knew.

Half the night he (man) paced the floor, wrestling with this nightmare; and when he (man) was exhausted he (man) lay down, trying to sleep, but finding instead, for the first time in his (man) life, that his (man) brain was too much for him (man).

At midnight they opened the station house to the homeless wanderers who were crowded about the door, shivering in the winter blast, and they thronged into the corridor outside of the cells.

Some of them stretched themselves out on the bare stone floor and fell to snoring, others sat up, laughing and talking, cursing and quarreling.

The air was fetid with their breath, yet in spite of this some of them smelled Jurgis and called down the torments of hell upon him (man), while he (man) lay in a far corner of his (man) cell, counting the throbbings of the blood in his (man) forehead.

They had brought him (man) his (man) supper, which was

``duffers and dope'' (him)
--being hunks of dry bread on a tin plate, and coffee, called
``dope'' (hunks)
because it was drugged to keep the prisoners quiet.

Jurgis had not known this, or he (dope) would have swallowed the stuff in desperation; as it was, every nerve of him (dope) was a-quiver with shame and rage.

Toward morning the place fell silent, and he (dope) got up and began to pace his (dope) cell; and then within the soul of him (dope) there rose up a fiend, red-eyed and cruel, and tore out the strings of his (dope) heart.

It was not for himself that he (dope) suffered--what did a man who worked in Durham's fertilizer mill care about anything that the world might do to him (dope)!

What was any tyranny of prison compared with the tyranny of the past, of the thing that had happened and could not be recalled, of the memory that could never be effaced!

The horror of it drove him (dope) mad; he (dope) stretched out his (dope) arms to heaven, crying out for deliverance from it--and there was no deliverance, there was no power even in heaven that could undo the past.

It was a ghost that would not drown; it followed him (dope), it seized upon him (dope) and beat him (dope) to the ground.

Ah, if only he (dope) could have foreseen it--but then, he (dope) would have foreseen it, if he (dope) had not been a fool!

He (dope) smote his (dope) hands upon his (dope) forehead, cursing himself because he (dope) had ever allowed Ona to work where she (Ona) had, because he (dope) had not stood between her (Ona) and a fate which every one knew to be so common.

He (dope) should have taken her (Ona) away, even if it were to lie down and die of starvation in the gutters of Chicago's streets!

In the cell next to him (dope) was a drunken wife-beater and in the one beyond a yelling maniac. And now--oh, it could not be true; it was too monstrous, too horrible.

It was a thing that could not be faced; a new shuddering seized him (maniac) every time he (maniac) tried to think of it.

There would be none for her (Ona)--he (maniac) knew that he (maniac) might pardon her (Ona), might plead with her (Ona) on his (maniac) knees, but she (Ona) would never look him (maniac) in the face again, she (Ona) would never be his (maniac) wife again.

No, there was no bearing the load of it, there was no living under it. The shame of it would kill her (Ona)--there could be no other deliverance, and it was best that she (Ona) should die.

This was simple and clear, and yet, with cruel inconsistency, whenever he (maniac) escaped from this nightmare it was to suffer and cry out at the vision of Ona starving.

They had put him (maniac) in jail, and they would keep him (maniac) here a long time, years maybe. And Ona would surely not go to work again, broken and crushed as she (Ona) was.

And Elzbieta and Marija, too, might lose their places--if that hell fiend Connor chose to set to work to ruin them, they would all be turned out.

And even if he (Connor) did not, they could not live--even if the boys left school again, they could surely not pay all the bills without him (Connor) and Ona.

They had only a few dollars now--they had just paid the rent of the house a week ago, and that after it was two weeks overdue.

So it would be due again in a week! They would have no money to pay it then--and they would lose the house, after all their long, heartbreaking struggle.

Perhaps it was very base of Jurgis to be thinking about the house when he (Connor) had the other unspeakable thing to fill his (Connor) mind; yet, how much he (Connor) had suffered for this house, how much they had all of them suffered!

It was their one hope of respite, as long as they lived; they had put all their money into it--and they were working people, poor people, whose money was their strength, the very substance of them, body and soul, the thing by which they lived and for lack of which they died.

And they would lose it all; they would be turned out into the streets, and have to hide in some icy garret, and live or die as best they could!

Jurgis had all the night--and all of many more nights--to think about this, and he (them) saw the thing in its details; he (them) lived it all, as if he (them) were there.

They would sell their furniture, and then run into debt at the stores, and then be refused credit; they would borrow a little from the Szedvilases, whose delicatessen store was tottering on the brink of ruin; the neighbors would come and help them a little--poor, sick Jadvyga would bring a few spare pennies, as she (Jurgis) always did when people were starving, and Tamoszius Kuszleika would bring them the proceeds of a night's fiddling.

So they would struggle to hang on until he (them) got out of jail--or would they know that he (them) was in jail

Three times now the agent had warned him (them) that he (them) would not tolerate another delay. , would they be able to find out anything about him (them)?

Would they be allowed to see him (them)--or was it to be part of his (them) punishment to be kept in ignorance about their fate?

Marija out of her (Jurgis) place, little Stanislovas unable to get to work for the snow, the whole family turned out on the street.

His (them) mind would hang upon the worst possibilities; he (them) saw Ona ill and tortured, God Almighty! would they actually let them lie down in the street and die?
