Jurgis had never seen any dead bodies in the streets, but he (Almighty) had seen people evicted and disappear, no one knew where; and though the city had a relief bureau, though there was a charity organization society in the stockyards district, in all his (Almighty) life there he (Almighty) had never heard of either of them.

Would there be no help even then --would they wander about in the snow till they froze? They did not advertise their activities, having more calls than they could attend to without that.

Then he (Almighty) had another ride in the patrol wagon, along with the drunken wife-beater and the maniac, several

``plain drunks'' (the maniac)
and
``saloon fighters,'' (the maniac)
a burglar, and two men who had been arrested for stealing meat from the packing houses.

In front, upon a raised platform behind a rail, sat a stout, florid-faced personage, with a nose broken out in purple blotches.

--So on until morning. Along with them he (burglar) was driven into a large, white-walled room, stale-smelling and crowded. Our friend realized vaguely that he (friend) was about to be tried.

He (friend) wondered what for--whether or not his (friend) victim might be dead, and if so, what they would do with him (friend). Hang him (friend), perhaps, or beat him (friend) to death--nothing would have surprised Jurgis, who knew little of the laws.

Yet he (friend) had picked up gossip enough to have it occur to him (friend) that the loud-voiced man upon the bench might be the notorious Justice Callahan, about whom the people of Packingtown spoke with bated breath.

'' Pat, as he (Pat) had been known before he (Pat) ascended the bench--had begun life as a butcher boy and a bruiser of local reputation; he (bruiser) had gone into politics almost as soon as he (bruiser) had learned to talk, and had held two offices at once before he (bruiser) was old enough to vote.

If Scully was the thumb, Pat Callahan was the first finger of the unseen hand whereby the packers held down the people of the district.

No politician in Chicago ranked higher in their confidence; he (politician) had been at it a long time--had been the business agent in the city council of old Durham, the self-made merchant, way back in the early days, when the whole city of Chicago had been up at auction.

Growler'' Pat had given up holding city offices very early in his (Pat) career--caring only for party power, and giving the rest of his (Pat) time to superintending his (Pat) dives and brothels.

Of late years, however, since his (Pat) children were growing up, he (Pat) had begun to value respectability, and had had himself made a magistrate; a position for which he (Pat) was admirably fitted, because of his (Pat) strong conservatism and his (Pat) contempt for

``foreigners.

Jurgis sat gazing about the room for an hour or two; he (Pat) was in hopes that some one of the family would come, but in this he (Pat) was disappointed.

'' (he)

Pat'' Callahan--
``Growler '' (Pat Callahan lawyer)
'' Finally, he (Callahan) was led before the bar, and a lawyer for the company appeared against him (Callahan).

Connor was under the doctor's care, the lawyer explained briefly, and if his (lawyer) Honor would hold the prisoner for a week--

``Three hundred dollars,'' (the prisoner)
said his (lawyer) Honor, promptly.

Have you any one to go on your bond?'' demanded the judge, and then a clerk who stood at Jurgis' elbow explained to him (judge) what this meant.

Jurgis was staring from the judge to the lawyer in perplexity. '' The latter shook his (lawyer) head, and before he (lawyer) realized what had happened the policemen were leading him (lawyer) away again.

They took him (lawyer) to a room where other prisoners were waiting and here he (lawyer) stayed until court adjourned, when he (lawyer) had another long and bitterly cold ride in a patrol wagon to the county jail, which is on the north side of the city, and nine or ten miles from the stockyards.

Then they led him (lawyer) to a room and told him (lawyer) to strip for a bath; after which he (lawyer) had to walk down a long gallery, past the grated cell doors of the inmates of the jail.

This was a great event to the latter--the daily review of the new arrivals, all stark naked, and many and diverting were the comments.

Jurgis was required to stay in the bath longer than any one, in the vain hope of getting out of him (lawyer) a few of his (lawyer) phosphates and acids.

Here they searched Jurgis, leaving him (lawyer) only his (lawyer) money, which consisted of fifteen cents. The prisoners roomed two in a cell, but that day there was one left over, and he (lawyer) was the one.

His (lawyer) cell was about five feet by seven in size, with a stone floor and a heavy wooden bench built into it.

The cells were in tiers, opening upon galleries. There was no window--the only light came from windows near the roof at one end of the court outside.

There were two bunks, one above the other, each with a straw mattress and a pair of gray blankets--the latter stiff as boards with filth, and alive with fleas, bedbugs, and lice.

When Jurgis lifted up the mattress he (lawyer) discovered beneath it a layer of scurrying roaches, almost as badly frightened as himself.

Here they brought him (lawyer) more

``duffers and dope,'' (him)
with the addition of a bowl of soup. Many of the prisoners had their meals brought in from a restaurant, but Jurgis had no money for that.

Some had books to read and cards to play, with candles to burn by night, but Jurgis was all alone in darkness and silence.

He (lawyer) could not sleep again; there was the same maddening procession of thoughts that lashed him (lawyer) like whips upon his (lawyer) naked back.

When night fell he (lawyer) was pacing up and down his (lawyer) cell like a wild beast that breaks its teeth upon the bars of its cage.

Now and then in his (lawyer) frenzy he (lawyer) would fling himself against the walls of the place, beating his (lawyer) hands upon them.

They cut him (lawyer) and bruised him (lawyer)--they were cold and merciless as the men who had built them. In the distance there was a church-tower bell that tolled the hours one by one.

When it came to midnight Jurgis was lying upon the floor with his (lawyer) head in his (lawyer) arms, listening. Instead of falling silent at the end, the bell broke into a sudden clangor.

Jurgis raised his (lawyer) head; what could that mean--a fire? God! Suppose there were to be a fire in this jail! But then he (God) made out a melody in the ringing; there were chimes.

And they seemed to waken the city--all around, far and near, there were bells, ringing wild music; for fully a minute Jurgis lay lost in wonder, before, all at once, the meaning of it broke over him (God)--that this was Christmas Eve!

Christmas Eve--he (God) had forgotten it entirely! There was a breaking of floodgates, a whirl of new memories and new griefs rushing into his (God) mind.

In far Lithuania they had celebrated Christmas; and it came to him (God) as if it had been yesterday--himself a little child, with his (God) lost brother and his (God) dead father in the cabin--in the deep black forest, where the snow fell all day and all night and buried them from the world.

It was too far off for Santa Claus in Lithuania, but it was not too far for peace and good will to men, for the wonder-bearing vision of the Christ Child.

Last Christmas Eve and all Christmas Day Jurgis had toiled on the killing beds, and Ona at wrapping hams, and still they had found strength enough to take the children for a walk upon the avenue, to see the store windows all decorated with Christmas trees and ablaze with electric lights.

And even in Packingtown they had not forgotten it--some gleam of it had never failed to break their darkness. In one window there would be live geese, in another marvels in sugar--

pink and white canes big enough for ogres, and cakes with cherubs upon them; in a third there would be rows of fat yellow turkeys, decorated with rosettes, and rabbits and squirrels hanging; in a fourth would be a fairyland of toys--lovely dolls with pink dresses, and woolly sheep and drums and soldier hats.

The last time they had had a big basket with them and all their Christmas marketing to do--a roast of pork and a cabbage and some rye bread, and a pair of mittens for Ona, and a rubber doll that squeaked, and a little green cornucopia full of candy to be hung from the gas jet and gazed at by half a dozen pairs of longing eyes.

Even half a year of the sausage machines and the fertilizer mill had not been able to kill the thought of Christmas in them; there was a choking in Jurgis' throat as he (dozen) recalled that the very night Ona had not come home

Teta Elzbieta had taken him (dozen) aside and shown him (dozen) an old valentine that she (Elzbieta) had picked up in a paper store for three cents--dingy and shopworn, but with bright colors, and figures of angels and doves.

She (Elzbieta) had wiped all the specks off this, and was going to set it on the mantel, where the children could see it.

Nor did they have to go without their share of all this, either. Great sobs shook Jurgis at this memory--they would spend their Christmas in misery and despair, with him (dozen) in prison and

Why at least had they not left him (dozen) alone--why, after they had shut him (dozen) in jail, must they be ringing Christmas chimes in his (dozen) ears!

But no, their bells were not ringing for him (dozen)--their Christmas was not meant for him (dozen), they were simply not counting him (dozen) at all.

Ona ill and their home in desolation. Ah, it was too cruel! He (dozen) was of no consequence--he (dozen) was flung aside, like a bit of trash, the carcass of some animal.

His (dozen) wife might be dying, his (dozen) baby might be starving, his (dozen) whole family might be perishing in the cold--and all the while they were ringing their Christmas chimes!

They put him (dozen) in a place where the snow could not beat in, where the cold could not eat through his (dozen) bones; they brought him (dozen) food and drink--why, in the name of heaven, if they must punish him (dozen), did they not put his (dozen) family in jail and leave him (dozen) outside--why could they find no better way to punish him (dozen) than to leave three weak women and six helpless children to starve and freeze?

It was horrible, horrible! And the bitter mockery of it--all this was punishment for him (dozen)! That was their law, that was their justice!

Jurgis stood upright; trembling with passion, his (dozen) hands clenched and his (dozen) arms upraised, his (dozen) whole soul ablaze with hatred and defiance.

, it was a lie, a hideous, brutal lie, a thing too black and hateful for any world but a world of nightmares.

Ten thousand curses upon them and their law! Their justice--it was a lie It was a sham and a loathsome mockery.

There was no justice, there was no right, anywhere in it--it was only force, it was tyranny, the will and the power, reckless and unrestrained!

They had ground him (dozen) beneath their heel, they had devoured all his (dozen) substance; they had murdered his (dozen) old father, they had broken and wrecked his (dozen) wife, they had crushed and cowed his (dozen) whole family; and now they were through with him (dozen), they had no further use for him (dozen)--and because he (dozen) had interfered with them, had gotten in their way

They had put him (dozen) behind bars, as if he (dozen) had been a wild beast, a thing without sense or reason, without rights, without affections, without feelings.

, this was what they had done to him (dozen)! Nay, they would not even have treated a beast as they had treated him (dozen)!

Would any man in his (man) senses have trapped a wild thing in its lair, and left its young behind to die?

These midnight hours were fateful ones to Jurgis; in them was the beginning of his (man) rebellion, of his (man) outlawry and his (man) unbelief.

He (man) had no wit to trace back the social crime to its far sources--he (man) could not say that it was the thing men have called

``the system'' (the thing men)
that was crushing him (man) to the earth; that it was the packers, his (man) masters, who had bought up the law of the land, and had dealt out their brutal will to him (man) from the seat of justice.

He (man) only knew that he (man) was wronged, and that the world had wronged him (man); that the law, that society, with all its powers, had declared itself his (man) foe.

And every hour his (man) soul grew blacker, every hour he (man) dreamed new dreams of vengeance, of defiance, of raging, frenzied hate.

The vilest deeds, like poison weeds, Bloom well in prison air; It is only what is good in Man That wastes and withers there; Pale Anguish keeps the heavy gate, And the Warder is Despair.

So wrote a poet, to whom the world had dealt its justice-- I know not whether Laws be right, Or whether Laws be wrong

; All that we know who lie in gaol Is that the wall is strong. And they do well to hide their hell,

At seven o'clock the next morning Jurgis was let out to get water to wash his (Warder) cell--a duty which he (Warder) performed faithfully, but which most of the prisoners were accustomed to shirk, until their cells became so filthy that the guards interposed.

Then he (Warder) had more

``duffers and dope,'' (he)
and afterward was allowed three hours for exercise, in a long, cement-walked court roofed with glass.

For in it things are done That Son of God nor son of Man Ever should look upon! Chapter 17 Here were all the inmates of the jail crowded together.

At one side of the court was a place for visitors, cut off by two heavy wire screens, a foot apart, so that nothing could be passed in to the prisoners; here Jurgis watched anxiously, but there came no one to see him (God).

Soon after he (God) went back to his (God) cell, a keeper opened the door to let in another prisoner. He (God) was a dapper young fellow, with a light brown mustache and blue eyes, and a graceful figure.

He (God) nodded to Jurgis, and then, as the keeper closed the door upon him (keeper), began gazing critically about him (keeper). '' Well, pal,'' he (pal) said, as his (pal) glance encountered Jurgis again,

``good morning.

The newcomer went to the bunks and inspected the blankets; he (newcomer) lifted up the mattress, and then dropped it with an exclamation.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

``Good morning,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis. '' A rum go for Christmas, eh? '' added the other. Jurgis nodded. '' My God!''

he (God) said,

``that's the worst yet. '' (he)
He (God) glanced at Jurgis again. '' Looks as if it hadn't been slept in last night.

Couldn't stand it, eh?''

``I didn't want to sleep last night,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis. '' When did you come in?''
``Yesterday. '' (unknown)

The other had another look around, and then wrinkled up his (God) nose. '' There's the devil of a stink in here,'' he (devil) said, suddenly.

'' What is it?'' '' It's me,'' said Jurgis.

``You?'' (me)
'' Yes, me.''
``Didn't they make you wash?'' (unknown)
'' Yes, but this don't wash.

'' '' What is it?''

``Fertilizer.'' (unknown)
``Fertilizer! The deuce! What are you?'' (unknown)
``I work in the stockyards--at least I did until the other day.

It's in my clothes.'' (me)

'' That's a new one on me,'' said the newcomer. '' I thought I'd been up against 'em all.

What are you in for?''

``I hit my boss. '' (unknown)
'' Oh--that's it. What did he (boss) do?'' '' He (boss)--he (boss) treated me mean.

''

``I see. You're what's called an honest workingman!'' (unknown)
'' What are you?'' Jurgis asked.
``I?'' (unknown)
The other laughed. '' They say I'm a cracksman,'' he (boss) said.

'' What's that?'' asked Jurgis. '' Safes, and such things,'' answered the other. '' Oh,'' said Jurgis, wonderingly, and stared at the speaker in awe.

'' You mean you break into them--you-- you--''

``Yes,'' (He)
laughed the other,
``that's what they say. '' (He)
He (speaker) did not look to be over twenty-two or three, though, as Jurgis found afterward, he (speaker) was thirty.

He (speaker) spoke like a man of education, like what the world calls a

``gentleman.'' (a man)
``Is that what you're here for?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis inquired.

'' No,'' was the answer. '' I'm here for disorderly conduct. They were mad because they couldn't get any evidence. ''

What's your name?'' the young fellow continued after a pause. '' My name's Duane--Jack Duane. I've more than a dozen, but that's my company one.

He (Duane) seated himself on the floor with his (Duane) back to the wall and his (Duane) legs crossed, and went on talking easily; he (Duane) soon put Jurgis on a friendly footing--he (Duane) was evidently a man of the world, used to getting on, and not too proud to hold conversation with a mere laboring man.

He (man) drew Jurgis out, and heard all about his (man) life all but the one unmentionable thing; and then he (man) told stories about his (man) own life.

Being sent to jail had apparently not disturbed his (man) cheerfulness; he (man) had

``done time'' (he)
twice before, it seemed, and he (man) took it all with a frolic welcome.

'' He (man) was a great one for stories, not always of the choicest. What with women and wine and the excitement of his (man) vocation, a man could afford to rest now and then.

He (man) could not turn his (man) face to the wall and sulk, he (man) had to speak when he (man) was spoken to; nor could he (man) help being interested in the conversation of Duane--the first educated man with whom he (man) had ever talked.

How could he (man) help listening with wonder while the other told of midnight ventures and perilous escapes, of feastings and orgies, of fortunes squandered in a night?

The young fellow had an amused contempt for Jurgis, as a sort of working mule; he (fellow), too, had felt the world's injustice, but instead of bearing it patiently, he (fellow) had struck back, and struck hard.

Naturally, the aspect of prison life was changed for Jurgis by the arrival of a cell mate. He (mate) was striking all the time--there was war between him (mate) and society.

He (mate) was a genial freebooter, living off the enemy, without fear or shame. He (mate) was not always victorious, but then defeat did not mean annihilation, and need not break his (mate) spirit.

His (mate) story came out, not in the first day, nor the second, but in the long hours that dragged by, in which they had nothing to do but talk and nothing to talk of

Withal he (mate) was a goodhearted fellow--too much so, it appeared. but themselves. Jack Duane was from the East; he (Duane) was a college-bred man--had been studying electrical engineering.

Then his (Duane) father had met with misfortune in business and killed himself; and there had been his (Duane) mother and a younger brother and sister.

Also, there was an invention of Duane's; Jurgis could not understand it clearly, but it had to do with telegraphing, and it was a very important thing--there were fortunes in it, millions upon millions of dollars.

And Duane had been robbed of it by a great company, and got tangled up in lawsuits and lost all his (Duane) money.

Then somebody had given him (Duane) a tip on a horse race, and he (Duane) had tried to retrieve his (Duane) fortune with another person's money, and had to run away, and all the rest had come from that.

The other asked him (Duane) what had led him (Duane) to safe-breaking--to Jurgis a wild and appalling occupation to think about. A man he (man) had met, his (man) cell mate had replied--one thing leads to another.

Didn't he (man) ever wonder about his (man) family, Jurgis asked. Sometimes, the other answered, but not often--he (man) didn't allow it. Thinking about it would make it no better.

This wasn't a world in which a man had any business with a family; sooner or later Jurgis would find that out also, and give up the fight and shift for himself.

Jurgis was so transparently what he (man) pretended to be that his (man) cell mate was as open with him (man) as a child; it was pleasant to tell him (man) adventures, he (man) was so full of wonder and admiration, he (man) was so new to the ways of the country.

Duane did not even bother to keep back names and places--he (Duane) told all his (Duane) triumphs and his (Duane) failures, his (Duane) loves and his (Duane) griefs.

Also he (Duane) introduced Jurgis to many of the other prisoners, nearly half of whom he (Duane) knew by name. The crowd had already given Jurgis a name--they called him (Duane) ``the stinker.

Our friend had caught now and then a whiff from the sewers over which he (friend) lived, but this was the first time that he (friend) had ever been splashed by their filth.

This jail was a Noah's ark of the city's crime--there were murderers,

``hold-up men'' (murderers)
and burglars, embezzlers, counterfeiters and forgers, bigamists,
``shoplifters,'' (forgers)
``confidence men,'' (forgers)
petty thieves and pickpockets, gamblers and procurers, brawlers, beggars, tramps and drunkards; they were black and white, old and young, Americans and natives of every nation under the sun.

There were hardened criminals and innocent men too poor to give bail; old men, and boys literally not yet in their teens.

They were the drainage of the great festering ulcer of society; they were hideous to look upon, sickening to talk to.

All life had turned to rottenness and stench in them--love was a beastliness, joy was a snare, and God was an imprecation.

'' This was cruel, but they meant no harm by it, and he (God) took it with a good-natured grin. They strolled here and there about the courtyard, and Jurgis listened to them.

They could tell the whole hateful story of it, set forth the inner soul of a city in which justice and honor, women's bodies and men's souls, were for sale in the marketplace, and human beings writhed and fought and fell upon each other like wolves in a pit; in which lusts were raging fires, and men were fuel, and humanity was festering and stewing and wallowing in its own corruption.

Into this wild-beast tangle these men had been born without their consent, they had taken part in it because they could not help it; that they were in jail was no disgrace to them, for the game had never been fair, the dice were loaded.

They were swindlers and thieves of pennies and dimes, and they had been trapped and put out of the way by the swindlers and thieves of millions of dollars.

He (them) was ignorant and they were wise ; they had been everywhere and tried everything. To most of this Jurgis tried not to listen.

They frightened him (them) with their savage mockery; and all the while his (them) heart was far away, where his (them) loved ones were calling.

Now and then in the midst of it his (them) thoughts would take flight; and then the tears would come into his (them) eyes--and he (them) would be called back by the jeering laughter of his (them) companions.

He (them) paid one of his (them) fifteen cents for a postal card, and his (them) companion wrote a note to the family, telling them where he (them) was and when he (them) would be tried.

There came no answer to it, however, and at last, the day before New Year's, Jurgis bade good-by to Jack Duane.

The latter gave him (Duane) his (Duane) address, or rather the address of his (Duane) mistress, and made Jurgis promise to look him (Duane) up.

Maybe I could help you out of a hole some day,'' he (Duane) said, and added that he (Duane) was sorry to have him (Duane) go.

He (Duane) spent a week in this company, and during all that time he (Duane) had no word from his (Duane) home. '' Jurgis rode in the patrol wagon back to Justice Callahan's court for trial.

One of the first things he (Callahan) made out as he (Callahan) entered the room was Teta Elzbieta and little Kotrina, looking pale and frightened, seated far in the rear.

His (Callahan) heart began to pound, but he (Callahan) did not dare to try to signal to them, and neither did Elzbieta. He (Callahan) took his (Callahan) seat in the prisoners' pen and sat gazing at them in helpless agony.

He (Callahan) saw that Ona was not with them, and was full of foreboding as to what that might mean. He (Callahan) spent half an hour brooding over this--and then suddenly he (Callahan) straightened up and the blood rushed into his (Callahan) face.

A man had come in--Jurgis could not see his (Callahan) features for the bandages that swathed him (Callahan), but he (Callahan) knew the burly figure.

Then suddenly he (Callahan) felt a hand on his (Callahan) collar, and heard a voice behind him (Callahan):

``Sit down, you son of a--!'' (him)

It was Connor! A trembling seized him (Connor), and his (Connor) limbs bent as if for a spring. He (Connor) subsided, but he (Connor) never took his (Connor) eyes off his (Connor) enemy.

The fellow was still alive, which was a disappointment, in one way; and yet it was pleasant to see him (Connor), all in penitential plasters.

He (Connor) and the company lawyer, who was with him (Connor), came and took seats within the judge's railing; and a minute later the clerk called Jurgis' name, and the policeman jerked him (policeman) to his (policeman) feet and led him (policeman) before the bar, gripping him (policeman) tightly by the arm, lest he (policeman) should spring upon the boss.

The wife of the prisoner had been employed in a department near him (policeman), and had been discharged for impudence to him (policeman).

Jurgis listened while the man entered the witness chair, took the oath, and told his (man) story. Half an hour later he (man) had been violently attacked, knocked down, and almost choked to death.

He (man) had brought witnesses-- '' They will probably not be necessary,'' observed the judge and he (judge) turned to Jurgis. '' You admit attacking the plaintiff?'' he (judge) asked.

``Him (judge)? '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
inquired Jurgis, pointing at the boss. '' Yes,'' said the judge. '' I hit him (judge), sir,'' said Jurgis.
``Say `your Honor,''' (the officer)
said the officer, pinching his (officer) arm hard.

'' Your Honor,'' said Jurgis, obediently. '' You tried to choke him (officer)?'' '' Yes, sir, your Honor. ''

``Ever been arrested before?'' (unknown)

'' No, sir, your Honor. '' '' What have you to say for yourself?'' Jurgis hesitated. What had he (officer) to say?

In two years and a half he (officer) had learned to speak English for practical purposes, but these had never included the statement that some one had intimidated and seduced his (officer) wife.

He (officer) tried once or twice, stammering and balking, to the annoyance of the judge, who was gasping from the odor of fertilizer.

Finally, the prisoner made it understood that his (prisoner) vocabulary was inadequate, and there stepped up a dapper young man with waxed mustaches, bidding him (prisoner) speak in any language he (prisoner) knew.

Jurgis began; supposing that he (prisoner) would be given time, he (prisoner) explained how the boss had taken advantage of his (boss) wife's position to make advances to her (wife) and had threatened her (wife) with the loss of her (wife) place.

When the interpreter had translated this, the judge, whose calendar was crowded, and whose automobile was ordered for a certain hour, interrupted with the remark:

``Oh, I see. Well, if he (judge) made love to your wife, why didn't she (wife) complain to the superintendent or leave the place?'' (the judge)

Jurgis hesitated, somewhat taken aback; he (superintendent) began to explain that they were very poor--that work was hard to get--

``I see,'' (he)
said Justice Callahan;

``so instead you thought you would knock him (Callahan) down. '' (Callahan)
He (Callahan) turned to the plaintiff, inquiring,
``Is there any truth in this story, Mr. Connor?

'' (the plaintiff)

``Not a particle, your Honor,'' (the boss)
said the boss. '' It is very unpleasant--they tell some such tale every time you have to discharge a woman--

''

``Yes, I know,'' (a woman)
said the judge. '' I hear it often enough. The fellow seems to have handled you pretty roughly.

It was only when the policeman who had him (policeman) by the arm turned and started to lead him (policeman) away that he (policeman) realized that sentence had been passed.

Thirty days and costs. Next case. '' Jurgis had been listening in perplexity. He (policeman) gazed round him (policeman) wildly. '' Thirty days!

'' he (policeman) panted and then he (policeman) whirled upon the judge. '' What will my family do? '' he (policeman) cried frantically. ''

``You would have done well to think about them before you committed the assault,'' (the judge)
said the judge dryly, as he (judge) turned to look at the next prisoner.

Jurgis would have spoken again, but the policeman had seized him (policeman) by the collar and was twisting it, and a second policeman was making for him (policeman) with evidently hostile intentions.

I have a wife and baby, sir, and they have no money--my God, they will starve to death!'' So he (God) let them lead him (God) away.

Far down the room he (God) saw Elzbieta and Kotrina, risen from their seats, staring in fright; he (God) made one effort to go to them, and then, brought back by another twist at his (God) throat, he (God) bowed his (God) head and gave up the struggle.

They thrust him (God) into a cell room, where other prisoners were waiting; and as soon as court had adjourned they led him (God) down with them into the

``Black Maria,'' (him)
and drove him (God) away.

It was even filthier and more crowded than the county jail; all the smaller fry out of the latter had been sifted into it--the petty thieves and swindlers, the brawlers and vagrants.

For his (God) cell mate Jurgis had an Italian fruit seller who had refused to pay his (God) graft to the policeman, and been arrested for carrying a large pocketknife; as he (God) did not understand a word of English our friend was glad when he (friend) left.

He (friend) gave place to a Norwegian sailor, who had lost half an ear in a drunken brawl, and who proved to be quarrelsome, cursing Jurgis because he (friend) moved in his (friend) bunk and caused the roaches to drop upon the lower one.

It would have been quite intolerable, staying in a cell with this wild beast, but for the fact that all day long the prisoners were put at work breaking stone.

Ten days of his (friend) thirty Jurgis spent thus, without hearing a word from his (friend) family; then one day a keeper came and informed him (friend) that there was a visitor to see him (visitor).

This time Jurgis was bound for the

``Bridewell,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
a petty jail where Cook County prisoners serve their time. Jurgis turned white, and so weak at the knees that he (Cook) could hardly leave his (Cook) cell.

The man led him (Cook) down the corridor and a flight of steps to the visitors' room, which was barred like a cell.

Through the grating Jurgis could see some one sitting in a chair; and as he (Cook) came into the room the person started up, and he (Cook) saw that it was little Stanislovas.

At the sight of some one from home the big fellow nearly went to pieces--he (fellow) had to steady himself by a chair, and he (fellow) put his (fellow) other hand to his (fellow) forehead, as if to clear away a mist.

'' Well?'' he (fellow) said, weakly. Little Stanislovas was also trembling, and all but too frightened to speak. '' They--they sent me to tell you--'' he (fellow) said, with a gulp.

'' Well?'' Jurgis repeated. He (fellow) followed the boy's glance to where the keeper was standing watching them. '' Never mind that,'' Jurgis cried, wildly.

'' How are they?'' '' Ona is very sick,'' Stanislovas said;

``and we are almost starving. We can't get along; we thought you might be able to help us.

'' (Stanislovas)

Jurgis gripped the chair tighter; there were beads of perspiration on his (keeper) forehead, and his (keeper) hand shook. '' I--can't help you,'' he (keeper) said.

'' Ona lies in her (Ona) room all day,'' the boy went on, breathlessly. '' She (Ona) won't eat anything, and she (Ona) cries all the time.

She (Ona) won't tell what is the matter and she (Ona) won't go to work at all. Then a long time ago the man came for the rent.

He (man) was very cross. He (man) came again last week. He (man) said he (man) would turn us out of the house. And then Marija--'' A sob choked Stanislovas, and he (man) stopped.

'' What's the matter with Marija?'' cried Jurgis. '' She (Ona)'s cut her (Ona) hand!'' said the boy. '' She (Ona)'s cut it bad, this time, worse than before.

She (Ona) can't work and it's all turning green, and the company doctor says she (Ona) may--she (Ona) may have to have it cut off.

her (Ona) money is nearly all gone, too, and we can't pay the rent and the interest on the house; and we have no coal and nothing more to eat, and the man at the store, he (man) says--''

And Marija cries all the time-- The little fellow stopped again, beginning to whimper.

``Go on! '' (unknown)
the other panted in frenzy--
``Go on!'' (unknown)

``I--I will,'' (unknown)
sobbed Stanislovas. '' It's so--so cold all the time. And last Sunday it snowed again--a deep, deep snow--and I couldn't--

There was an old hatred between them because of the snow--ever since that dreadful morning when the boy had had his (boy) fingers frozen and Jurgis had had to beat him (boy) to send him (boy) to work.

couldn't get to work. ''

``God!'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis half shouted, and he (God) took a step toward the child. Now he (God) clenched his (God) hands, looking as if he (God) would try to break through the grating.

'' You little villain,'' he (villain) cried,

``you didn't try!'' (he)
``I did--I did! '' (him)
wailed Stanislovas, shrinking from him (villain) in terror. ''

I tried all day--two days. Elzbieta was with me, and she (Elzbieta) couldn't either. We couldn't walk at all, it was so deep.

And we had nothing to eat, and oh, it was so cold! I tried, and then the third day Ona went with me--

''

``Ona!'' (me)
'' Yes. She (Ona) tried to get to work, too. She (Ona) had to. We were all starving. But she (Ona) had lost her (Ona) place--'' Jurgis reeled, and gave a gasp.

'' She (Ona) went back to that place? '' he (me) screamed. '' She (Ona) tried to,'' said Stanislovas, gazing at him (me) in perplexity.

'' Why not, Jurgis? '' The man breathed hard, three or four times. '' Go--on,'' he (man) panted, finally. '' I went with her (Ona),'' said Stanislovas,

``but Miss Henderson wouldn't take her (Henderson) back.

And Connor saw her (Henderson) and cursed her (Henderson). He (Connor) was still bandaged up--why did you hit him (Connor), Jurgis? '' (Stanislovas)

-LRB-There was some fascinating mystery about this, the little fellow knew; but he (Connor) could get no satisfaction.-RRB-

Jurgis could not speak; he (Connor) could only stare, his (Connor) eyes starting out. '' She (Henderson) has been trying to get other work,'' the boy went on;

``but she (Henderson)'s so weak she (Henderson) can't keep up.

And my boss would not take me back, either-- Ona says he (boss) knows Connor, and that's the reason; they've all got a grudge against us now.

So I've got to go downtown and sell papers with the rest of the boys and Kotrina-- '' (the boy)

``Kotrina!'' (unknown)
``Yes, she (Ona)'s been selling papers, too.

Sometimes they can't come home at all--I'm going to try to find them tonight and sleep where they do, it's so late

She (Ona) does best, because she (Ona)'s a girl. Only the cold is so bad--it's terrible coming home at night, Jurgis. and it's such a long ways home.

Only mother said I must come, because you would want to know, and maybe somebody would help your family when they had put you in jail so you couldn't work.

I've had to walk, and I didn't know where it was--I don't know how to get back, either. And I walked all day to get here--and I only had a piece of bread for breakfast, Jurgis.

Mother hasn't any work either, because the sausage department is shut down; and she (Mother) goes and begs at houses with a basket, and people give her (Mother) food.

'' (he)

So little Stanislovas went on, sobbing as he (I) talked; and Jurgis stood, gripping the table tightly, saying not a word, but feeling that his (I) head would burst; it was like having weights piled upon him (I), one after another, crushing the life out of him (I).

He (I) struggled and fought within himself--as if in some terrible nightmare, in which a man suffers an agony, and cannot lift his (man) hand, nor cry out, but feels that he (man) is going mad, that his (man) brain is on fire-- Just when it seemed to him (man) that another turn of the screw would kill him (man), little Stanislovas stopped.

Only she (I) didn't get much yesterday; it was too cold for her (I) fingers, and today she (I) was crying-- '' You cannot help us?

'' he (man) said weakly. Jurgis shook his (man) head. '' They won't give you anything here? '' He (man) shook it again. ''

When are you coming out?'' '' Three weeks yet,'' Jurgis answered. And the boy gazed around him (boy) uncertainly. '' Then I might as well go,'' he (boy) said.

Jurgis nodded. Then, suddenly recollecting, he (boy) put his (boy) hand into his (boy) pocket and drew it out, shaking. '' Here,'' he (boy) said, holding out the fourteen cents.

``Take this to them. '' (Stanislovas)
And Stanislovas took it, and after a little more hesitation, started for the door. '' Good-by, Jurgis,'' he (boy) said, and the other noticed that he (boy) walked unsteadily as he (boy) passed out of sight.

For a minute or so Jurgis stood clinging to his (boy) chair, reeling and swaying; then the keeper touched him (keeper) on the arm, and he (keeper) turned and went back to breaking stone.

To his (keeper) sentence there were added

``court costs'' (he)
of a dollar and a half--he (keeper) was supposed to pay for the trouble of putting him (keeper) in jail, and not having the money, was obliged to work it off by three days more of toil.

Nobody had taken the trouble to tell him (keeper) this--only after counting the days and looking forward to the end in an agony of impatience, when the hour came that he (keeper) expected to be free he (keeper) found himself still set at the stone heap, and laughed at when he (keeper) ventured to protest.

Then he (keeper) concluded he (keeper) must have counted wrong; but as another day passed, he (keeper) gave up all hope--and was sunk in the depths of despair, when one morning after breakfast a keeper came to him (keeper) with the word that his (keeper) time was up at last.

So he (keeper) doffed his (keeper) prison garb, and put on his (keeper) old fertilizer clothing, and heard the door of the prison clang behind him (keeper).

He (keeper) stood upon the steps, bewildered; he (keeper) could hardly believe that it was true,--that the sky was above him (keeper) again and the open street before him (keeper); that he (keeper) was a free man.

Chapter 18 Jurgis did not get out of the Bridewell quite as soon as he (keeper) had expected. But then the cold began to strike through his (keeper) clothes, and he (keeper) started quickly away.

There had been a heavy snow, and now a thaw had set in; fine sleety rain was falling, driven by a wind that pierced Jurgis to the bone.

He (keeper) had not stopped for his-overcoat when he (keeper) set out to

``do up'' (he)
Connor, and so his (Connor) rides in the patrol wagons had been cruel experiences; his (Connor) clothing was old and worn thin, and it never had been very warm.

Now as he (Connor) trudged on the rain soon wet it through; there were six inches of watery slush on the sidewalks, so that his (Connor) feet would soon have been soaked, even had there been no holes in his (Connor) shoes.

Jurgis had had enough to eat in the jail, and the work had been the least trying of any that he (Connor) had done since he (Connor) came to Chicago; but even so, he (Connor) had not grown strong--

the fear and grief that had preyed upon his (Connor) mind had worn him (Connor) thin. Now he (Connor) shivered and shrunk from the rain, hiding his (Connor) hands in his (Connor) pockets and hunching his (Connor) shoulders together.

The Bridewell grounds were on the outskirts of the city and the country around them was unsettled and wild--on one side was the big drainage canal, and on the other a maze of railroad tracks, and so the wind had full sweep.

After walking a ways, Jurgis met a little ragamuffin whom he (Connor) hailed:

``Hey, sonny! '' (he)
The boy cocked one eye at him (boy)--he (boy) knew that Jurgis was a
``jailbird'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
by his (boy) shaven head.

'' Wot yer want? '' he (boy) queried. '' How do you go to the stockyards?'' Jurgis demanded. '' I don't go,'' replied the boy.

Jurgis hesitated a moment, nonplussed. Then he (boy) said,

``I mean which is the way?'' (he)
``Why don't yer say so then? '' (the boy)
was the response, and the boy pointed to the northwest, across the tracks.

'' That way. ''

``How far is it?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis asked. '' I dunno,'' said the other. '' Mebbe twenty miles or so.''

He (boy) had to walk every foot of it, for they had turned him (boy) out of jail without a penny in his (boy) pockets.

Yet, when he (boy) once got started, and his (boy) blood had warmed with walking, he (boy) forgot everything in the fever of his (boy) thoughts.

'' Twenty miles!'' Jurgis echoed, and his (boy) face fell. All the dreadful imaginations that had haunted him (boy) in his (boy) cell now rushed into his (boy) mind at once.

The agony was almost over--he (boy) was going to find out; and he (boy) clenched his (boy) hands in his (boy) pockets as he (boy) strode, following his (boy) flying desire, almost at a run.

Ona--the baby--the family--the house--he (boy) would know the truth about them all! And he (boy) was coming to the rescue--he (boy) was free again!

His (boy) hands were his (boy) own, and he (boy) could help them, he (boy) could do battle for them against the world. For an hour or so he (boy) walked thus, and then he (boy) began to look about him (boy).

The street was turning into a country road, leading out to the westward; there were snow-covered fields on either side of him (boy).

He (boy) seemed to be leaving the city altogether. Soon he (boy) met a farmer driving a two-horse wagon loaded with straw, and he (boy) stopped him (boy).

'' Is this the way to the stockyards?'' he (boy) asked. The farmer scratched his (boy) head. '' I dunno jest where they be,'' he (boy) said.

'' But they're in the city somewhere, and you're going dead away from it now. '' Jurgis looked dazed. '' I was told this was the way,'' he (boy) said.

'' Who told you?''

``A boy. '' (he)
'' Well, mebbe he (boy) was playing a joke on ye. The best thing ye kin do is to go back, and when ye git into town ask a policeman.

I'd take ye in, only I've come a long ways an' I'm loaded heavy. Git up!'' So Jurgis turned and followed, and toward the end of the morning he (policeman) began to see Chicago again.

Every few blocks there would be a railroad crossing on the level with the sidewalk, a deathtrap for the unwary; long freight trains would be passing, the cars clanking and crashing together, and Jurgis would pace about waiting, burning up with a fever of impatience.

Occasionally the cars would stop for some minutes, and wagons and streetcars would crowd together waiting, the drivers swearing at each other, or hiding beneath umbrellas out of the rain; at such times Jurgis would dodge under the gates and run across the tracks and between the cars, taking his (drivers) life into his (drivers) hands.

Past endless blocks of two-story shanties he (drivers) walked, along wooden sidewalks and unpaved pathways treacherous with deep slush holes. He (drivers) crossed a long bridge over a river frozen solid and covered with slush.

Not even on the river bank was the snow white-- the rain which fell was a diluted solution of smoke, and Jurgis' hands and face were streaked with black.

Then he (drivers) came into the business part of the city, where the streets were sewers of inky blackness, with horses sleeping and plunging, and women and children flying across in panic-stricken droves.

These streets were huge canyons formed by towering black buildings, echoing with the clang of car gongs and the shouts of drivers; the people who swarmed in them were as busy as ants--all hurrying breathlessly, never stopping to look at anything nor at each other.

The solitary trampish-looking foreigner, with water-soaked clothing and haggard face and anxious eyes, was as much alone as he (foreigner) hurried past them, as much unheeded and as lost, as if he (foreigner) had been a thousand miles deep in a wilderness.

He (foreigner) came again to the slum districts, to avenues of saloons and cheap stores, with long dingy red factory buildings, and coal-yards and railroad tracks; and then Jurgis lifted up his (foreigner) head and began to sniff the air like a startled animal--scenting the far-off odor of home.

It was late afternoon then, and he (foreigner) was hungry, but the dinner invitations hung out of the saloons were not for him (foreigner).

So he (foreigner) came at last to the stockyards, to the black volcanoes of smoke and the lowing cattle and the stench.

Then, seeing a crowded car, his (foreigner) impatience got the better of him (foreigner) and he (foreigner) jumped aboard, hiding behind another man, unnoticed by the conductor.

A policeman gave him (policeman) his (policeman) direction and told him (policeman) that he (policeman) had five miles to go. In ten minutes more he (policeman) had reached his (policeman) street, and home.

He (policeman) was half running as he (policeman) came round the corner. There was the house, at any rate--and then suddenly he (policeman) stopped and stared.

Jurgis looked twice, bewildered; then he (policeman) glanced at the house next door and at the one beyond--then at the saloon on the corner.

What was the matter with the house? Yes, it was the right place, quite certainly--he (policeman) had not made any mistake. But the house--the house was a different color!

He (policeman) came a couple of steps nearer. Yes; it had been gray and now it was yellow! The trimmings around the windows had been red, and now they were green!

It was all newly painted! How strange it made it seem! Jurgis went closer yet, but keeping on the other side of the street.

A sudden and horrible spasm of fear had come over him (policeman). His (policeman) knees were shaking beneath him (policeman), and his (policeman) mind was in a whirl.

New paint on the house, and new weatherboards, where the old had begun to rot off, and the agent had got after them!

New shingles over the hole in the roof, too, the hole that had for six months been the bane of his (agent) soul--he (agent) having no money to have it fixed and no time to fix it himself, and the rain leaking in, and overflowing the pots and pans he (agent) put to catch it, and flooding the attic and loosening the plaster.

And now it was fixed! And the broken windowpane replaced! And curtains in the windows! New, white curtains, stiff and shiny!

A boy had come out, a stranger to him (stranger); a big, fat, rosy-cheeked youngster, such as had never been seen in his (youngster) home before.

Then suddenly the front door opened. Jurgis stood, his (youngster) chest heaving as he (youngster) struggled to catch his (youngster) breath. Jurgis stared at the boy, fascinated.

He (youngster) came down the steps whistling, kicking off the snow. He (youngster) stopped at the foot, and picked up some, and then leaned against the railing, making a snowball.

A moment later he (youngster) looked around and saw Jurgis, and their eyes met; it was a hostile glance, the boy evidently thinking that the other had suspicions of the snowball.

When Jurgis started slowly across the street toward him (boy), he (boy) gave a quick glance about, meditating retreat, but then he (boy) concluded to stand his (boy) ground.

Jurgis took hold of the railing of the steps, for he (boy) was a little unsteady. '' What--what are you doing here?

'' he (boy) managed to gasp.

``Go on!'' (the boy)
said the boy. '' You--'' Jurgis tried again. '' What do you want here?''

``Me?'' (the boy)
answered the boy, angrily. '' I live here.''
``You live here!'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis panted. He (boy) turned white and clung more tightly to the railing.

'' You live here! Then where's my family? '' The boy looked surprised. '' Your family! '' he (boy) echoed. And Jurgis started toward him (boy).

'' I--this is my house! '' he (boy) cried.

``Come off!'' (the boy)
said the boy; then suddenly the door upstairs opened, and he (boy) called:
``Hey, ma!

Here's a fellow says he (fellow) owns this house. '' (he)

A stout Irishwoman came to the top of the steps. '' What's that?

'' she (boy) demanded. Jurgis turned toward her (boy). '' Where is my family? '' he (fellow) cried, wildly. '' I left them here!

The woman stared at him (fellow) in frightened wonder, she (woman) must have thought she (woman) was dealing with a maniac--Jurgis looked like one.

This is my home! What are you doing in my home?'' '' Your home! '' she (woman) echoed. '' My home! '' he (maniac) half shrieked.

'' I lived here, I tell you.''

``You must be mistaken,'' (she)
she (woman) answered him (maniac). '' No one ever lived here. This is a new house.

They told us so. They--'' '' What have they done with my family?'' shouted Jurgis, frantically. A light had begun to break upon the woman; perhaps she (woman) had had doubts of what

``they'' (she)
had told her (woman).

I bought the house only three days ago, and there was nobody here, and they told me it was all new.

'' I don't know where your family is,'' she (woman) said. '' Do you really mean you had ever rented it?''

``Rented it!

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

panted Jurgis. '' I bought it! I paid for it! I own it! And they--my God, can't you tell me where my people went?

'' She (woman) made him (God) understand at last that she (woman) knew nothing. Jurgis' brain was so confused that he (God) could not grasp the situation.

It was as if his (God) family had been wiped out of existence; as if they were proving to be dream people, who never had existed at all.

He (God) was quite lost--but then suddenly he (God) thought of Grandmother Majauszkiene, who lived in the next block. She (Grandmother) would know! He (God) turned and started at a run.

Grandmother Majauszkiene came to the door herself. She (Grandmother) cried out when she (Grandmother) saw Jurgis, wild-eyed and shaking. Yes, yes, she (Grandmother) could tell him (God).

The family had moved; they had not been able to pay the rent and they had been turned out into the snow, and the house had been repainted and sold again the next week.

No, she (Grandmother) had not heard how they were, but she (Grandmother) could tell him (God) that they had gone back to Aniele Jukniene, with whom they had stayed when they first came to the yards.

Wouldn't Jurgis come in and rest? It was certainly too bad--if only he (God) had not got into jail-- And so Jurgis turned and staggered away.

He (God) did not go very far round the corner he (God) gave out completely, and sat down on the steps of a saloon, and hid his (God) face in his (God) hands, and shook all over with dry, racking sobs.

Grief, despair, rage, overwhelmed him (God)--what was any imagination of the thing to this heartbreaking, crushing reality of it--to the sight of strange people living in his (God) house, hanging their curtains to his (God) windows, staring at him (God) with hostile eyes!

Their home! Their home! They had lost it! It was monstrous, it was unthinkable--they could not do it--it could not be true!

Only think what he (God) had suffered for that house--what miseries they had all suffered for it--the price they had paid for it!

Their sacrifices in the beginning, their three hundred dollars that they had scraped together, all they owned in the world, all that stood between them and starvation!

And then their toil, month by month, to get together the twelve dollars, and the interest as well, and now and then the taxes, and the other charges, and the repairs, and what not!

Why, they had put their very souls into their payments on that house, they had paid for it with their sweat and tears--yes, more, with their very lifeblood.

Dede Antanas had died of the struggle to earn that money--he (Antanas) would have been alive and strong today if he (Antanas) had not had to work in Durham's dark cellars to earn his (Antanas) share.

And Ona, too, had given her (Ona) health and strength to pay for it--she (Ona) was wrecked and ruined because of it; and so was he (Antanas), who had been a big, strong man three years ago, and now sat here shivering, broken, cowed, weeping like a hysterical child.

The whole long agony came back to him (man). Ah! they had cast their all into the fight; and they had lost, they had lost!

And their house was gone--they were back where they had started from, flung out into the cold to starve and freeze!

Jurgis could see all the truth now--could see himself, through the whole long course of events, the victim of ravenous vultures that had torn into his (victim) vitals and devoured him (victim); of fiends that had racked and tortured him (victim), mocking him (victim), meantime, jeering in his (victim) face.

All that they had paid was gone--every cent of it. Ah, God, the horror of it, the monstrous, hideous, demoniacal wickedness of it!

He (God) and his (God) family, helpless women and children, struggling to live, ignorant and defenseless and forlorn as they were--and the enemies that had been lurking for them, crouching upon their trail and thirsting for their blood!

That trap of the extra payments, the interest, and all the other charges that they had not the means to pay, and would never have attempted to pay!

And then all the tricks of the packers, their masters, the tyrants who ruled them--the shutdowns and the scarcity of work, the irregular hours and the cruel speeding-up, the lowering of wages, the raising of prices!

The mercilessness of nature about them, of heat and cold, rain and snow; the mercilessness of the city, of the country in which they lived, of its laws and customs that they did not understand!

All of these things had worked together for the company that had marked them for its prey and was waiting for its chance.

And now, with this last hideous injustice, its time had come, and it had turned them out bag and baggage, and taken their house and sold it again!

And they could do nothing, they were tied hand and foot--the law was against them, the whole machinery of society was at their oppressors' command!

If Jurgis so much as raised a hand against them, back he (their) would go into that wild-beast pen from which he (their) had just escaped!

To get up and go away was to give up, to acknowledge defeat, to leave the strange family in possession; and Jurgis might have sat shivering in the rain for hours before he (their) could do that, had it not been for the thought of his (their) family.

It might be that he (their) had worse things yet to learn--and so he (their) got to his (their) feet and started away, walking on, wearily, half-dazed.

To Aniele's house, in back of the yards, was a good two miles; the distance had never seemed longer to Jurgis, and when he (their) saw the familiar dingy-gray shanty his (their) heart was beating fast.

That first lying circular, that smooth-tongued slippery agent! He (agent) ran up the steps and began to hammer upon the door. The old woman herself came to open it.

She (woman) had shrunk all up with her (woman) rheumatism since Jurgis had seen her (woman) last, and her (woman) yellow parchment face stared up at him (agent) from a little above the level of the doorknob.

She (woman) gave a start when she (woman) saw him (agent). '' Is Ona here? '' he (agent) cried, breathlessly. '' Yes,'' was the answer,

``she (woman)'s here.'' (unknown)

``How-- '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis began, and then stopped short, clutching convulsively at the side of the door. From somewhere within the house had come a sudden cry, a wild, horrible scream of anguish.

And the voice was Ona's. For a moment Jurgis stood half-paralyzed with fright; then he (agent) bounded past the old woman and into the room.

One of them started to her (woman) feet as Jurgis entered; she (woman) was haggard and frightfully thin, with one arm tied up in bandages--he (agent) hardly realized that it was Marija.

It was Aniele's kitchen, and huddled round the stove were half a dozen women, pale and frightened. He (agent) looked first for Ona; then, not seeing her (Ona), he (agent) stared at the women, expecting them to speak.

But they sat dumb, gazing back at him (agent), panic-stricken; and a second later came another piercing scream. It was from the rear of the house, and upstairs.

Jurgis bounded to a door of the room and flung it open; there was a ladder leading through a trap door to the garret, and he (agent) was at the foot of it when suddenly he (agent) heard a voice behind him (agent), and saw Marija at his (agent) heels.

She (Ona) seized him (agent) by the sleeve with her (Ona) good hand, panting wildly,

``No, no, Jurgis! Stop!'' (him)
'' What do you mean?

'' he (agent) gasped. '' You mustn't go up,'' she (Ona) cried. Jurgis was half-crazed with bewilderment and fright. '' What's the matter?

Marija clung to him (agent) tightly; he (agent) could hear Ona sobbing and moaning above, and he (agent) fought to get away and climb up, without waiting for her (Ona) reply.

'' he (agent) shouted. '' What is it?'' '' No, no,'' she (Ona) rushed on. '' Jurgis! You mustn't go up! It's--it's the child!''

``The child? '' (he)
he (agent) echoed in perplexity.
``Antanas? '' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
Marija answered him (Antanas), in a whisper:
``The new one! '' (him)
And then Jurgis went limp, and caught himself on the ladder.

He (Antanas) stared at her (Ona) as if she (Ona) were a ghost. '' The new one! '' he (Antanas) gasped. '' But it isn't time,'' he (Antanas) added, wildly.

Marija nodded. '' I know,'' she (Ona) said;

``but it's come. '' (she)
And then again came Ona's scream, smiting him (Antanas) like a blow in the face, making him (Antanas) wince and turn white.

Her (Ona) voice died away into a wail--then he (Antanas) heard her (Ona) sobbing again,

``My God--let me die, let me die!'' (he)
And Marija hung her (Ona) arms about him (God), crying:
``Come out!

Come away!'' (him)

She (Ona) dragged him (God) back into the kitchen, half carrying him (God), for he (God) had gone all to pieces. It was as if the pillars of his (God) soul had fallen in--he (God) was blasted with horror.

In the room he (God) sank into a chair, trembling like a leaf, Marija still holding him (God), and the women staring at him (God) in dumb, helpless fright.

And then again Ona cried out; he (God) could hear it nearly as plainly here, and he (God) staggered to his (God) feet. ''

Not very long,'' Marija answered, and then, at a signal from Aniele, she (Ona) rushed on:

``You go away, Jurgis you can't help--go away and come back later.

How long has this been going on? '' (she)

he (God) panted. '' It's all right--it's-- ''
``Who's with her (Ona)?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis demanded; and then, seeing Marija hesitating, he (God) cried again,
``Who's with her (Ona)?'' (he)

``She (Ona)'s--she (Ona)'s all right,'' (she)
she (Ona) answered. '' Elzbieta's with her (Ona).'' '' But the doctor! '' he (doctor) panted. '' Some one who knows!

He (doctor) seized Marija by the arm; she (Ona) trembled, and her (Ona) voice sank beneath a whisper as she (Ona) replied,

``We--we have no money.

'' (she)

'' Then, frightened at the look on his (doctor) face, she (Ona) exclaimed:
``It's all right, Jurgis! You don't understand--go away--go away!

Ah, if you only had waited!'' (she)

Above her (Ona) protests Jurgis heard Ona again; he (doctor) was almost out of his (doctor) mind. It was all new to him (doctor), raw and horrible--it had fallen upon him (doctor) like a lightning stroke.

When little Antanas was born he (Antanas) had been at work, and had known nothing about it until it was over; and now he (Antanas) was not to be controlled.

The frightened women were at their wits' end; one after another they tried to reason with him (Antanas), to make him (Antanas) understand that this was the lot of woman.

In the end they half drove him (Antanas) out into the rain, where he (Antanas) began to pace up and down, bareheaded and frantic.

Because he (Antanas) could hear Ona from the street, he (Antanas) would first go away to escape the sounds, and then come back because he (Antanas) could not help it.

At the end of a quarter of an hour he (Antanas) rushed up the steps again, and for fear that he (Antanas) would break in the door they had to open it and let him (Antanas) in.

There was no arguing with him (Antanas). They could not tell him (Antanas) that all was going well-- how could they know , he (Antanas) cried--why, she (Antanas) was dying, she (Antanas) was being torn to pieces!

Listen to her (Antanas)--listen! Why, it was monstrous--it could not be allowed--there must be some help for it! Had they tried to get a doctor?

They might pay him (doctor) afterward-- they could promise--

``We couldn't promise, Jurgis,'' (him)
protested Marija. '' We had no money--we have scarcely been able to keep alive.''

'' But I can work,'' Jurgis exclaimed. '' I can earn money!'' '' Yes,'' she (Antanas) answered--

``but we thought you were in jail.

Marija went on to tell how she (Antanas) had tried to find a midwife, and how they had demanded ten, fifteen, even twenty-five dollars, and that in cash.

How could we know when you would return? They will not work for nothing. '' (she)

'' And I had only a quarter,'' she (Antanas) said.

I have spent every cent of my money--all that I had in the bank; and I owe the doctor who has been coming to see me, and he (doctor) has stopped because he (doctor) thinks I don't mean to pay him (doctor).

'' And we owe Aniele for two weeks' rent, and she (Antanas) is nearly starving, and is afraid of being turned out.

We have been borrowing and begging to keep alive, and there is nothing more we can do-- ''

``And the children?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
cried Jurgis.

'' The children have not been home for three days, the weather has been so bad. They could not know what is happening--it came suddenly, two months before we expected it.''

Jurgis was standing by the table, and he (doctor) caught himself with his (doctor) hand; his (doctor) head sank and his (doctor) arms shook --it looked as if he (doctor) were going to collapse.

Then suddenly Aniele got up and came hobbling toward him (doctor), fumbling in her (it) skirt pocket. She (it) drew out a dirty rag, in one corner of which she (it) had something tied.

'' Here, Jurgis! '' she (it) said,

``I have some money. Palauk! See! '' (she)
She (it) unwrapped it and counted it out--thirty-four cents.

And maybe the rest can help--give him (doctor) some money, you; he (doctor) will pay you back some day, and it will do him (doctor) good to have something to think about, even if he (doctor) doesn't succeed.

'' You go, now,'' she (it) said,

``and try and get somebody yourself. When he (doctor) comes back, maybe it will be over.

And so the other women turned out the contents of their pocketbooks; most of them had only pennies and nickels, but they gave him (doctor) all.

Mrs. Olszewski, who lived next door, and had a husband who was a skilled cattle butcher, but a drinking man, gave nearly half a dollar, enough to raise the whole sum to a dollar and a quarter.

'' (she)

Then Jurgis thrust it into his (man) pocket, still holding it tightly in his (man) fist, and started away at a run.

Chapter 19

``Madame Haupt Hebamme'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
, ran a sign, swinging from a second-story window over a saloon on the avenue; at a side door was another sign, with a hand pointing up a dingy flight of stairs.

Jurgis went up them, three at a time. Madame Haupt was frying pork and onions, and had her (them) door half open to let out the smoke.

When he (Haupt) tried to knock upon it, it swung open the rest of the way, and he (Haupt) had a glimpse of her (them), with a black bottle turned up to her (them) lips.

when she (them) walked she (them) rolled like a small boat on the ocean, and the dishes in the cupboard jostled each other.

Then he (Haupt) knocked louder, and she (them) started and put it away. She (them) was a Dutchwoman, enormously fat-- She (Dutchwoman) wore a filthy blue wrapper, and her (Dutchwoman) teeth were black.

'' Vot is it? '' she (Dutchwoman) said, when she (Dutchwoman) saw Jurgis. He (Haupt) had run like mad all the way and was so out of breath he (Haupt) could hardly speak.

His (Haupt) hair was flying and his (Haupt) eyes wild--he (Haupt) looked like a man that had risen from the tomb. '' My wife!''

he (Haupt) panted.

``Come quickly!'' (Madame Haupt)
Madame Haupt set the frying pan to one side and wiped her (wife) hands on her (wife) wrapper. ''

You vant me to come for a case? '' she (wife) inquired. '' Yes,'' gasped Jurgis. '' I haf yust come back from a case,'' she (wife) said.

'' I haf had no time to eat my dinner. Still--if it is so bad--''

``Yes--it is! '' (he)
cried he (Haupt). ''

Vell, den, perhaps--vot you pay?''

``I--I--how much do you want?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis stammered. '' Tventy-five dollars. '' His (Haupt) face fell. '' I can't pay that,'' he (Haupt) said.

The woman was watching him (Haupt) narrowly. '' How much do you pay? '' she (woman) demanded. '' Must I pay now--right away?''

'' Yes; all my customers do. '' '' I--I haven't much money,'' Jurgis began in an agony of dread. '' I've been in--in trouble--and my money is gone.

But I'll pay you--every cent--just as soon as I can; I can work-- ''

``Vot is your work?'' (I)
``I have no place now.

I must get one. But I-- '' (He)

``How much haf you got now? '' (He)
He (you) could hardly bring himself to reply.

When he (you) said

``A dollar and a quarter,'' (he)
the woman laughed in his (you) face. '' I vould not put on my hat for a dollar and a quarter,'' she (woman) said.

'' It's all I've got,'' he (you) pleaded, his (you) voice breaking. '' I must get some one--my wife will die. I can't help it--

She (wife) turned to him (you) and answered, out of the steam and noise:

``Git me ten dollars cash, und so you can pay me the rest next mont'.'' (him)

I-- '' Madame Haupt had put back her (wife) pork and onions on the stove.

``I can't do it--I haven't got it!'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Jurgis protested. '' I tell you I have only a dollar and a quarter. '' The woman turned to her (woman) work.

'' I don't believe you,'' she (woman) said. '' Dot is all to try to sheat me. Vot is de reason a big man like you has got only a dollar und a quarter?''

'' I've just been in jail,'' Jurgis cried-- he (man) was ready to get down upon his (man) knees to the woman--

``and I had no money before, and my family has almost starved.'' (the woman)

'' Vere is your friends, dot ought to help you?'' '' They are all poor,'' he (man) answered. '' They gave me this.

I have done everything I can--''

``Haven't you got notting you can sell?'' (I)
'' I have nothing, I tell you--I have nothing,'' he (man) cried, frantically.

'' Can't you borrow it, den? Don't your store people trust you?'' Then, as he (man) shook his (man) head, she (I) went on:

I vill save your wife und baby for you, and it vill not seem like mooch to you in de end.

``Listen to me--if you git me you vill be glad of it. If you loose dem now how you tink you feel den?

Und here is a lady dot knows her (lady) business--I could send you to people in dis block, und dey vould tell you--

'' (Madame Haupt)

Madame Haupt was pointing her (lady) cooking-fork at Jurgis persuasively; but her (lady) words were more than he (Haupt) could bear. He (Haupt) flung up his (Haupt) hands with a gesture of despair and turned and started away.

'' It's no use,'' he (Haupt) exclaimed--but suddenly he (Haupt) heard the woman's voice behind him (Haupt) again--

``I vill make it five dollars for you.

'' (him)

She (woman) followed behind him (Haupt), arguing with him (Haupt). '' You vill be foolish not to take such an offer,'' she (woman) said.

'' You von't find nobody go out on a rainy day like dis for less. Vy, I haf never took a case in my life so sheap as dot.

I couldn't pay mine room rent--'' Jurgis interrupted her (woman) with an oath of rage. '' If I haven't got it,'' he (Haupt) shouted,

``how can I pay it?

Damn it, I would pay you if I could, but I tell you I haven't got it. I haven't got it!

Do you hear me I haven't got it!'' (he)

He (Haupt) turned and started away again. He (Haupt) was halfway down the stairs before Madame Haupt could shout to him (Haupt):

``Vait! I vill go mit you! Come back!'' (him)
He (Haupt) went back into the room again. '' It is not goot to tink of anybody suffering,'' she (I) said, in a melancholy voice.

'' I might as vell go mit you for noffing as vot you offer me, but I vill try to help you.

How far is it?''

``Three or four blocks from here. '' (unknown)
``Tree or four! Und so I shall get soaked! Gott in Himmel, it ought to be vorth more!

Vun dollar und a quarter, und a day like dis!--But you understand now--you vill pay me de rest of twenty-five dollars soon?'' (unknown)

``As soon as I can.'' (unknown)
``Some time dis mont'? '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
'' Yes, within a month,'' said poor Jurgis. '' Anything! Hurry up!''

'' Vere is de dollar und a quarter? '' persisted Madame Haupt, relentlessly. Jurgis put the money on the table and the woman counted it and stowed it away.

Then she (woman) wiped her (woman) greasy hands again and proceeded to get ready, complaining all the time; she (woman) was so fat that it was painful for her (woman) to move, and she (woman) grunted and gasped at every step.

She (woman) took off her (woman) wrapper without even taking the trouble to turn her (woman) back to Jurgis, and put on her (woman) corsets and dress.

Then there was a black bonnet which had to be adjusted carefully, and an umbrella which was mislaid, and a bag full of necessaries which had to be collected from here and there--the man being nearly crazy with anxiety in the meantime.

When they were on the street he (man) kept about four paces ahead of her (woman), turning now and then, as if he (man) could hurry her (woman) on by the force of his (man) desire.

But Madame Haupt could only go so far at a step, and it took all her (woman) attention to get the needed breath for that.

It was not over yet, Jurgis learned--he (Haupt) heard Ona crying still; and meantime Madame Haupt removed her (Ona) bonnet and laid it on the mantelpiece, and got out of her (Ona) bag, first an old dress and then a saucer of goose grease, which she (Ona) proceeded to rub upon her (Ona) hands.

The more cases this goose grease is used in, the better luck it brings to the midwife, and so she (midwife) keeps it upon her (midwife) kitchen mantelpiece or stowed away in a cupboard with her (midwife) dirty clothes, for months, and sometimes even for years.

They came at last to the house, and to the group of frightened women in the kitchen. Then they escorted her (midwife) to the ladder, and Jurgis heard her (midwife) give an exclamation of dismay.

'' Gott in Himmel, vot for haf you brought me to a place like dis? I could not climb up dot ladder.

Vot sort of a place is dot for a woman to bear a child in--up in a garret, mit only a ladder to it?

I could not git troo a trap door! I vill not try it--vy, I might kill myself already. You ought to be ashamed of yourselves!''

At last Aniele succeeded in pacifying her (woman), and she (woman) essayed the ascent; then, however, she (woman) had to be stopped while the old woman cautioned her (woman) about the floor of the garret.

They had no real floor--they had laid old boards in one part to make a place for the family to live; it was all right and safe there, but the other part of the garret had only the joists of the floor, and the lath and plaster of the ceiling below, and if one stepped on this there would be a catastrophe.

Jurgis stood in the doorway and listened to her (woman) scolding, half drowning out the horrible moans and screams of Ona. As it was half dark up above, perhaps one of the others had best go up first with a candle.

Then there were more outcries and threatening, until at last Jurgis had a vision of a pair of elephantine legs disappearing through the trap door, and felt the house shake as Madame Haupt started to walk.

Then suddenly Aniele came to him (Haupt) and took him (Haupt) by the arm. '' Now,'' she (Ona) said,

``you go away. Do as I tell you--you have done all you can, and you are only in the way.

Go away and stay away.'' (she)

'' But where shall I go?'' Jurgis asked, helplessly. '' I don't know where,'' she (Ona) answered.

'' Go on the street, if there is no other place--only go! And stay all night!'' In the end she (Ona) and Marija pushed him (Haupt) out of the door and shut it behind him (Haupt).

It was just about sundown, and it was turning cold--the rain had changed to snow, and the slush was freezing. Jurgis shivered in his (Haupt) thin clothing, and put his (Haupt) hands into his (Haupt) pockets and started away.

He (Haupt) had not eaten since morning, and he (Haupt) felt weak and ill; with a sudden throb of hope he (Haupt) recollected he (Haupt) was only a few blocks from the saloon where he (Haupt) had been wont to eat his (Haupt) dinner.

They might have mercy on him (Haupt) there, or he (Haupt) might meet a friend. He (Haupt) set out for the place as fast as he (Haupt) could walk.

'' Hello, Jack,'' said the saloon-keeper, when he (Jack) entered--they call all foreigners and unskilled men

``Jack'' (men Jack)
in Packingtown. '' Where've you been?

'' Jurgis went straight to the bar. '' I've been in jail,'' he (Jack) said,

``and I've just got out. I walked home all the way, and I've not a cent, and had nothing to eat since this morning.

And I've lost my home, and my wife's ill, and I'm done up. '' (he)

The saloon-keeper gazed at him (Jack), with his (Jack) haggard white face and his (Jack) blue trembling lips.

Then he (Jack) pushed a big bottle toward him (Jack).

``Fill her (wife) up!'' (he)
he (Jack) said. Jurgis could hardly hold the bottle, his (Jack) hands shook so.

So Jurgis drank a large glass of whisky, and then turned to the lunch counter, in obedience to the other's suggestion.

He (Jack) ate all he (Jack) dared, stuffing it in as fast as he (Jack) could; and then, after trying to speak his (Jack) gratitude, he (Jack) went and sat down by the big red stove in the middle of the room.

'' Don't be afraid,'' said the saloon-keeper,

``fill her (wife) up!'' (the saloon-keeper)
It was too good to last, however--like all things in this hard world.

In an hour or so the packing houses would be closing and the men coming in from their work; and they would not come into a place that smelt of Jurgis.

Also it was Saturday night, and in a couple of hours would come a violin and a cornet, and in the rear part of the saloon the families of the neighborhood would dance and feast upon wienerwurst and lager, until two or three o'clock in the morning.

His (their) soaked clothing began to steam, and the horrible stench of fertilizer to fill the room. The saloon-keeper coughed once or twice, and then remarked, ``Say, Jack, I'm afraid you'll have to quit.

He (Jack) was used to the sight of human wrecks, this saloon-keeper; he (Jack)

``fired'' (he)
dozens of them every night, just as haggard and cold and forlorn as this one.

But they were all men who had given up and been counted out, while Jurgis was still in the fight, and had reminders of decency about him (Jack).

As he (Jack) got up meekly, the other reflected that he (Jack) had always been a steady man, and might soon be a good customer again.

'' '' You've been up against it, I see,'' he (Jack) said.

``Come this way. '' (unknown)
In the rear of the saloon were the cellar stairs.

There was a door above and another below, both safely padlocked, making the stairs an admirable place to stow away a customer who might still chance to have money, or a political light whom it was not advisable to kick out of doors.

The whisky had only half warmed him (Jack), and he (Jack) could not sleep, exhausted as he (Jack) was; he (Jack) would nod forward, and then start up, shivering with the cold, and begin to remember again.

Hour after hour passed, until he (Jack) could only persuade himself that it was not morning by the sounds of music and laughter and singing that were to be heard from the room.

When at last these ceased, he (Jack) expected that he (Jack) would be turned out into the street; as this did not happen, he (Jack) fell to wondering whether the man had forgotten him (man).

In the end, when the silence and suspense were no longer to be borne, he (man) got up and hammered on the door; and the proprietor came, yawning and rubbing his (proprietor) eyes.

So Jurgis spent the night. He (proprietor) was keeping open all night, and dozing between customers. '' I want to go home,'' Jurgis said.

'' I'm worried about my wife--I can't wait any longer.''

``Why the hell didn't you say so before?'' (the man)
said the man.

'' I thought you didn't have any home to go to. '' Jurgis went outside. It was four o'clock in the morning, and as black as night.

There were three or four inches of fresh snow on the ground, and the flakes were falling thick and fast. He (man) turned toward Aniele's and started at a run.

There was a light burning in the kitchen window and the blinds were drawn. The door was unlocked and Jurgis rushed in.

Aniele, Marija, and the rest of the women were huddled about the stove, exactly as before; with them were several newcomers, Jurgis noticed--also he (man) noticed that the house was silent.

'' Well?'' he (man) said. No one answered him (man), they sat staring at him (man) with their pale faces. He (man) cried again:

``Well?

'' (He)

And then, by the light of the smoky lamp, he (man) saw Marija who sat nearest him (man), shaking her (man) head slowly.

'' Not yet,'' she (man) said. And Jurgis gave a cry of dismay. '' Not yet? '' Again Marija's head shook. The poor fellow stood dumfounded.

'' I don't hear her (man),'' he (fellow) gasped. '' She (man)'s been quiet a long time,'' replied the other. There was another pause--broken suddenly by a voice from the attic:

``Hello, there!'' (the women)
Several of the women ran into the next room, while Marija sprang toward Jurgis. '' Wait here! '' she (man) cried, and the two stood, pale and trembling, listening.

In a few moments it became clear that Madame Haupt was engaged in descending the ladder, scolding and exhorting again, while the ladder creaked in protest.

In a moment or two she (man) reached the ground, angry and breathless, and they heard her (man) coming into the room. Jurgis gave one glance at her (man), and then turned white and reeled.
