She (man) had her (man) jacket off, like one of the workers on the killing beds. Her (man) hands and arms were smeared with blood, and blood was splashed upon her (man) clothing and her (man) face.

She (man) stood breathing hard, and gazing about her (man); no one made a sound. '' I haf done my best,'' she (man) began suddenly.

'' I can do noffing more--dere is no use to try. '' Again there was silence. '' It ain't my fault,'' she (man) said.

'' You had ought to haf had a doctor, und not vaited so long--it vas too late already ven I come.

'' Once more there was deathlike stillness. Marija was clutching Jurgis with all the power of her (man) one well arm. Then suddenly Madame Haupt turned to Aniele.

'' You haf not got something to drink, hey? '' she (man) queried. '' Some brandy? '' Aniele shook her (man) head. ''

Herr Gott! '' exclaimed Madame Haupt. '' Such people! Perhaps you vill give me someting to eat den-- I haf had noffing since yesterday morning,

If I could haf known it vas like dis, I vould never haf come for such money as you gif me.

und I haf vorked myself near to death here. '' At this moment she (man) chanced to look round, and saw Jurgis: She (man) shook her (man) finger at him (Haupt).

'' You understand me,'' she (man) said, ``you pays me dot money yust de same! It is not my fault dat you send for me

so late I can't help your vife. It is not my fault if der baby comes mit one arm first, so dot I can't save it.

it is not fit for dogs to be born, und mit notting to eat only vot I brings in mine own pockets.

Here Madame Haupt paused for a moment to get her (man) breath; and Marija, seeing the beads of sweat on Jurgis's forehead, and feeling the quivering of his (Haupt) frame, broke out in a low voice:

``How is Ona?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

I haf tried all night, und in dot place vere ''

``How is she (man)? '' (I)
echoed Madame Haupt. '' How do you tink she (man) can be ven

you leave her (man) to kill herself so? I told dem dot ven they send for de priest. She (man) is young, und she (man) might haf got over it,

und been vell und strong, if she (man) had been treated right. She (man) fight hard, dot girl--she (man) is not yet quite dead.

'' And Jurgis gave a frantic scream. '' Dead!'' '' She (man) vill die, of course,'' said the other angrily. '' Der baby is dead now.

The garret was lighted by a candle stuck upon a board; it had almost burned itself out, and was sputtering and smoking as Jurgis rushed up the ladder.

He (man) could make out dimly in one corner a pallet of rags and old blankets, spread upon the floor; at the foot of it was a crucifix, and near it a priest muttering a prayer.

She (man) was covered with a blanket, but he (priest) could see her (man) shoulders and one arm lying bare; she (man) was so shrunken he (priest) would scarcely have known her (man)--she (man) was all but a skeleton, and as white as a piece of chalk.

'' In a far corner crouched Elzbieta, moaning and wailing. Upon the pallet lay Ona. Her (Ona) eyelids were closed, and she (Ona) lay still as death.

He (priest) staggered toward her (Ona) and fell upon his (priest) knees with a cry of anguish:

``Ona! Ona!'' (her)
She (Ona) did not stir. He (priest) caught her (Ona) hand in his (priest), and began to clasp it frantically, calling:
``Look at me!

Answer me! It is Jurgis come back-- don't you hear me? '' (He)

There was the faintest quivering of the eyelids, and he (priest) called again in frenzy:

One instant she (Ona) looked at him (priest)--there was a flash of recognition between them, he (priest) saw her (Ona) afar off, as through a dim vista, standing forlorn.

He (priest) stretched out his (priest) arms to her (Ona), he (priest) called her (Ona) in wild despair; a fearful yearning surged up in him (priest), hunger for her (Ona) that was agony, desire that was a new being born within him (priest), tearing his (priest) heartstrings, torturing him (priest).

``Ona! Ona!'' (unknown)
Then suddenly her (Ona) eyes opened one instant. But it was all in vain--she (Ona) faded from him (priest), she (Ona) slipped back and was gone.

And a wail of anguish burst from him (priest), great sobs shook all his (priest) frame, and hot tears ran down his (priest) cheeks and fell upon her (Ona).

He (priest) clutched her (Ona) hands, he (priest) shook her (Ona), he (priest) caught her (Ona) in his (priest) arms and pressed her (Ona) to him (priest) but she (Ona) lay cold and still--

The word rang through him (priest) like the sound of a bell, echoing in the far depths of him (priest), making forgotten chords to vibrate, old shadowy fears to stir--fears of the dark, fears of the void, fears of annihilation.

she (Ona) was gone--she (Ona) was gone! She (Ona) was dead! She (Ona) was dead! He (priest) would never see her (Ona) again, never hear her (Ona) again!

An icy horror of loneliness seized him (priest); he (priest) saw himself standing apart and watching all the world fade away from him (priest)--a world of shadows, of fickle dreams.

He (priest) was like a little child, in his (priest) fright and grief; he (priest) called and called, and got no answer, and his (priest) cries of despair echoed through the house, making the women downstairs draw nearer to each other in fear.

He (priest) was inconsolable, beside himself--the priest came and laid his (priest) hand upon his (priest) shoulder and whispered to him (priest), but he (priest) heard not a sound.

He (priest) was gone away himself, stumbling through the shadows, and groping after the soul that had fled. So he (priest) lay. The gray dawn came up and crept into the attic.

The priest left, the women left, and he (priest) was alone with the still, white figure--quieter now, but moaning and shuddering, wrestling with the grisly fiend.

Now and then he (fiend) would raise himself and stare at the white mask before him (fiend), then hide his (fiend) eyes because he (fiend) could not bear it.

Dead! dead! And she (fiend) was only a girl, she (fiend) was barely eighteen! Her (fiend) life had hardly begun--and here she (fiend) lay murdered--mangled, tortured to death!

More of the neighbors had come in, and they stared at him (fiend) in silence as he (fiend) sank down upon a chair by the table and buried his (fiend) face in his (fiend) arms.

A few minutes later the front door opened; a blast of cold and snow rushed in, and behind it little Kotrina, breathless from running, and blue with the cold.

It was morning when he (fiend) rose up and came down into the kitchen--haggard and ashen gray, reeling and dazed. '' I'm home again!

Looking from one to another she (fiend) saw that something had happened, and she (fiend) asked, in a lower voice:

``What's the matter?'' (she)

'' she (fiend) exclaimed. '' I could hardly-- '' And then, seeing Jurgis, she (fiend) stopped with an exclamation. Before anyone could reply, Jurgis started up; he (fiend) went toward her (fiend), walking unsteadily.

'' Where have you been? '' he (fiend) demanded. '' Selling papers with the boys,'' she (fiend) said. '' The snow--''

``Have you any money?'' (he)
he (fiend) demanded.

'' Yes.''

``How much?'' (unknown)
``Nearly three dollars, Jurgis.'' (unknown)
``Give it to me. '' (Kotrina)
Kotrina, frightened by his (fiend) manner, glanced at the others.

``Give it to me!'' (he)
he (fiend) commanded again, and she (fiend) put her (fiend) hand into her (fiend) pocket and pulled out a lump of coins tied in a bit of rag.

Jurgis took it without a word, and went out of the door and down the street. Three doors away was a saloon.

``Whisky,'' (he)
he (fiend) said, as he (fiend) entered, and as the man pushed him (fiend) some, he (fiend) tore at the rag with his (fiend) teeth and pulled out half a dollar.

'' How much is the bottle? '' he (fiend) said. '' I want to get drunk. '' Chapter 20 But a big man cannot stay drunk very long on three dollars.

That was Sunday morning, and Monday night Jurgis came home, sober and sick, realizing that he (man) had spent every cent the family owned, and had not bought a single instant's forgetfulness with it.

Ona was not yet buried; but the police had been notified, and on the morrow they would put the body in a pine coffin and take it to the potter's field.

Elzbieta was out begging now, a few pennies from each of the neighbors, to get enough to pay for a mass for her (Elzbieta); and the children were upstairs starving to death, while he (potter), good-for-nothing rascal, had been spending their money on drink.

So spoke Aniele, scornfully, and when he (rascal) started toward the fire she (Elzbieta) added the information that her (Elzbieta) kitchen was no longer for him (rascal) to fill with his (rascal) phosphate stinks.

She (Elzbieta) had crowded all her (Elzbieta) boarders into one room on Ona's account, but now he (rascal) could go up in the garret where he (rascal) belonged--and not there much longer, either, if he (rascal) did not pay her (Elzbieta) some rent.

Jurgis went without a word, and, stepping over half a dozen sleeping boarders in the next room, ascended the ladder. It was dark up above; they could not afford any light; also it was nearly as cold as outdoors.

In a corner, as far away from the corpse as possible, sat Marija, holding little Antanas in her (Elzbieta) one good arm and trying to soothe him (Antanas) to sleep.

Marija said not a word to Jurgis; he (Antanas) crept in like a whipped cur, and went and sat down by the body.

Perhaps he (Antanas) ought to have meditated upon the hunger of the children, and upon his (Antanas) own baseness; but he (Antanas) thought only of Ona, he (Antanas) gave himself up again to the luxury of grief.

In another corner crouched poor little Juozapas, wailing because he (Antanas) had had nothing to eat all day. He (Antanas) shed no tears, being ashamed to make a sound; he (Antanas) sat motionless and shuddering with his (Antanas) anguish.

He (Antanas) had never dreamed how much he (Antanas) loved Ona, until now that she (Ona) was gone; until now that he (Antanas) sat here, knowing that on the morrow they would take her (Ona) away, and that he (Antanas) would never lay eyes upon her (Ona) again--never all the days of his (Antanas) life.

His (Antanas) old love, which had been starved to death, beaten to death, awoke in him (Antanas) again; the floodgates of memory were lifted--he (Antanas) saw all their life together, saw her (Ona) as he (Antanas) had seen her (Ona) in Lithuania, the first day at the fair, beautiful as the flowers, singing like a bird.

He (Antanas) saw her (Ona) as he (Antanas) had married her (Ona), with all her (Ona) tenderness, with her (Ona) heart of wonder; the very words she (Ona) had spoken seemed to ring now in his (Antanas) ears, the tears she (Ona) had shed to be wet upon his (Antanas) cheek.

--she (Ona) had been the same hungry soul to the end, stretching out her (Ona) arms to him (Antanas), pleading with him (Antanas), begging him (Antanas) for love and tenderness.

And she (Ona) had suffered--so cruelly she (Ona) had suffered, such agonies, such infamies--ah, God, the memory of them was not to be borne.

The long, cruel battle with misery and hunger had hardened and embittered him (God), but it had not changed her (Ona) What a monster of wickedness, of heartlessness, he (God) had been!

Every angry word that he (God) had ever spoken came back to him (God) and cut him (God) like a knife; every selfish act that he (God) had done--with what torments he (God) paid for them now!

And such devotion and awe as welled up in his (God) soul--now that it could never be spoken, now that it was too late, too late!

His (God) bosom-was choking with it, bursting with it; he (God) crouched here in the darkness beside her (Ona), stretching out his (God) arms to her (Ona)--and she (Ona) was gone forever, she (Ona) was dead!

He (God) could have screamed aloud with the horror and despair of it; a sweat of agony beaded his (God) forehead, yet he (God) dared not make a sound--he (God) scarcely dared to breathe, because of his (God) shame and loathing of himself.

Late at night came Elzbieta, having gotten the money for a mass, and paid for it in advance, lest she (Elzbieta) should be tempted too sorely at home.

She (Elzbieta) brought also a bit of stale rye bread that some one had given her (Elzbieta), and with that they quieted the children and got them to sleep.

She (Elzbieta) said not a word of reproach--she (Elzbieta) and Marija had chosen that course before; she (Elzbieta) would only plead with him (God), here by the corpse of his (God) dead wife.

Then she (wife) came over to Jurgis and sat down beside him (God). Already Elzbieta had choked down her (Elzbieta) tears, grief being crowded out of her (Elzbieta) soul by fear.

She (Elzbieta) had to bury one of her (Elzbieta) children--but then she (Elzbieta) had done it three times before, and each time risen up and gone back to take up the battle for the rest.

Elzbieta was one of the primitive creatures: like the angleworm, which goes on living though cut in half; like a hen, which, deprived of her (Elzbieta) chickens one by one, will mother the last that is left her (Elzbieta).

--she (Elzbieta) asked no questions about the justice of it, nor the worth-whileness of life in which destruction and death ran riot.

She (Elzbieta) did this because it was her (Elzbieta) nature And this old common-sense view she (Elzbieta) labored to impress upon Jurgis, pleading with him (creatures) with tears in her (Elzbieta) eyes.

Ona was dead, but the others were left and they must be saved. She (Ona) did not ask for her (Ona) own children.

Ona had given Antanas to him (Antanas)--the little fellow was the only remembrance of her (Ona) that he (fellow) had; he (fellow) must treasure it and protect it, he (fellow) must show himself a man.

He (fellow) knew what Ona would have had him (fellow) do, what she (Ona) would ask of him (fellow) at this moment, if she (Ona) could speak to him (fellow).

It was a terrible thing that she (Ona) should have died as she (Ona) had; but the life had been too hard for her (Ona), and she (Ona) had to go.

It was terrible that they were not able to bury her (Ona), that he (fellow) could not even have a day to mourn her (Ona)--but so it was.

She (Ona) and Marija could care for them somehow, but there was Antanas, his (Antanas) own son. Their fate was pressing; they had not a cent, and the children would perish--some money must be had.

In a little while they would be out of danger--now that they had given up the house they could live more cheaply, and with all the children working they could get along, if only he (Antanas) would not go to pieces.

It was a struggle for life with her (Ona); she (Ona) was not afraid that Jurgis would go on drinking, for he (Antanas) had no money for that, but she (Ona) was wild with dread at the thought that he (Antanas) might desert them, might take to the road, as Jonas had done.

Could he (Jonas) not be a man for Ona's sake, and pull himself together? So Elzbieta went on, with feverish intensity. But with Ona's dead body beneath his (Jonas) eyes, Jurgis could not well think of treason to his (Jonas) child.

He (Jonas) would give the little fellow his (Jonas) chance--would get to work at once, yes, tomorrow, without even waiting for Ona to be buried.

Yes, he (Jonas) said, he (Jonas) would try, for the sake of Antanas. They might trust him (Antanas), he (Antanas) would keep his (Antanas) word, come what might.

And so he (Antanas) was out before daylight the next morning, headache, heartache, and all. He (Antanas) went straight to Graham's fertilizer mill, to see if he (Antanas) could get back his (Antanas) job.

But the boss shook his (Antanas) head when he (Antanas) saw him (Antanas)--no, his (Antanas) place had been filled long ago, and there was no room for him (Antanas).

'' Do you think there will be?'' Jurgis asked. '' I may have to wait.'' '' No,'' said the other,

``it will not be worth your while to wait--there will be nothing for you here.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Jurgis stood gazing at him (Antanas) in perplexity. '' What is the matter? '' he (Antanas) asked. '' Didn't I do my work?

The other met his (Antanas) look with one of cold indifference, and answered,

``There will be nothing for you here, I said.

Jurgis had his (Antanas) suspicions as to the dreadful meaning of that incident, and he (Antanas) went away with a sinking at the heart.

He (Antanas) went and took his (Antanas) stand with the mob of hungry wretches who were standing about in the snow before the time station.

'' (he)

'' Here he (Antanas) stayed, breakfastless, for two hours, until the throng was driven away by the clubs of the police.

Jurgis had made a good many acquaintances in his (Antanas) long services at the yards--there were saloon-keepers who would trust him (Antanas) for a drink and a sandwich, and members of his (Antanas) old union who would lend him (Antanas) a dime at a pinch.

It was not a question of life and death for him (Antanas), therefore; he (Antanas) might hunt all day, and come again on the morrow, and try hanging on thus for weeks, like hundreds and thousands of others.

Meantime, Teta Elzbieta would go and beg, over in the Hyde Park district, and the children would bring home enough to pacify Aniele, and keep them all alive.

It was at the end of a week of this sort of waiting, roaming about in the bitter winds or loafing in saloons, that Jurgis stumbled on a chance in one of the cellars of Jones's big packing plant.

There was no work for him (Jones) that day. He (Jones) saw a foreman passing the open doorway, and hailed him (Jones) for a job.

'' Push a truck? '' inquired the man, and Jurgis answered,

``Yes, sir!'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
before the words were well out of his (man) mouth.

'' What's your name?'' demanded the other. '' Jurgis Rudkus. ''

``Worked in the yards before?'' (unknown)
``Yes.'' (unknown)
``Whereabouts?'' (unknown)
``Two places--Brown's killing beds and Durham's fertilizer mill.

'' (unknown)

``Why did you leave there?'' (I)
'' The first time I had an accident, and the last time I was sent up for a month.

''

``I see. Well, I'll give you a trial. Come early tomorrow and ask for Mr. Thomas. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
So Jurgis rushed home with the wild tidings that he (Thomas) had a job--that the terrible siege was over.

The remnants of the family had quite a celebration that night; and in the morning Jurgis was at the place half an hour before the time of opening.

The foreman came in shortly afterward, and when he (foreman) saw Jurgis he (foreman) frowned. '' Oh,'' he (foreman) said,

``I promised you a job, didn't I?'' (he)

'' Yes, sir,'' said Jurgis. '' Well, I'm sorry, but I made a mistake. I can't use you.'' Jurgis stared, dumfounded.

'' What's the matter? '' he (foreman) gasped. '' Nothing,'' said the man,

``only I can't use you. '' (the man)
There was the same cold, hostile stare that he (foreman) had had from the boss of the fertilizer mill.

Out in the saloons the men could tell him (foreman) all about the meaning of it; they gazed at him (foreman) with pitying eyes--poor devil, he (devil) was blacklisted!

He (devil) knew that there was no use in saying a word, and he (devil) turned and went away. What had he (devil) done?

they asked--knocked down his (devil) boss? Good heavens, then he (devil) might have known! Why, he (devil) stood as much chance of getting a job in Packingtown as of being chosen mayor of Chicago.

Why had he (mayor) wasted his (mayor) time hunting? They had him (mayor) on a secret list in every office, big and little, in the place.

They had his (mayor) name by this time in St. Louis and New York, in Omaha and Boston, in Kansas City and St. Joseph.

He (Joseph) was condemned and sentenced, without trial and without appeal; he (Joseph) could never work for the packers again--he (Joseph) could not even clean cattle pens or drive a truck in any place where they controlled.

He (Joseph) would never be told anything about it; he (Joseph) would never get any more satisfaction than he (Joseph) had gotten just now; but he (Joseph) would always find when the time came that he (Joseph) was not needed.

It would not do for him (Joseph) to give any other name, either--they had company

``spotters'' (him)
for just that purpose, and he (Joseph) wouldn't keep a job in Packingtown three days.

It was worth a fortune to the packers to keep their blacklist effective, as a warning to the men and a means of keeping down union agitation and political discontent.

He (Joseph) might try it, if he (Joseph) chose, as hundreds had tried it, and found out for themselves. Jurgis went home, carrying these new tidings to the family council.

It was a most cruel thing; here in this district was his (Joseph) home, such as it was, the place he (Joseph) was used to and the friends he (Joseph) knew--and now every possibility of employment in it was closed to him (Joseph).

There was nothing in Packingtown but packing houses; and so it was the same thing as evicting him (Joseph) from his (Joseph) home.

It would be convenient, downtown, to the children's place of work; but then Marija was on the road to recovery, and had hopes of getting a job in the yards; and though she (Joseph) did not see her (Joseph) old-time lover once a month, because of the misery of their state, yet she (Joseph) could not make up her (Joseph) mind to go away and give him (lover) up forever.

Then, too, Elzbieta had heard something about a chance to scrub floors in Durham's offices and was waiting every day for word.

In the end it was decided that Jurgis should go downtown to strike out for himself, and they would decide after he (lover) got a job.

As there was no one from whom he (lover) could borrow there, and he (lover) dared not beg for fear of being arrested, it was arranged that every day he (lover) should meet one of the children and be given fifteen cents of their earnings, upon which he (lover) could keep going.

Then all day he (lover) was to pace the streets with hundreds and thousands of other homeless wretches inquiring at stores, warehouses, and factories for a chance; and at night he (lover) was to crawl into some doorway or underneath a truck, and hide there until midnight, when he (lover) might get into one of the station houses, and spread a newspaper upon the floor, and lie down in the midst of a throng of

``bums'' (the midst)
and beggars, reeking with alcohol and tobacco, and filthy with vermin and disease.

He (lover) and the two women spent all day and half the night discussing it. So for two weeks more Jurgis fought with the demon of despair.

Once he (demon) got a chance to load a truck for half a day, and again he (demon) carried an old woman's valise and was given a quarter.

This let him (demon) into a lodging-house on several nights when he (demon) might otherwise have frozen to death; and it also gave him (demon) a chance now and then to buy a newspaper in the morning and hunt up jobs while his (demon) rivals were watching and waiting for a paper to be thrown away.

This, however, was really not the advantage it seemed, for the newspaper advertisements were a cause of much loss of precious time and of many weary journeys.

A full half of these were

``fakes,'' (unknown)
put in by the endless variety of establishments which preyed upon the helpless ignorance of the unemployed.

If Jurgis lost only his (demon) time, it was because he (demon) had nothing else to lose; whenever a smooth-tongued agent would tell him (agent) of the wonderful positions he (agent) had on hand, he (agent) could only shake his (agent) head sorrowfully and say that he (agent) had not the necessary dollar to deposit; when it was explained to him (agent) what

``big money'' (him)
he (agent) and all his (agent) family could make by coloring photographs, he (agent) could only promise to come in again when he (agent) had two dollars to invest in the outfit.

He (agent) met this man on his (agent) way to work in the giant factories of the Harvester Trust; and his (agent) friend told him (agent) to come along and he (agent) would speak a good word for him (agent) to his (agent) boss, whom he (agent) knew well.

So Jurgis trudged four or five miles, and passed through a waiting throng of unemployed at the gate under the escort of his (agent) friend.

His (agent) knees nearly gave way beneath him (agent) when the foreman, after looking him (foreman) over and questioning him (foreman), told him (foreman) that he (foreman) could find an opening for him (foreman).

How much this accident meant to Jurgis he (foreman) realized only by stages; for he (foreman) found that the harvester works were the sort of place to which philanthropists and reformers pointed with pride.

It had some thought for its employees; its workshops were big and roomy, it provided a restaurant where the workmen could buy good food at cost, it had even a reading room, and decent places where its girl-hands could rest; also the work was free from many of the elements of filth and repulsiveness that prevailed at the stockyards.

Day after day Jurgis discovered these things--things never expected nor dreamed of by him (foreman)--until this new place came to seem a kind of a heaven to him (foreman).

It was an enormous establishment, covering a hundred and sixty acres of ground, employing five thousand people, and turning out over three hundred thousand machines every year--a good part of all the harvesting and mowing machines used in the country.

Jurgis saw very little of it, of course--it was all specialized work, the same as at the stockyards; each one of the hundreds of parts of a mowing machine was made separately, and sometimes handled by hundreds of men.

Where Jurgis worked there was a machine which cut and stamped a certain piece of steel about two square inches in size; the pieces came tumbling out upon a tray, and all that human hands had to do was to pile them in regular rows, and change the trays at intervals.

This was done by a single boy, who stood with eyes and thought centered upon it, and fingers flying so fast that the sounds of the bits of steel striking upon each other was like the music of an express train as one hears it in a sleeping car at night.

This was

``piece-work,'' (the boy)
of course; and besides it was made certain that the boy did not idle, by setting the machine to match the highest possible speed of human hands.

Thirty thousand of these pieces he (boy) handled every day, nine or ten million every year--how many in a lifetime it rested with the gods to say.

Near by him (boy) men sat bending over whirling grindstones, putting the finishing touches to the steel knives of the reaper; picking them out of a basket with the right hand, pressing first one side and then the other against the stone and finally dropping them with the left hand into another basket.

In the end Jurgis got a chance through an accidental meeting with an old-time acquaintance of his (acquaintance) union days. One of these men told Jurgis that he (acquaintance) had sharpened three thousand pieces of steel a day for thirteen years.

In the next room were wonderful machines that ate up long steel rods by slow stages, cutting them off, seizing the pieces, stamping heads upon them, grinding them and polishing them, threading them, and finally dropping them into a basket, all ready to bolt the harvesters together.

In other places all these various parts were dipped into troughs of paint and hung up to dry, and then slid along on trolleys to a room where men streaked them with red and yellow, so that they might look cheerful in the harvest fields.

From yet another machine came tens of thousands of steel burs to fit upon these bolts. Jurgis's friend worked upstairs in the casting rooms, and his (friend) task was to make the molds of a certain part.

He (friend) shoveled black sand into an iron receptacle and pounded it tight and set it aside to harden; then it would be taken out, and molten iron poured into it.

You might see him (friend), along with dozens of others, toiling like one possessed by a whole community of demons; his (friend) arms working like the driving rods of an engine, his (friend) long, black hair flying wild, his (friend) eyes starting out, the sweat rolling in rivers down his (friend) face.

When he (friend) had shoveled the mold full of sand, and reached for the pounder to pound it with, it was after the manner of a canoeist running rapids and seizing a pole at sight of a submerged rock.

All day long this man would toil thus, his (man) whole being centered upon the purpose of making twenty-three instead of twenty-two and a half cents an hour; and then his (man) product would be reckoned up by the census taker, and jubilant captains of industry would boast of it in their banquet halls, telling how our workers are nearly twice as efficient as those of any other country.

If we are the greatest nation the sun ever shone upon, it would seem to be mainly because we have been able to goad our wage-earners to this pitch of frenzy; though there are a few other things that are great among us including our drink-bill, which is a billion and a quarter of dollars a year, and doubling itself every decade.

There was a machine which stamped out the iron plates, and then another which, with a mighty thud, mashed them to the shape of the sitting-down portion of the American farmer.

Then they were piled upon a truck, and it was Jurgis's task to wheel them to the room where the machines were

``assembled.

This man, too, was paid by the mold--or rather for perfect castings, nearly half his (man) work going for naught. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

This was child's play for him (man), and he (man) got a dollar and seventy-five cents a day for it

; on Saturday he (man) paid Aniele the seventy-five cents a week he (man) owed her (man) for the use of her (man) garret, and also redeemed his (man) overcoat, which Elzbieta had put in pawn when he (man) was in jail.

A man cannot go about in midwinter in Chicago with no overcoat and not pay for it, and Jurgis had to walk or ride five or six miles back and forth to his (man) work.

It so happened that half of this was in one direction and half in another, necessitating a change of cars; the law required that transfers be given at all intersecting points, but the railway corporation had gotten round this by arranging a pretense at separate ownership.

So whenever he (man) wished to ride, he (man) had to pay ten cents each way, or over ten per cent of his (man) income to this power, which had gotten its franchises long ago by buying up the city council, in the face of popular clamor amounting almost to a rebellion.

Tired as he (man) felt at night, and dark and bitter cold as it was in the morning, Jurgis generally chose to walk; at the hours other workmen were traveling, the streetcar monopoly saw fit to put on so few cars that there would be men hanging to every foot of the backs of them and often crouching upon the snow-covered roof.

Of course the doors could never be closed, and so the cars were as cold as outdoors; Jurgis, like many others, found it better to spend his (man) fare for a drink and a free lunch, to give him (man) strength to walk.

This last was a great blessing. These, however, were all slight matters to a man who had escaped from Durham's fertilizer mill.

but then the awful load of the rent and interest was off his (man) shoulders, and when Marija was well again they could start over and save.

In the shop where he (man) worked was a man, a Lithuanian like himself, whom the others spoke of in admiring whispers, because of the mighty feats he (man) was performing.

All day he (man) sat at a machine turning bolts; and then in the evening he (man) went to the public school to study English and learn to read.

In addition, because he (man) had a family of eight children to support and his (man) earnings were not enough, on Saturdays and Sundays he (man) served as a watchman; he (man) was required to press two buttons at opposite ends of a building every five minutes, and as the walk only took him (man) two minutes, he (man) had three minutes to study between each trip.

Jurgis felt jealous of this fellow; for that was the sort of thing he (fellow) himself had dreamed of, two or three years ago.

He (fellow) might do it even yet, if he (fellow) had a fair chance--he (fellow) might attract attention and become a skilled man or a boss, as some had done in this place.

Suppose that Marija could get a job in the big mill where they made binder twine--then they would move into this neighborhood, and he (man) would really have a chance.

With a hope like that, there was some use in living; to find a place where you were treated like a human being--by God!

Jurgis began to pick up heart again and to make plans. He (God) had lost his (God) house he (God) would show them how he (God) could appreciate it.

And then one afternoon, the ninth of his (God) work in the place, when he (God) went to get his (God) overcoat he (God) saw a group of men crowded before a placard on the door, and when he (God) went over and asked what it was, they told him (God) that beginning with the morrow his (God) department of the harvester works would be closed until further notice!

He (God) laughed to himself as he (God) thought how he (God) would hang on to this job! Chapter 21 That was the way they did it!

There was not half an hour's warning--the works were closed! It had happened that way before, said the men, and it would happen that way forever.

They had made all the harvesting machines that the world needed, and now they had to wait till some wore out!

It was nobody's fault--that was the way of it; and thousands of men and women were turned out in the dead of winter, to live upon their savings if they had any, and otherwise to die.

So many tens of thousands already in the city, homeless and begging for work, and now several thousand more added to them!

Jurgis walked home-with his (Jurgis) pittance of pay in his (Jurgis) pocket, heartbroken, overwhelmed. One more bandage had been torn from his (Jurgis) eyes, one more pitfall was revealed to him (Jurgis)!

Of what help was kindness and decency on the part of employers--when they could not keep a job for him (Jurgis), when there were more harvesting machines made than the world was able to buy!

What a hellish mockery it was, anyway, that a man should slave to make harvesting machines for the country, only to be turned out to starve for doing his (man) duty too well!

He (man) did not drink anything, because Elzbieta got his (man) money for safekeeping, and knew him (man) too well to be in the least frightened by his (man) angry demands.

He (man) stayed up in the garret however, and sulked--what was the use of a man's hunting a job when it was taken from him (man) before he (man) had time to learn the work?

But then their money was going again, and little Antanas was hungry, and crying with the bitter cold of the garret.

It took him (Antanas) two days to get over this heart-sickening disappointment. Also Madame Haupt, the midwife, was after him (Haupt) for some money.

For another ten days he (Haupt) roamed the streets and alleys of the huge city, sick and hungry, begging for any work.

He (Haupt) tried in stores and offices, in restaurants and hotels, along the docks and in the railroad yards, in warehouses and mills and factories where they made products that went to every corner of the world.

There were often one or two chances--but there were always a hundred men for every chance, and his (Haupt) turn would not come.

At night he (Haupt) crept into sheds and cellars and doorways--until there came a spell of belated winter weather, with a raging gale, and the thermometer five degrees below zero at sundown and falling all night.

Then Jurgis fought like a wild beast to get into the big Harrison Street police station, and slept down in a corridor, crowded with two other men upon a single step.

He (Harrison) had to fight often in these days to fight for a place near the factory gates, and now and again with gangs on the street.

He (Harrison) found, for instance, that the business of carrying satchels for railroad passengers was a pre-empted one--whenever he (Harrison) essayed it, eight or ten men and boys would fall upon him (Harrison) and force him (Harrison) to run for his (Harrison) life.

So he (Harrison) went out once more. They always had the policeman

``squared,'' (the policeman)
and so there was no use in expecting protection.

That Jurgis did not starve to death was due solely to the pittance the children brought him (policeman). And even this was never certain.

For one thing the cold was almost more than the children could bear; and then they, too, were in perpetual peril from rivals who plundered and beat them.

The law was against them, too--little Vilimas, who was really eleven, but did not look to be eight, was stopped on the streets by a severe old lady in spectacles, who told him (policeman) that he (policeman) was too young to be working and that if he (policeman) did not stop selling papers she (lady) would send a truant officer after him (policeman).

Also one night a strange man caught little Kotrina by the arm and tried to persuade her (lady) into a dark cellar-way, an experience which filled her (lady) with such terror that she (lady) was hardly to be kept at work.

At last, on a Sunday, as there was no use looking for work, Jurgis went home by stealing rides on the cars.

He (man) found that they had been waiting for him (man) for three days--there was a chance of a job for him (man). It was quite a story.

Juozapas had only one leg, having been run over by a wagon when a little child, but he (man) had got himself a broomstick, which he (man) put under his (man) arm for a crutch.

He (man) had fallen in with some other children and found the way to Mike Scully's dump, which lay three or four blocks away.

To this place there came every day many hundreds of wagon-loads of garbage and trash from the lake front, where the rich people lived; and in the heaps the children raked for food--there were hunks of bread and potato peelings and apple cores and meat bones, all of it half frozen and quite unspoiled.

Little Juozapas gorged himself, and came home with a newspaper full, which he (Scully) was feeding to Antanas when his (Scully) mother came in.

Little Juozapas, who was near crazy with hunger these days, had gone out on the street to beg for himself. Elzbieta was horrified, for she (Elzbieta) did not believe that the food out of the dumps was fit to eat.

The next day, however, when no harm came of it and Juozapas began to cry with hunger, she (Elzbieta) gave in and said that he (Scully) might go again.

And that afternoon he (Scully) came home with a story of how while he (Scully) had been digging away with a stick, a lady upon the street had called him (Scully).

A real fine lady, the little boy explained, a beautiful lady; and she (lady) wanted to know all about him (boy), and whether he (boy) got the garbage for chickens, and why he (boy) walked with a broomstick, and why Ona had died, and how Jurgis had come to go to jail, and what was the matter with Marija, and everything.

In the end she (Ona) had asked where he (boy) lived, and said that she (Ona) was coming to see him (boy), and bring him (boy) a new crutch to walk with.

She (Ona) really came, the very next morning, and climbed the ladder to the garret, and stood and stared about her (Ona), turning pale at the sight of the blood stains on the floor where Ona had died.

She (Ona) had on a hat with a bird upon it, Juozapas added, and a long fur snake around her (Ona) neck. She (Ona) was a

``settlement worker,'' (She)
she (Ona) explained to Elzbieta--she (Ona) lived around on Ashland Avenue.

Elzbieta knew the place, over a feed store; somebody had wanted her (Elzbieta) to go there, but she (Elzbieta) had not cared to, for she (Elzbieta) thought that it must have something to do with religion, and the priest did not like her (Elzbieta) to have anything to do with strange religions.

They were rich people who came to live there to find out about the poor people; but what good they expected it would do them to know, one could not imagine.

So spoke Elzbieta, naively, and the young lady laughed and was rather at a loss for an answer--she (Elzbieta) stood and gazed about her (Elzbieta), and thought of a cynical remark that had been made to her (Elzbieta), that she (Elzbieta) was standing upon the brink of the pit of hell and throwing in snowballs to lower the temperature.

Elzbieta was glad to have somebody to listen, and she (Elzbieta) told all their woes--what had happened to Ona, and the jail, and the loss of their home, and Marija's accident, and how Ona had died, and how Jurgis could get no work.

As she (Ona) listened the pretty young lady's eyes filled with tears, and in the midst of it she (Ona) burst into weeping and hid her (Ona) face on Elzbieta's shoulder, quite regardless of the fact that the woman had on a dirty old wrapper and that the garret was full of fleas.

Poor Elzbieta was ashamed of herself for having told so woeful a tale, and the other had to beg and plead with her (Elzbieta) to get her (Elzbieta) to go on.

The end of it was that the young lady sent them a basket of things to eat, and left a letter that Jurgis was to take to a gentleman who was superintendent in one of the mills of the great steelworks in South Chicago.

He (superintendent) will get Jurgis something to do,'' the young lady had said, and added, smiling through her (lady) tears--

``If he (superintendent) doesn't, he (superintendent) will never marry me.

The steel-works were fifteen miles away, and as usual it was so contrived that one had to pay two fares to get there.

Far and wide the sky was flaring with the red glare that leaped from rows of towering chimneys--for it was pitch dark when Jurgis arrived.

The vast works, a city in themselves, were surrounded by a stockade; and already a full hundred men were waiting at the gate where new hands were taken on.

Soon after daybreak whistles began to blow, and then suddenly thousands of men appeared, streaming from saloons and boardinghouses across the way, leaping from trolley cars that passed--it seemed as if they rose out of the ground, in the dim gray light.

A river of them poured in through the gate--and then gradually ebbed away again, until there were only a few late ones running, and the watchman pacing up and down, and the hungry strangers stamping and shivering.

The gatekeeper was surly, and put him (gatekeeper) through a catechism, but he (gatekeeper) insisted that he (gatekeeper) knew nothing, and as he (gatekeeper) had taken the precaution to seal his (gatekeeper) letter, there was nothing for the gatekeeper to do but send it to the person to whom it was addressed.

A messenger came back to say that Jurgis should wait, and so he (gatekeeper) came inside of the gate, perhaps not sorry enough that there were others less fortunate watching him (gatekeeper) with greedy eyes.

'' (the lady)

'' Jurgis presented his (gatekeeper) precious letter. The great mills were getting under way--one could hear a vast stirring, a rolling and rumbling and hammering.

Little by little the scene grew plain: towering, black buildings here and there, long rows of shops and sheds, little railways branching everywhere, bare gray cinders underfoot and oceans of billowing black smoke above.

On one side of the grounds ran a railroad with a dozen tracks, and on the other side lay the lake, where steamers came to load.

Jurgis had time enough to stare and speculate, for it was two hours before he (dozen) was summoned. He (dozen) went into the office building, where a company timekeeper interviewed him (dozen).

The superintendent was busy, he (superintendent) said, but he (superintendent) -LRB-the timekeeper-RRB- would try to find Jurgis a job. He (superintendent) had never worked in a steel mill before?

But he (superintendent) was ready for anything? Well, then, they would go and see. So they began a tour, among sights that made Jurgis stare amazed.

He (superintendent) wondered if ever he (superintendent) could get used to working in a place like this, where the air shook with deafening thunder, and whistles shrieked warnings on all sides of him (superintendent) at once; where miniature steam engines came rushing upon him (superintendent), and sizzling, quivering, white-hot masses of metal sped past him (superintendent), and explosions of fire and flaming sparks dazzled him (superintendent) and scorched his (superintendent) face.

The men in these mills were all black with soot, and hollow-eyed and gaunt; they worked with fierce intensity, rushing here and there, and never lifting their eyes from their tasks.

Jurgis clung to his (superintendent) guide like a scared child to its nurse, and while the latter hailed one foreman after another to ask if they could use another unskilled man, he (man) stared about him (man) and marveled.

He (man) was taken to the Bessemer furnace, where they made billets of steel--a dome-like building, the size of a big theater.

Jurgis stood where the balcony of the theater would have been, and opposite, by the stage, he (man) saw three giant caldrons, big enough for all the devils of hell to brew their broth in, full of something white and blinding, bubbling and splashing, roaring as if volcanoes were blowing through it--one had to shout to be heard in the place.

Liquid fire would leap from these caldrons and scatter like bombs below--and men were working there, seeming careless, so that Jurgis caught his (man) breath with fright.

Then a whistle would toot, and across the curtain of the theater would come a little engine with a carload of something to be dumped into one of the receptacles; and then another whistle would toot, down by the stage, and another train would back up--and suddenly, without an instant's warning, one of the giant kettles began to tilt and topple, flinging out a jet of hissing, roaring flame.

Jurgis shrank back appalled, for he (man) thought it was an accident; there fell a pillar of white flame, dazzling as the sun, swishing like a huge tree falling in the forest.

A torrent of sparks swept all the way across the building, overwhelming everything, hiding it from sight; and then Jurgis looked through the fingers of his (man) hands, and saw pouring out of the caldron a cascade of living, leaping fire, white with a whiteness not of earth, scorching the eyeballs.

Out of regions of wonder it streamed, the very river of life; and the soul leaped up at the sight of it, fled back upon it, swift and resistless, back into far-off lands, where beauty and terror dwell.

Then the great caldron tilted back again, empty, and Jurgis saw to his (man) relief that no one was hurt, and turned and followed his (man) guide out into the sunlight.

They went through the blast furnaces, through rolling mills where bars of steel were tossed about and chopped like bits of cheese.

All around and above giant machine arms were flying, giant wheels were turning, great hammers crashing; traveling cranes creaked and groaned overhead, reaching down iron hands and seizing iron prey--it was like standing in the center of the earth, where the machinery of time was revolving.

By and by they came to the place where steel rails were made; and Jurgis heard a toot behind him (they), and jumped out of the way of a car with a white-hot ingot upon it, the size of a man's body.

There was a sudden crash and the car came to a halt, and the ingot toppled out upon a moving platform, where steel fingers and arms seized hold of it, punching it and prodding it into place, and hurrying it into the grip of huge rollers.

Then it came out upon the other side, and there were more crashings and clatterings, and over it was flopped, like a pancake on a gridiron, and seized again and rushed back at you through another squeezer.

Incandescent rainbows shone above it, blue, red, and golden lights played about it; but the stream itself was white, ineffable. So amid deafening uproar it clattered to and fro, growing thinner and flatter and longer.

The ingot seemed almost a living thing; it did not want to run this mad course, but it was in the grip of fate, it was tumbled on, screeching and clanking and shivering in protest.

By and by it was long and thin, a great red snake escaped from purgatory; and then, as it slid through the rollers, you would have sworn that it was alive--it writhed and squirmed, and wriggles and shudders passed out through its tail, all but flinging it off by their violence.

There was no rest for it until it was cold and black--and then it needed only to be cut and straightened to be ready for a railroad.

It was at the end of this rail's progress that Jurgis got his (It) chance. They had to be moved by men with crowbars, and the boss here could use another man.

It took him (boss) two hours to get to this place every day and cost him (boss) a dollar and twenty cents a week.

As this was out of the question, he (boss) wrapped his (boss) bedding in a bundle and took it with him (boss), and one of his (boss) fellow workingmen introduced him (boss) to a Polish lodging-house, where he (boss) might have the privilege of sleeping upon the floor for ten cents a night.

He (boss) got his (boss) meals at free-lunch counters, and every Saturday night he (boss) went home--bedding and all--and took the greater part of his (boss) money to the family.

Elzbieta was sorry for this arrangement, for she (Elzbieta) feared that it would get him (boss) into the habit of living without them, and once a week was not very often for him (boss) to see his (boss) baby; but there was no other way of arranging it.

There was no chance for a woman at the steelworks, and Marija was now ready for work again, and lured on from day to day by the hope of finding it at the yards.

So he (boss) took off his (boss) coat and set to work on the spot. In a week Jurgis got over his (boss) sense of helplessness and bewilderment in the rail mill.

He (boss) learned to find his (boss) way about and to take all the miracles and terrors for granted, to work without hearing the rumbling and crashing.

From blind fear he (boss) went to the other extreme; he (boss) became reckless and indifferent, like all the rest of the men, who took but little thought of themselves in the ardor of their work.

It was wonderful, when one came to think of it, that these men should have taken an interest in the work they did--they had no share in it--they were paid by the hour, and paid no more for being interested.

and still they would hurry to their task by dangerous short cuts, would use methods that were quicker and more effective in spite of the fact that they were also risky.

His (men) fourth day at his (men) work Jurgis saw a man stumble while running in front of a car, and have his (men) foot mashed off, and before he (men) had been there three weeks he (men) was witness of a yet more dreadful accident.

Also they knew that if they were hurt they would be flung aside and forgotten-- There was a row of brick furnaces, shining white through every crack with the molten steel inside.

Some of these were bulging dangerously, yet men worked before them, wearing blue glasses when they opened and shut the doors.

As they lay screaming and rolling upon the ground in agony, Jurgis rushed to help them, and as a result he (men) lost a good part of the skin from the inside of one of his (men) hands.

The company doctor bandaged it up, but he (men) got no other thanks from any one, and was laid up for eight working days without any pay.

Most fortunately, at this juncture, Elzbieta got the long-awaited chance to go at five o'clock in the morning and help scrub the office floors of one of the packers.

Jurgis came home and covered himself with blankets to keep warm, and divided his (men) time between sleeping and playing with little Antanas.

Juozapas was away raking in the dump a good part of the time, and Elzbieta and Marija were hunting for more work.

One morning as Jurgis was passing, a furnace blew out, spraying two men with a shower of liquid fire. Antanas was now over a year and a half old, and was a perfect talking machine.

He (Antanas) learned so fast that every week when Jurgis came home it seemed to him (Antanas) as if he (Antanas) had a new child.

He (Antanas) would sit down and listen and stare at him (Antanas), and give vent to delighted exclamations--

``Palauk! Muma! Tu mano szirdele! '' (him)

The little fellow was now really the one delight that Jurgis had in the world--his (fellow) one hope, his (fellow) one victory. Thank God, Antanas was a boy!

Nothing had hurt him (Antanas), and nothing could hurt him (Antanas); he (Antanas) had come through all the suffering and deprivation unscathed--only shriller-voiced and more determined in his (Antanas) grip upon life.

He (Antanas) was a terrible child to manage, was Antanas, but his (Antanas) father did not mind that--he (Antanas) would watch him (Antanas) and smile to himself with satisfaction.

And he (Antanas) was as tough as a pine knot, and with the appetite of a wolf. The more of a fighter he (fighter) was the better--he (fighter) would need to fight before he (fighter) got through.

Jurgis had got the habit of buying the Sunday paper whenever he (fighter) had the money; a most wonderful paper could be had for only five cents, a whole armful, with all the news of the world set forth in big headlines, that Jurgis could spell out slowly, with the children to help him (fighter) at the long words.

There was battle and murder and sudden death--it was marvelous how they ever heard about so many entertaining and thrilling happenings; the stories must be all true, for surely no man could have made such things up, and besides, there were pictures of them all, as real as life.

One of these papers was as good as a circus, and nearly as good as a spree--certainly a most wonderful treat for a workingman, who was tired out and stupefied, and had never had any education, and whose work was one dull, sordid grind, day after day, and year after year, with never a sight of a green field nor an hour's entertainment, nor anything but liquor to stimulate his (them) imagination.

Among other things, these papers had pages full of comical pictures, and these were the main joy in life to little Antanas.

He (Antanas) treasured them up, and would drag them out and make his (Antanas) father tell him (Antanas) about them; there were all sorts of animals among them, and Antanas could tell the names of all of them, lying upon the floor for hours and pointing them out with his (Antanas) chubby little fingers.

Whenever the story was plain enough for Jurgis to make out, Antanas would have it repeated to him (Antanas), and then he (Antanas) would remember it, prattling funny little sentences and mixing it up with other stories in an irresistible fashion.

Also his (Antanas) quaint pronunciation of words was such a delight--and the phrases he (Antanas) would pick up and remember, the most outlandish and impossible things!

The first time that the little rascal burst out with

``God damn,'' (father)
his (God) father nearly rolled off the chair with glee; but in the end he (God) was sorry for this, for Antanas was soon
``God-damning'' (Antanas/Dede Antanas)
everything and everybody.

And then, when he (Antanas) was able to use his (Antanas) hands, Jurgis took his (Antanas) bedding again and went back to his (Antanas) task of shifting rails.

It was now April, and the snow had given place to cold rains, and the unpaved street in front of Aniele's house was turned into a canal.

Jurgis would have to wade through it to get home, and if it was late he (Antanas) might easily get stuck to his (Antanas) waist in the mire.

Marija had now gotten a place as beef-trimmer in one of the smaller packing plants; and he (Antanas) told himself that he (Antanas) had learned his (Antanas) lesson now, and would meet with no more accidents--so that at last there was prospect of an end to their long agony.

They could save money again, and when another winter came they would have a comfortable place; and the children would be off the streets and in school again, and they might set to work to nurse back into life their habits of decency and kindness.

But he (Antanas) did not mind this much--it was a promise that summer was coming. So once more Jurgis began to make plans and dream dreams.

And then one Saturday night he (Antanas) jumped off the car and started home, with the sun shining low under the edge of a bank of clouds that had been pouring floods of water into the mud-soaked street.

There was a rainbow in the sky, and another in his (Antanas) breast--for he (Antanas) had thirty-six hours' rest before him (Antanas), and a chance to see his (Antanas) family.

Then suddenly he (Antanas) came in sight of the house, and noticed that there was a crowd before the door. He (Antanas) ran up the steps and pushed his (Antanas) way in, and saw Aniele's kitchen crowded with excited women.

It reminded him (Antanas) so vividly of the time when he (Antanas) had come home from jail and found Ona dying, that his (Antanas) heart almost stood still.

'' What's the matter? '' he (Antanas) cried. A dead silence had fallen in the room, and he (Antanas) saw that every one was staring at him (Antanas).

'' What's the matter? '' he (Antanas) exclaimed again. And then, up in the garret, he (Antanas) heard sounds of wailing, in Marija's voice.

He (Antanas) started for the ladder--and Aniele seized him (Antanas) by the arm. '' No, no! '' she (Ona) exclaimed. '' Don't go up there!''

'' What is it? '' he (Antanas) shouted. And the old woman answered him (Antanas) weakly:

``It's Antanas. He (Antanas)'s dead. He (Antanas) was drowned out in the street!'' (him)

He (Antanas) turned deadly pale, but he (Antanas) caught himself, and for half a minute stood in the middle of the room, clenching his (Antanas) hands tightly and setting his (Antanas) teeth.

Chapter 22 Jurgis took the news in a peculiar way. Then he (Antanas) pushed Aniele aside and strode into the next room and climbed the ladder.

In the corner was a blanket, with a form half showing beneath it; and beside it lay Elzbieta, whether crying or in a faint, Jurgis could not tell.

Marija was pacing the room, screaming and wringing her (Elzbieta) hands. He (Antanas) clenched his (Antanas) hands tighter yet, and his (Antanas) voice was hard as he (Antanas) spoke.

'' How did it happen? '' he (Antanas) asked. Marija scarcely heard him (Antanas) in her (Elzbieta) agony. He (Antanas) repeated the question, louder and yet more harshly.

The sidewalk in front of the house was a platform made of half-rotten boards, about five feet above the level of the sunken street.

'' He (Antanas) fell off the sidewalk! '' she (Elzbieta) wailed. '' How did he (Antanas) come to be there? '' he (Antanas) demanded. ''

He (Antanas) went--he (Antanas) went out to play,'' Marija sobbed, her (Elzbieta) voice choking her (Elzbieta). '' We couldn't make him (Antanas) stay in. He (Antanas) must have got caught in the mud!''

``Are you sure that he (Antanas) is dead?'' (he)
he (Antanas) demanded. '' Ai! ai!'' she (Elzbieta) wailed. '' Yes; we had the doctor. ''

He (doctor) took one glance more at the blanket with the little form beneath it, and then turned suddenly to the ladder and climbed down again.

Then Jurgis stood a few seconds, wavering. He (doctor) did not shed a tear. A silence fell once more in the room as he (doctor) entered.

When his (doctor) wife had died, Jurgis made for the nearest saloon, but he (doctor) did not do that now, though he (doctor) had his (doctor) week's wages in his (doctor) pocket.

He (doctor) went straight to the door, passed out, and started down the street. He (doctor) walked and walked, seeing nothing, splashing through mud and water.

Later on he (doctor) sat down upon a step and hid his (doctor) face in his (doctor) hands and for half an hour or so he (doctor) did not move.

It was about sunset, and he (doctor) went on and on until it was dark, when he (doctor) was stopped by a railroad crossing.

Now and then he (doctor) would whisper to himself:

``Dead! Dead!'' (he)
Finally, he (doctor) got up and walked on again. The gates were down, and a long train of freight cars was thundering by.

He (doctor) stood and watched it; and all at once a wild impulse seized him (doctor), a thought that had been lurking within him (doctor), unspoken, unrecognized, leaped into sudden life.

He (doctor) started down the track, and when he (doctor) was past the gate-keeper's shanty he (doctor) sprang forward and swung himself on to one of the cars.

By and by the train stopped again, and Jurgis sprang down and ran under the car, and hid himself upon the truck.

Here he (doctor) sat, and when the train started again, he (doctor) fought a battle with his (doctor) soul. He (doctor) gripped his (doctor) hands and set his (doctor) teeth together--he (doctor) had not wept, and he (doctor) would not--not a tear!

It was past and over, and he (doctor) was done with it--he (doctor) would fling it off his (doctor) shoulders, be free of it, the whole business, that night.

And every time that a thought of it assailed him (doctor)--a tender memory, a trace of a tear--he (doctor) rose up, cursing with rage, and pounded it down.

It should go like a black, hateful nightmare, and in the morning he (doctor) would be a new man. He (doctor) was fighting for his (doctor) life; he (doctor) gnashed his (doctor) teeth together in his (doctor) desperation.

He (doctor) had wasted his (doctor) life, he (doctor) had wrecked himself, with his (doctor) accursed weakness; and now he (doctor) was done with it--he (doctor) would tear it out of him (doctor), root and branch!

There should be no more tears and no more tenderness; he (doctor) had had enough of them--they had sold him (doctor) into slavery!

He (doctor) had been a fool, a fool! Now he (doctor) was going to be free, to tear off his (doctor) shackles, to rise up and fight.

He (doctor) was glad that the end had come--it had to come some time, and it was just as well now. This was no world for women and children, and the sooner they got out of it the better for them.

Whatever Antanas might suffer where he (Antanas) was, he (Antanas) could suffer no more than he (Antanas) would have had he (Antanas) stayed upon earth.

And meantime his (Antanas) father had thought the last thought about him (Antanas) that he (Antanas) meant to; he (Antanas) was going to think of himself, he (Antanas) was going to fight for himself, against the world that had baffled him (Antanas) and tortured him (Antanas)!

So he (Antanas) went on, tearing up all the flowers from the garden of his (Antanas) soul, and setting his (Antanas) heel upon them.

The train thundered deafeningly, and a storm of dust blew in his (Antanas) face; but though it stopped now and then through the night, he (Antanas) clung where he (Antanas) was--he (Antanas) would cling there until he (Antanas) was driven off, for every mile that he (Antanas) got from Packingtown meant another load from his (Antanas) mind.

Whenever the cars stopped a warm breeze blew upon him (Antanas), a breeze laden with the perfume of fresh fields, of honeysuckle and clover.

He (Antanas) snuffed it, and it made his (Antanas) heart beat wildly--he (Antanas) was out in the country again! He (Antanas) was going to live in the country!

When the dawn came he (Antanas) was peering out with hungry eyes, getting glimpses of meadows and woods and rivers. At last he (Antanas) could stand it no longer, and when the train stopped again he (Antanas) crawled out.

Upon the top of the car was a brakeman, who shook his (Antanas) fist and swore; Jurgis waved his (Antanas) hand derisively, and started across the country.

Only think that he (Antanas) had been a countryman all his (Antanas) life; and for three long years he (Antanas) had never seen a country sight nor heard a country sound!

Excepting for that one walk when he (Antanas) left jail, when he (Antanas) was too much worried to notice anything, and for a few times that he (Antanas) had rested in the city parks in the winter time when he (Antanas) was out of work, he (Antanas) had literally never seen a tree!

And now he (Antanas) felt like a bird lifted up and borne away upon a gale; he (Antanas) stopped and stared at each new sight of wonder--at a herd of cows, and a meadow full of daisies, at hedgerows set thick with June roses, at little birds singing in the trees.

Then he (Antanas) came to a farm-house, and after getting himself a stick for protection, he (Antanas) approached it. The farmer was greasing a wagon in front of the barn, and Jurgis went to him (Antanas).

'' I would like to get some breakfast, please,'' he (Antanas) said. '' Do you want to work?'' said the farmer. ''

No,'' said Jurgis. '' I don't. ''

``Then you can't get anything here,'' (I)
snapped the other. '' I meant to pay for it,'' said Jurgis.

'' Oh,'' said the farmer; and then added sarcastically,

``We don't serve breakfast after 7 A.M. '' (the farmer)
``I am very hungry,'' (the farmer)
said Jurgis gravely;
``I would like to buy some food.'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

The

``woman'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
was more tractable, and for a dime Jurgis secured two thick sandwiches and a piece of pie and two apples.

``Ask the woman,'' (the farmer)
said the farmer, nodding over his (farmer) shoulder. He (farmer) walked off eating the pie, as the least convenient thing to carry.

In a few minutes he (farmer) came to a stream, and he (farmer) climbed a fence and walked down the bank, along a woodland path.

Then he (farmer) lay for hours, just gazing and drinking in joy; until at last he (farmer) felt sleepy, and lay down in the shade of a bush.

By and by he (farmer) found a comfortable spot, and there he (farmer) devoured his (farmer) meal, slaking his (farmer) thirst at the stream. When he (farmer) awoke the sun was shining hot in his (farmer) face.

He (farmer) sat up and stretched his (farmer) arms, and then gazed at the water sliding by. There was a deep pool, sheltered and silent, below him (farmer), and a sudden wonderful idea rushed upon him (farmer).

He (farmer) might have a bath! The water was free, and he (farmer) might get into it--all the way into it! It would be the first time that he (farmer) had been all the way into the water since he (farmer) left Lithuania!

But later on, what with sickness and cold and hunger and discouragement, and the filthiness of his (farmer) work, and the vermin in his (farmer) home, he (farmer) had given up washing in winter, and in summer only as much of him (farmer) as would go into a basin.

When Jurgis had first come to the stockyards he (farmer) had been as clean as any workingman could well be. He (farmer) had had a shower bath in jail, but nothing since--and now he (farmer) would have a swim!

Afterward he (farmer) sat down in the water near the bank, and proceeded to scrub himself--soberly and methodically, scouring every inch of him (farmer) with sand.

The water was warm, and he (farmer) splashed about like a very boy in his (farmer) glee. While he (farmer) was doing it he (farmer) would do it thoroughly, and see how it felt to be clean.

He (farmer) even scrubbed his (farmer) head with sand, and combed what the men called

``crumbs'' (the men)
out of his (farmer) long, black hair, holding his (farmer) head under water as long as he (farmer) could, to see if he (farmer) could not kill them all.

Then, seeing that the sun was still hot, he (farmer) took his (farmer) clothes from the bank and proceeded to wash them, piece by piece; as the dirt and grease went floating off downstream he (farmer) grunted with satisfaction and soused the clothes again, venturing even to dream that he (farmer) might get rid of the fertilizer.

He (farmer) hung them all up, and while they were drying he (farmer) lay down in the sun and had another long sleep.

They were hot and stiff as boards on top, and a little damp on the underside, when he (farmer) awakened; but being hungry, he (farmer) put them on and set out again.

He (farmer) had no knife, but with some labor he (farmer) broke himself a good stout club, and, armed with this, he (farmer) marched down the road again.

Before long he (farmer) came to a big farmhouse, and turned up the lane that led to it. It was just supper-time, and the farmer was washing his (farmer) hands at the kitchen door.

'' Please, sir,'' said Jurgis,

``can I have something to eat? I can pay. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
To which the farmer responded promptly,
``We don't feed tramps here.

Jurgis went without a word; but as he (farmer) passed round the barn he (farmer) came to a freshly ploughed and harrowed field, in which the farmer had set out some young peach trees; and as he (farmer) walked he (farmer) jerked up a row of them by the roots, more than a hundred trees in all, before he (farmer) reached the end of the field.

That was his (farmer) answer, and it showed his (farmer) mood; from now on he (farmer) was fighting, and the man who hit him (farmer) would get all that he (farmer) gave, every time.

Beyond the orchard Jurgis struck through a patch of woods, and then a field of winter grain, and came at last to another road.

Before long he (farmer) saw another farmhouse, and, as it was beginning to cloud over a little, he (farmer) asked here for shelter as well as food.

Get out!'' (the farmer)

Seeing the farmer eying him (farmer) dubiously, he (farmer) added,
``I'll be glad to sleep in the barn. '' (he)
'' Well, I dunno,'' said the other.

'' Do you smoke?'' '' Sometimes,'' said Jurgis,

``but I'll do it out of doors. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
When the man had assented, he (man) inquired,
``How much will it cost me?

I haven't very much money. '' (he)

``I reckon about twenty cents for supper,'' (the farmer)
replied the farmer. '' I won't charge ye for the barn.

It was a bountiful meal--there were baked beans and mashed potatoes and asparagus chopped and stewed, and a dish of strawberries, and great, thick slices of bread, and a pitcher of milk.

Jurgis had not had such a feast since his (pitcher) wedding day, and he (pitcher) made a mighty effort to put in his (pitcher) twenty cents' worth.

They were all of them too hungry to talk; but afterward they sat upon the steps and smoked, and the farmer questioned his (farmer) guest.

When Jurgis had explained that he (farmer) was a workingman from Chicago, and that he (farmer) did not know just whither he (farmer) was bound, the other said,

``Why don't you stay here and work for me?'' (he)

'' So Jurgis went in, and sat down at the table with the farmer's wife and half a dozen children. ''

I'm not looking for work just now,'' Jurgis answered. '' I'll pay ye good,'' said the other, eying his (farmer) big form--

``a dollar a day and board ye.

Help's terrible scarce round here.'' (I)

``Is that winter as well as summer?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis demanded quickly. '' N--no,'' said the farmer;
``I couldn't keep ye after November--I ain't got a big enough place for that.

'' (the farmer)

``I see,'' (unknown)
said the other,
``that's what I thought. When you get through working your horses this fall, will you turn them out in the snow?

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

-LRB-Jurgis was beginning to think for himself nowadays.-RRB- '' It ain't quite the same,'' the farmer answered, seeing the point.

There ought to be work a strong fellow like you can find to do, in the cities, or some place, in the winter time.''

when they have to beg or steal to live, then people ask 'em why they don't go into the country, where help is scarce.

'' '' Yes,'' said Jurgis,

``that's what they all think; and so they crowd into the cities, and '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
The farmer meditated awhile.

'' How about when your money's gone? '' he (farmer) inquired, finally. '' You'll have to, then, won't you?'' '' Wait till she ('em)'s gone,'' said Jurgis;

``then I'll see.

He (farmer) had a long sleep in the barn and then a big breakfast of coffee and bread and oatmeal and stewed cherries, for which the man charged him (man) only fifteen cents, perhaps having been influenced by his (man) arguments.

It was seldom he (man) got as fair treatment as from this last farmer, and so as time went on he (farmer) learned to shun the houses and to prefer sleeping in the fields.

When it rained he (farmer) would find a deserted building, if he (farmer) could, and if not, he (farmer) would wait until after dark and then, with his (farmer) stick ready, begin a stealthy approach upon a barn.

Generally he (farmer) could get in before the dog got scent of him (farmer), and then he (farmer) would hide in the hay and be safe until morning; if not, and the dog attacked him (farmer), he (farmer) would rise up and make a retreat in battle order.

Jurgis was not the mighty man he (man) had once been, but his (man) arms were still good, and there were few farm dogs he (man) needed to hit more than once.

Before long there came raspberries, and then blackberries, to help him (man) save his (man) money; and there were apples in the orchards and potatoes in the ground--he (man) learned to note the places and fill his (man) pockets after dark.

Twice he (man) even managed to capture a chicken, and had a feast, once in a deserted barn and the other time in a lonely spot alongside of a stream.

When all of these things failed him (man) he (man) used his (man) money carefully, but without worry--for he (man) saw that he (man) could earn more whenever he (man) chose.

Half an hour's chopping wood in his (man) lively fashion was enough to bring him (man) a meal, and when the farmer had seen him (farmer) working he (farmer) would sometimes try to bribe him (farmer) to stay.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Then Jurgis bade farewell, and went on his (farmer) way. Such was the beginning of his (farmer) life as a tramp. But Jurgis was not staying.

The old wanderlust had got into his (farmer) blood, the joy of the unbound life, the joy of seeking, of hoping without limit.

There were mishaps and discomforts--but at least there was always something new; and only think what it meant to a man who for years had been penned up in one place, seeing nothing but one dreary prospect of shanties and factories, to be suddenly set loose beneath the open sky, to behold new landscapes, new places, and new people every hour!

To a man whose whole life had consisted of doing one certain thing all day, until he (man) was so exhausted that he (man) could only lie down and sleep until the next day--and to be now his (man) own master, working as he (man) pleased and when he (man) pleased, and facing a new adventure every hour!

Then, too, his (man) health came back to him (man), all his (man) lost youthful vigor, his (man) joy and power that he (man) had mourned and forgotten!

It came with a sudden rush, bewildering him (man), startling him (man); it was as if his (man) dead childhood had come back to him (man), laughing and calling!

What with plenty to eat and fresh air and exercise that was taken as it pleased him (man), he (man) would waken from his (man) sleep and start off not knowing what to do with his (man) energy, stretching his (man) arms, laughing, singing old songs of home that came back to him (man).

Now and then, of course, he (man) could not help but think of little Antanas, whom he (Antanas) should never see again, whose little voice he (Antanas) should never hear; and then he (Antanas) would have to battle with himself.

Sometimes at night he (Antanas) would waken dreaming of Ona, and stretch out his (Antanas) arms to her (Ona), and wet the ground with his (Antanas) tears.

He (Antanas) was a free man now, a buccaneer. But in the morning he (Antanas) would get up and shake himself, and stride away again to battle with the world.

He (Antanas) never asked where he (Antanas) was nor where he (Antanas) was going; the country was big enough, he (Antanas) knew, and there was no danger of his (Antanas) coming to the end of it.

And of course he (Antanas) could always have company for the asking--everywhere he (Antanas) went there were men living just as he (Antanas) lived, and whom he (Antanas) was welcome to join.

He (Antanas) was a stranger at the business, but they were not clannish, and they taught him (Antanas) all their tricks--what towns and villages it was best to keep away from, and how to read the secret signs upon the fences, and when to beg and when to steal, and just how to do both.

They laughed at his (Antanas) ideas of paying for anything with money or with work--for they got all they wanted without either.

Now and then Jurgis camped out with a gang of them in some woodland haunt, and foraged with them in the neighborhood at night.

And then among them some one would

``take a shine'' (him)
to him (Antanas), and they would go off together and travel for a week, exchanging reminiscences.

But the vast majority of them had been workingmen, had fought the long fight as Jurgis had, and found that it was a losing fight, and given up.

Later on he (Antanas) encountered yet another sort of men, those from whose ranks the tramps were recruited, men who were homeless and wandering, but still seeking work--seeking it in the harvest fields.

Of these there was an army, the huge surplus labor army of society; called into being under the stern system of nature, to do the casual work of the world, the tasks which were transient and irregular, and yet which had to be done.

They did not know that they were such, of course; they only knew that they sought the job, and that the job was fleeting.

In the early summer they would be in Texas, and as the crops were ready they would follow north with the season, ending with the fall in Manitoba.

Then they would seek out the big lumber camps, where there was winter work; or failing in this, would drift to the cities, and live upon what they had managed to save, with the help of such transient work as was there the loading and unloading of steamships and drays, the digging of ditches and the shoveling of snow.

If there were more of them on hand than chanced to be needed, the weaker ones died off of cold and hunger, again according to the stern system of nature.

Of these professional tramps a great many had, of course, been shiftless and vicious all their lives. It was in the latter part of July, when Jurgis was in Missouri, that he (ones) came upon the harvest work.

Here were crops that men had worked for three or four months to prepare, and of which they would lose nearly all unless they could find others to help them for a week or two.

--agencies were set up and all the cities were drained of men, even college boys were brought by the carload, and hordes of frantic farmers would hold up trains and carry off wagon-loads of men by main force.

Not that they did not pay them well--any man could get two dollars a day and his (man) board, and the best men could get two dollars and a half or three.

The harvest-fever was in the very air, and no man with any spirit in him (man) could be in that region and not catch it.

So all over the land there was a cry for labor Jurgis joined a gang and worked from dawn till dark, eighteen hours a day, for two weeks without a break.
