Then he (man) had a sum of money that would have been a fortune to him (man) in the old days of misery--but what could he (man) do with it now?

To be sure he (man) might have put it in a bank, and, if he (man) were fortunate, get it back again when he (man) wanted it.

But Jurgis was now a homeless man, wandering over a continent; and what did he (man) know about banking and drafts and letters of credit?

If he (man) carried the money about with him (man), he (man) would surely be robbed in the end; and so what was there for him (man) to do but enjoy it while he (man) could?

On a Saturday night he (man) drifted into a town with his (man) fellows; and because it was raining, and there was no other place provided for him (man), he (man) went to a saloon.

And there were some who treated him (man) and whom he (man) had to treat, and there was laughter and singing and good cheer; and then out of the rear part of the saloon a girl's face, red-cheeked and merry, smiled at Jurgis, and his (man) heart thumped suddenly in his (man) throat.

He (man) nodded to her (girl), and she (girl) came and sat by him (man), and they had more drink, and then he (man) went upstairs into a room with her (girl), and the wild beast rose up within him (man) and screamed, as it has screamed in the Jungle from the dawn of time.

And then because of his (man) memories and his (man) shame, he (man) was glad when others joined them, men and women; and they had more drink and spent the night in wild rioting and debauchery.

In the van of the surplus-labor army, there followed another, an army of women, they also struggling for life under the stern system of nature.

Because there were rich men who sought pleasure, there had been ease and plenty for them so long as they were young and beautiful; and later on, when they were crowded out by others younger and more beautiful, they went out to follow upon the trail of the workingmen.

Sometimes they came of themselves, and the saloon-keepers shared with them; or sometimes they were handled by agencies, the same as the labor army.

They were in the towns in harvest time, near the lumber camps in the winter, in the cities when the men came there; if a regiment were encamped, or a railroad or canal being made, or a great exposition getting ready, the crowd of women were on hand, living in shanties or saloons or tenement rooms, sometimes eight or ten of them together.

In the morning Jurgis had not a cent, and he (them) went out upon the road again. He (them) was sick and disgusted, but after the new plan of his (them) life, he (them) crushed his (them) feelings down.

He (them) had made a fool of himself, but he (them) could not help it now--all he (them) could do was to see that it did not happen again.

This happened to him (them) every time, for Jurgis was still a creature of impulse, and his (them) pleasures had not yet become business.

It would be a long time before he (them) could be like the majority of these men of the road, who roamed until the hunger for drink and for women mastered them, and then went to work with a purpose in mind, and stopped when they had the price of a spree.

So he (them) tramped on until exercise and fresh air banished his (them) headache, and his (them) strength and joy returned. On the contrary, try as he (them) would, Jurgis could not help being made miserable by his (them) conscience.

It was the ghost that would not down. It would come upon him (them) in the most unexpected places--sometimes it fairly drove him (them) to drink.

One night he (them) was caught by a thunderstorm, and he (them) sought shelter in a little house just outside of a town.

It was a working-man's home, and the owner was a Slav like himself, a new emigrant from White Russia; he (White) bade Jurgis welcome in his (White) home language, and told him (White) to come to the kitchen-fire and dry himself.

He (White) had no bed for him (White), but there was straw in the garret, and he (White) could make out. The man's wife was cooking the supper, and their children were playing about on the floor.

Jurgis sat and exchanged thoughts with him (White) about the old country, and the places where they had been and the work they had done.

In the middle of a sentence, however, Jurgis stopped, seeing that the woman had brought a big basin of water and was proceeding to undress her (woman) youngest baby.

The rest had crawled into the closet where they slept, but the baby was to have a bath, the workingman explained.

The nights had begun to be chilly, and his (White) mother, ignorant as to the climate in America, had sewed him (White) up for the winter; then it had turned warm again, and some kind of a rash had broken out on the child.

Then they ate, and afterward sat and smoked and talked more about America, and how they found it. The doctor had said she (mother) must bathe him (doctor) every night, and she (mother), foolish woman, believed him (doctor).

He (doctor) was about a year old, and a sturdy little fellow, with soft fat legs, and a round ball of a stomach, and eyes as black as coals.

His (fellow) pimples did not seem to bother him (fellow) much, and he (fellow) was wild with glee over the bath, kicking and squirming and chuckling with delight, pulling at his (fellow) mother's face and then at his (fellow) own little toes.

When she (mother) put him (fellow) into the basin he (fellow) sat in the midst of it and grinned, splashing the water over himself and squealing like a little pig.

He (fellow) spoke in Russian, of which Jurgis knew some; he (fellow) spoke it with the quaintest of baby accents--and every word of it brought back to Jurgis some word of his (fellow) own dead little one, and stabbed him (fellow) like a knife.

He (fellow) sat perfectly motionless, silent, but gripping his (fellow) hands tightly, while a storm gathered in his (fellow) bosom and a flood heaped itself up behind his (fellow) eyes.

And in the end he (fellow) could bear it no more, but buried his (fellow) face in his (fellow) hands and burst into tears, to the alarm and amazement of his (fellow) hosts.

Jurgis scarcely heard the explanation; he (fellow) was watching the baby. Between the shame of this and his (fellow) woe Jurgis could not stand it, and got up and rushed out into the rain.

He (fellow) went on and on down the road, finally coming to a black woods, where he (fellow) hid and wept as if his (fellow) heart would break.

Ah, what agony was that, what despair, when the tomb of memory was rent open and the ghosts of his (fellow) old life came forth to scourge him (fellow)!

What terror to see what he (fellow) had been and now could never be--to see Ona and his (fellow) child and his (fellow) own dead self stretching out their arms to him (fellow), calling to him (fellow) across a bottomless abyss--and to know that they were gone from him (fellow) forever, and he (fellow) writhing and suffocating in the mire of his (fellow) own vileness!

All the joy went out of tramping as soon as a man could not keep warm in the hay; and, like many thousands of others, he (man) deluded himself with the hope that by coming early he (man) could avoid the rush.

He (man) brought fifteen dollars with him (man), hidden away in one of his (man) shoes, a sum which had been saved from the saloon-keepers, not so much by his (man) conscience, as by the fear which filled him (man) at the thought of being out of work in the city in the winter time.

He (man) traveled upon the railroad with several other men, hiding in freight cars at night, and liable to be thrown off at any time, regardless of the speed of the train.

When he (man) reached the city he (man) left the rest, for he (man) had money and they did not, and he (man) meant to save himself in this fight.

Chapter 23 Early in the fall Jurgis set out for Chicago again. He (Early) would bring to it all the skill that practice had brought him (Early), and he (Early) would stand, whoever fell.

On fair nights he (Early) would sleep in the park or on a truck or an empty barrel or box, and when it was rainy or cold he (Early) would stow himself upon a shelf in a ten-cent lodging-house, or pay three cents for the privileges of a

``squatter'' (he)
in a tenement hallway.

He (squatter) would eat at free lunches, five cents a meal, and never a cent more--so he (squatter) might keep alive for two months and more, and in that time he (squatter) would surely find a job.

He (squatter) would have to bid farewell to his (squatter) summer cleanliness, of course, for he (squatter) would come out of the first night's lodging with his (squatter) clothes alive with vermin.

There was no place in the city where he (squatter) could wash even his (squatter) face, unless he (squatter) went down to the lake front--and there it would soon be all ice.

First he (squatter) went to the steel mill and the harvester works, and found that his (squatter) places there had been filled long ago.

He (squatter) was careful to keep away from the stockyards--he (squatter) was a single man now, he (squatter) told himself, and he (squatter) meant to stay one, to have his (squatter) wages for his (squatter) own when he (squatter) got a job.

He (squatter) began the long, weary round of factories and warehouses, tramping all day, from one end of the city to the other, finding everywhere from ten to a hundred men ahead of him (squatter).

He (squatter) watched the newspapers, too--but no longer was he (squatter) to be taken in by smooth-spoken agents. He (squatter) had been told of all those tricks while ``on the road.

It was a call for a hundred laborers, and though he (squatter) thought it was a

``fake,'' (he)
he (squatter) went because the place was near by.

He (squatter) found a line of men a block long, but as a wagon chanced to come out of an alley and break the line, he (squatter) saw his (squatter) chance and sprang to seize a place.

Men threatened him (squatter) and tried to throw him (squatter) out, but he (squatter) cursed and made a disturbance to attract a policeman, upon which they subsided, knowing that if the latter interfered it would be to

``fire'' (a policeman)
them all.

'' In the end it was through a newspaper that he (squatter) got a job, after nearly a month of seeking. An hour or two later he (squatter) entered a room and confronted a big Irishman behind a desk.

'' the man inquired; and whether it was a good angel that put it into Jurgis's mind, or an intuition of his (man) sharpened wits, he (man) was moved to answer,

``No, sir.'' (he)

'' Ever worked in Chicago before?

``Where do you come from?'' (unknown)
``Kansas City, sir.'' (unknown)
``Any references?'' (unknown)
'' No, sir. I'm just an unskilled man.

I've got good arms. ''

``I want men for hard work--it's all underground, digging tunnels for telephones. Maybe it won't suit you.'' (I)

'' I'm willing, sir--anything for me. What's the pay?''

``Fifteen cents an hour. '' (I)
'' I'm willing, sir.'' '' All right; go back there and give your name.

The tunnel was a peculiar one for telephone wires; it was about eight feet high, and with a level floor nearly as wide.

It had innumerable branches--a perfect spider web beneath the city; Jurgis walked over half a mile with his (your) gang to the place where they were to work.

'' So within half an hour he (your) was at work, far underneath the streets of the city. Stranger yet, the tunnel was lighted by electricity, and upon it was laid a double-tracked, narrow-gauge railroad!

But Jurgis was not there to ask questions, and he (Stranger) did not give the matter a thought. It was nearly a year afterward that he (Stranger) finally learned the meaning of this whole affair.

The City Council had passed a quiet and innocent little bill allowing a company to construct telephone conduits under the city streets; and upon the strength of this, a great corporation had proceeded to tunnel all Chicago with a system of railway freight-subways.

In the city there was a combination of employers, representing hundreds of millions of capital, and formed for the purpose of crushing the labor unions.

The chief union which troubled it was the teamsters'; and when these freight tunnels were completed, connecting all the big factories and stores with the railroad depots, they would have the teamsters' union by the throat.

Now and then there were rumors and murmurs in the Board of Aldermen, and once there was a committee to investigate--but each time another small fortune was paid over, and the rumors died away; until at last the city woke up with a start to find the work completed.

There was a tremendous scandal, of course; it was found that the city records had been falsified and other crimes committed, and some of Chicago's big capitalists got into jail--figuratively speaking.

The aldermen declared that they had had no idea of it all, in spite of the fact that the main entrance to the work had been in the rear of the saloon of one of them.

He (they) was so rejoiced that he (they) treated himself to a spree that night, and with the balance of his (they) money he (they) hired himself a place in a tenement room, where he (they) slept upon a big homemade straw mattress along with four other workingmen.

It was in a newly opened cut that Jurgis worked, and so he (they) knew that he (they) had an all-winter job. This was one dollar a week, and for four more he (they) got his (they) food in a boardinghouse near his (they) work.

At the outset he (they) had to pay for his (they) digging tools, and also to buy a pair of heavy boots, since his (they) shoes were falling to pieces, and a flannel shirt, since the one he (they) had worn all summer was in shreds.

This would leave him (they) four dollars extra each week, an unthinkable sum for him (they). He (they) spent a week meditating whether or not he (they) should also buy an overcoat.

There was one belonging to a Hebrew collar button peddler, who had died in the room next to him (peddler), and which the landlady was holding for her (landlady) rent; in the end, however, Jurgis decided to do without it, as he (peddler) was to be underground by day and in bed at night.

From now on Jurgis worked from seven o'clock until half-past five, with half an hour for dinner; which meant that he (peddler) never saw the sunlight on weekdays.

In the evenings there was no place for him (peddler) to go except a barroom; no place where there was light and warmth, where he (peddler) could hear a little music or sit with a companion and talk.

He (peddler) had now no home to go to; he (peddler) had no affection left in his (peddler) life--only the pitiful mockery of it in the camaraderie of vice.

On Sundays the churches were open--but where was there a church in which an ill-smelling workingman, with vermin crawling upon his (peddler) neck, could sit without seeing people edge away and look annoyed?

He (peddler) had, of course, his (peddler) corner in a close though unheated room, with a window opening upon a blank wall two feet away; and also he (peddler) had the bare streets, with the winter gales sweeping through them; besides this he (peddler) had only the saloons--and, of course, he (peddler) had to drink to stay in them.

If he (peddler) drank now and then he (peddler) was free to make himself at home, to gamble with dice or a pack of greasy cards, to play at a dingy pool table for money, or to look at a beer-stained pink

``sporting paper,'' (he)
with pictures of murderers and half-naked women.

It was for such pleasures as these that he (peddler) spent his (peddler) money; and such was his (peddler) life during the six weeks and a half that he (peddler) toiled for the merchants of Chicago, to enable them to break the grip of their teamsters' union.

This was an unfortunate decision, however, for it drove him (peddler) more quickly than ever into the saloons. In a work thus carried out, not much thought was given to the welfare of the laborers.

On an average, the tunneling cost a life a day and several manglings; it was seldom, however, that more than a dozen or two men heard of any one accident.

The work was all done by the new boring machinery, with as little blasting as possible; but there would be falling rocks and crushed supports, and premature explosions--and in addition all the dangers of railroading.

So it was that one night, as Jurgis was on his (it) way out with his (it) gang, an engine and a loaded car dashed round one of the innumerable right-angle branches and struck him (it) upon the shoulder, hurling him (it) against the concrete wall and knocking him (it) senseless.

When he (it) opened his (it) eyes again it was to the clanging of the bell of an ambulance. He (it) was lying in it, covered by a blanket, and it was threading its way slowly through the holiday-shopping crowds.

They took him (it) to the county hospital, where a young surgeon set his (surgeon) arm; then he (surgeon) was washed and laid upon a bed in a ward with a score or two more of maimed and mangled men.

Every year there were scandals and investigations in this institution, the newspapers charging that doctors were allowed to try fantastic experiments upon the patients; but Jurgis knew nothing of this

--his (surgeon) only complaint was that they used to feed him (surgeon) upon tinned meat, which no man who had ever worked in Packingtown would feed to his (man) dog.

Jurgis had often wondered just who ate the canned corned beef and

``roast beef'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
of the stockyards; now he (man) began to understand--that it was what you might call
``graft meat,'' (he)
put up to be sold to public officials and contractors, and eaten by soldiers and sailors, prisoners and inmates of institutions,
``shantymen'' (inmates)
and gangs of railroad laborers.

Jurgis spent his (man) Christmas in this hospital, and it was the pleasantest Christmas he (man) had had in America. Jurgis was ready to leave the hospital at the end of two weeks.

This did not mean that his (man) arm was strong and that he (man) was able to go back to work, but simply that he (man) could get along without further attention, and that his (man) place was needed for some one worse off than he (man).

That he (man) was utterly helpless, and had no means of keeping himself alive in the meantime, was something which did not concern the hospital authorities, nor any one else in the city.

As it chanced, he (man) had been hurt on a Monday, and had just paid for his (man) last week's board and his (man) room rent, and spent nearly all the balance of his (man) Saturday's pay.

He (man) had less than seventy-five cents in his (man) pockets, and a dollar and a half due him (man) for the day's work he (man) had done before he (man) was hurt.

He (man) might possibly have sued the company, and got some damages for his (man) injuries, but he (man) did not know this, and it was not the company's business to tell him (man).

Then he (man) went to his (man) landlady, who had rented his (man) place and had no other for him (man); and then to his (man) boardinghouse keeper, who looked him (man) over and questioned him (man).

As he (man) must certainly be helpless for a couple of months, and had boarded there only six weeks, she (landlady) decided very quickly that it would not be worth the risk to keep him (man) on trust.

He (man) went and got his (man) pay and his (man) tools, which he (man) left in a pawnshop for fifty cents. So Jurgis went out into the streets, in a most dreadful plight.

He (man) had no overcoat, and no place to go, and two dollars and sixty-five cents in his (man) pocket, with the certainty that he (man) could not earn another cent for months.

The snow meant no chance to him (man) now; he (man) must walk along and see others shoveling, vigorous and active--and he (man) with his (man) left arm bound to his (man) side!

He (man) could not hope to tide himself over by odd jobs of loading trucks; he (man) could not even sell newspapers or carry satchels, because he (man) was now at the mercy of any rival.

It was bitterly cold, and a heavy snow was falling, beating into his (man) face. Words could not paint the terror that came over him (man) as he (man) realized all this.

There would be no consideration for him (man) because of his (man) weakness--it was no one's business to help him (man) in such distress, to make the fight the least bit easier for him (man).

Even if he (man) took to begging, he (man) would be at a disadvantage, for reasons which he (man) was to discover in good time.

He (man) was like a wounded animal in the forest; he (man) was forced to compete with his (man) enemies upon unequal terms. In the beginning he (man) could not think of anything except getting out of the awful cold.

He (man) went into one of the saloons he (man) had been wont to frequent and bought a drink, and then stood by the fire shivering and waiting to be ordered out.

According to an unwritten law, the buying a drink included the privilege of loafing for just so long; then one had to buy another drink or move on.

That Jurgis was an old customer entitled him (man) to a somewhat longer stop; but then he (man) had been away two weeks, and was evidently ``on the bum.

He (bum) might plead and tell his (bum)

``hard luck story,'' (He)
but that would not help him (bum) much; a saloon-keeper who was to be moved by such means would soon have his (bum) place jammed to the doors with
``hoboes'' (a saloon-keeper)
on a day like this.

He (bum) was so hungry this time that he (bum) could not resist the hot beef stew, an indulgence which cut short his (bum) stay by a considerable time.

When he (bum) was again told to move on, he (bum) made his (bum) way to a

``tough'' (he)
place in the
``Levee'' (he)
district, where now and then he (bum) had gone with a certain rat-eyed Bohemian workingman of his (bum) acquaintance, seeking a woman.

'' So Jurgis went out into another place, and paid another nickel. It was Jurgis's vain hope that here the proprietor would let him (proprietor) remain as a ``sitter.

In low-class places, in the dead of winter, saloon-keepers would often allow one or two forlorn-looking bums who came in covered with snow or soaked with rain to sit by the fire and look miserable to attract custom.

A workingman would come in, feeling cheerful after his (proprietor) day's work was over, and it would trouble him (proprietor) to have to take his (proprietor) glass with such a sight under his (proprietor) nose; and so he (proprietor) would call out: ``Hello, Bub, what's the matter?

And then the other would begin to pour out some tale of misery, and the man would say, ``Come have a glass, and maybe that'll brace you up.

And so they would drink together, and if the tramp was sufficiently wretched-looking, or good enough at the

``gab,'' (the tramp)
they might have two; and if they were to discover that they were from the same country, or had lived in the same city or worked at the same trade, they might sit down at a table and spend an hour or two in talk--and before they got through the saloon-keeper would have taken in a dollar.

'' You look as if you'd been up against it!'' '' All of this might seem diabolical, but the saloon-keeper was in no wise to blame for it.

If he (you) does not, some one else will; and the saloon-keeper, unless he (you) is also an alderman, is apt to be in debt to the big brewers, and on the verge of being sold out.

He (you) was in the same plight as the manufacturer who has to adulterate and misrepresent his (you) product. The market for

``sitters'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
was glutted that afternoon, however, and there was no place for Jurgis.

In all he (you) had to spend six nickels in keeping a shelter over him (you) that frightful day, and then it was just dark, and the station houses would not open until midnight!

At the last place, however, there was a bartender who knew him (bartender) and liked him (bartender), and let him (bartender) doze at one of the tables until the boss came back; and also, as he (boss) was going out, the man gave him (man) a tip--on the next block there was a religious revival of some sort, with preaching and singing, and hundreds of hoboes would go there for the shelter and warmth.

Jurgis went straightway, and saw a sign hung out, saying that the door would open at seven-thirty; then he (man) walked, or half ran, a block, and hid awhile in a doorway and then ran again, and so on until the hour.

At the end he (man) was all but frozen, and fought his (man) way in with the rest of the throng -LRB-at the risk of having his (man) arm broken again-RRB-, and got close to the big stove.

By eight o'clock the place was so crowded that the speakers ought to have been flattered; the aisles were filled halfway up, and at the door men were packed tight enough to walk upon.

First they sang a hymn, and then one of the three, a tall, smooth-shaven man, very thin, and wearing black spectacles, began an address.

Jurgis heard smatterings of it, for the reason that terror kept him (man) awake--he (man) knew that he (man) snored abominably, and to have been put out just then would have been like a sentence of death to him (man).

There were three elderly gentlemen in black upon the platform, and a young lady who played the piano in front. The evangelist was preaching

``sin and redemption,'' (The evangelist)
the infinite grace of God and His (God) pardon for human frailty.

He (God) was very much in earnest, and he (God) meant well, but Jurgis, as he (God) listened, found his (God) soul filled with hatred.

What did he (God) know about sin and suffering--with his (God) smooth, black coat and his (God) neatly starched collar, his (God) body warm, and his (God) belly full, and money in his (God) pocket--and lecturing men who were struggling for their lives, men at the death grapple with the demon powers of hunger and cold!--This, of course, was unfair; but Jurgis felt that these men were out of touch with the life they discussed, that they were unfitted to solve its problems; nay, they themselves were part of the problem--they were part of the order established that was crushing men down and beating them!

They were of the triumphant and insolent possessors; they had a hall, and a fire, and food and clothing and money, and so they might preach to hungry men, and the hungry men must be humble and listen!

They were trying to save their souls--and who but a fool could fail to see that all that was the matter with their souls was that they had not been able to get a decent existence for their bodies?

At eleven the meeting closed, and the desolate audience filed out into the snow, muttering curses upon the few traitors who had got repentance and gone up on the platform.

It was yet an hour before the station house would open, and Jurgis had no overcoat--and was weak from a long illness.

He (fool) was obliged to run hard to keep his (fool) blood moving at all--and then he (fool) came back to the station house and found a crowd blocking the street before the door!

This was in the month of January, 1904, when the country was on the verge of

``hard times,'' (a half men)
and the newspapers were reporting the shutting down of factories every day--it was estimated that a million and a half men were thrown out of work before the spring.

So all the hiding places of the city were crowded, and before that station house door men fought and tore each other like savage beasts.

When at last the place was jammed and they shut the doors, half the crowd was still outside; and Jurgis, with his (men) helpless arm, was among them.

During that hour he (men) nearly perished. There was no choice then but to go to a lodging-house and spend another dime.

It really broke his (men) heart to do this, at half-past twelve o'clock, after he (men) had wasted the night at the meeting and on the street.

He (men) would be turned out of the lodging-house promptly at seven--they had the shelves which served as bunks so contrived that they could be dropped, and any man who was slow about obeying orders could be tumbled to the floor.

At the end of six days every cent of Jurgis' money was gone; and then he (man) went out on the streets to beg for his (man) life.

This was one day, and the cold spell lasted for fourteen of them. He (man) would begin as soon as the business of the city was moving.

He (man) would sally forth from a saloon, and, after making sure there was no policeman in sight, would approach every likely-looking person who passed him (policeman), telling his (policeman) woeful story and pleading for a nickel or a dime.

Then when he (policeman) got one, he (policeman) would dart round the corner and return to his (policeman) base to get warm; and his (policeman) victim, seeing him (policeman) do this, would go away, vowing that he (policeman) would never give a cent to a beggar again.

The victim never paused to ask where else Jurgis could have gone under the circumstances--where he (victim), the victim, would have gone.

At the saloon Jurgis could not only get more food and better food than he (victim) could buy in any restaurant for the same money, but a drink in the bargain to warm him (victim) up.

Also he (victim) could find a comfortable seat by a fire, and could chat with a companion until he (companion) was as warm as toast.

Part of the saloon-keeper's business was to offer a home and refreshments to beggars in exchange for the proceeds of their foragings; and was there any one else in the whole city who would do this--would the victim have done it himself?

He (victim) was just out of the hospital, and desperately sick-looking, and with a helpless arm; also he (victim) had no overcoat, and shivered pitifully.

But, alas, it was again the case of the honest merchant, who finds that the genuine and unadulterated article is driven to the wall by the artistic counterfeit.

At the saloon, too, he (merchant) felt at home. Poor Jurgis might have been expected to make a successful beggar. Jurgis, as a beggar, was simply a blundering amateur in competition with organized and scientific professionalism.

He (beggar) was just out of the hospital--but the story was worn threadbare, and how could he (beggar) prove it? He (beggar) had his (beggar) arm in a sling--and it was a device a regular beggar's little boy would have scorned.

As to his (boy) being without an overcoat, among them you would meet men you could swear had on nothing but a ragged linen duster and a pair of cotton trousers--so cleverly had they concealed the several suits of all-wool underwear beneath.

Many of these professional mendicants had comfortable homes, and families, and thousands of dollars in the bank; some of them had retired upon their earnings, and gone into the business of fitting out and doctoring others, or working children at the trade.

There were some who had both their arms bound tightly to their sides, and padded stumps in their sleeves, and a sick child hired to carry a cup for them.

There were some who had no legs, and pushed themselves upon a wheeled platform--some who had been favored with blindness, and were led by pretty little dogs.

Some less fortunate had mutilated themselves or burned themselves, or had brought horrible sores upon themselves with chemicals; you might suddenly encounter upon the street a man holding out to you a finger rotting and discolored with gangrene--or one with livid scarlet wounds half escaped from their filthy bandages.

These desperate ones were the dregs of the city's cesspools, wretches who hid at night in the rain-soaked cellars of old ramshackle tenements, in

``stale-beer dives'' (wretches)
and opium joints, with abandoned women in the last stages of the harlot's progress--women who had been kept by Chinamen and turned away at last to die.

Every day the police net would drag hundreds of them off the streets, and in the detention hospital you might see them, herded together in a miniature inferno, with hideous, beastly faces, bloated and leprous with disease, laughing, shouting, screaming in all stages of drunkenness, barking like dogs, gibbering like apes, raving and tearing themselves in delirium.

He (women) was pale and shivering--but they were made up with cosmetics, and had studied the art of chattering their teeth. Chapter 24

In the face of all his (women) handicaps, Jurgis was obliged to make the price of a lodging, and of a drink every hour or two, under penalty of freezing to death.

He (women) saw the world of civilization then more plainly than ever he (women) had seen it before; a world in which nothing counted but brutal might, an order devised by those who possessed it for the subjugation of those who did not.

He (women) was one of the latter; and all outdoors, all life, was to him (women) one colossal prison, which he (women) paced like a pent-up tiger, trying one bar after another, and finding them all beyond his (women) power.

He (women) had lost in the fierce battle of greed, and so was doomed to be exterminated; and all society was busied to see that he (women) did not escape the sentence.

Everywhere that he (women) turned were prison bars, and hostile eyes following him (women); the well-fed, sleek policemen, from whose glances he (women) shrank, and who seemed to grip their clubs more tightly when they saw him (women); the saloon-keepers, who never ceased to watch him (women) while he (women) was in their places, who were jealous of every moment he (women) lingered after he (women) had paid his (women) money; the hurrying throngs upon the streets, who were deaf to his (women) entreaties, oblivious of his (women) very existence--and savage and contemptuous when he (women) forced himself upon them.

Day after day he (women) roamed about in the arctic cold, his (women) soul filled full of bitterness and despair. They had their own affairs, and there was no place for him (women) among them.

There was no place for him (women) anywhere--every direction he (women) turned his (women) gaze, this fact was forced upon him (women): Everything was built to express it to him (women): the residences, with their heavy walls and bolted doors, and basement windows barred with iron; the great warehouses filled with the products of the whole world, and guarded by iron shutters and heavy gates; the banks with their unthinkable billions of wealth, all buried in safes and vaults of steel.

And then one day there befell Jurgis the one adventure of his (women) life. It was late at night, and he (women) had failed to get the price of a lodging.

Snow was falling, and he (Snow) had been out so long that he (Snow) was covered with it, and was chilled to the bone.

He (Snow) was working among the theater crowds, flitting here and there, taking large chances with the police, in his (Snow) desperation half hoping to be arrested.

When he (Snow) saw a blue-coat start toward him (Snow), however, his (Snow) heart failed him (Snow), and he (Snow) dashed down a side street and fled a couple of blocks.

When he (Snow) stopped again he (Snow) saw a man coming toward him (Snow), and placed himself in his (Snow) path. '' Please, sir,'' he (Snow) began, in the usual formula,

``will you give me the price of a lodging?

I've had a broken arm, and I can't work, and I've not a cent in my pocket. I'm an honest working-man, sir, and I never begged before!

'' (he)

Jurgis usually went on until he (Snow) was interrupted, but this man did not interrupt, and so at last he (man) came to a breathless stop.

It's not my fault, sir-- The other had halted, and Jurgis suddenly noticed that he (man) stood a little unsteadily. '' Whuzzat you say?

Jurgis began again, speaking more slowly and distinctly; before he (man) was half through the other put out his (man) hand and rested it upon his (man) shoulder.

'' he (man) queried suddenly, in a thick voice. '' Poor ole chappie! '' he (man) said. '' Been up--hic--up--against it, hey?'' Then he (man) lurched toward Jurgis, and the hand upon his (man) shoulder became an arm about his (man) neck.

'' Up against it myself, ole sport,'' he (man) said. '' She (man)'s a hard ole world. '' They were close to a lamppost, and Jurgis got a glimpse of the other.

He (man) wore a silk hat and a rich soft overcoat with a fur collar; and he (man) smiled at Jurgis with benignant sympathy.

He (man) was a young fellow--not much over eighteen, with a handsome boyish face. '' I'm hard up, too, my goo' fren','' he (goo) said.

'' I've got cruel parents, or I'd set you up. Whuzzamatter whizyer? '' '' I've been in the hospital.''

``Hospital!'' (the fellow)
exclaimed the young fellow, still smiling sweetly,
``thass too bad!

Same's my Aunt Polly-- hic-- my Aunt Polly's in the hospital, too-- ole auntie's been havin' twins! Whuzzamatter whiz you?'' (the fellow)

``I've got a broken arm--

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Jurgis began. '' So,'' said the other, sympathetically. '' That ain't so bad--you get over that. I wish somebody'd break my arm, ole chappie--

damfidon't! Then they'd treat me better--hic-- hole me up, ole sport! Whuzzit you wamme do?'' '' I'm hungry, sir,'' said Jurgis.

'' Hungry! Why don't you hassome supper?''

``I've got no money, sir. '' (unknown)
``No money! Ho, ho--less be chums, ole boy--

jess like me! No money, either--a`most busted! Why don't you go home, then, same's me?'' (unknown)

``I haven't any home,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis.

'' No home! Stranger in the city, hey? Goo' God, thass bad! Better come home wiz me--yes, by Harry , thass the trick, you'll come home an' hassome supper--hic--wiz me!

Awful lonesome--nobody home! Guv`ner gone abroad-- Bubby on's honeymoon-- Polly havin' twins--every damn soul gone away! Nuff--hic-- nuff to drive a feller to drink, I say!

Only ole Ham standin' by, passin' plates--damfican eat like that, no sir! The club for me every time, my boy, I say.

But then they won't lemme sleep there--guv`ner's orders, by Harry--home every night, sir! Ever hear anythin' like that? ' Every mornin' do?'

I asked him (Harry). ' No, sir, every night, or no allowance at all, sir.' Thass my guv`ner--`nice as nails, by Harry!

Tole ole Ham to watch me, too--servants spyin' on me--whuzyer think that, my fren'? A nice, quiet--hic--goodhearted young feller like me, an' his (feller) daddy can't go to Europe--hup!--an' leave him (feller) in peace!

Ain't that a shame, sir? An' I gotter go home every evenin' an' miss all the fun, by Harry! Thass whuzzamatter now--thass why I'm here!

Hadda come away an' leave Kitty--hic--left her (Kitty) cryin', too--whujja think of that, ole sport? ' Lemme go, Kittens,' says I--`come early an' often--I go where duty--hic--calls me.

Farewell, farewell, my own true love--farewell, farewehell, my--own true--love!' '' This last was a song, and the young gentleman's voice rose mournful and wailing, while he (gentleman) swung upon Jurgis's neck.

The latter was glancing about nervously, lest some one should approach. They were still alone, however. '' But I came all right, all right,'' continued the youngster, aggressively,

``I can--hic

--I can have my own way when I want it, by Harry--Freddie Jones is a hard man to handle when he (Jones) gets goin'! '

No, sir,' says I, `by thunder, and I don't need anybody goin' home with me, either --whujja take me for, hey?

Think I'm drunk, dontcha, hey?--I know you! But I'm no more drunk than you are, Kittens,' says I to her (I). And then says she (I), `Thass true, Freddie dear' -LRB-she (I)'s a smart one, is Kitty-RRB-, '

but I'm stayin' in the flat, an' you're goin' out into the cold, cold night!' `Put it in a pome, lovely Kitty,' says I. `No jokin', Freddie, my boy,' says she (Kitty). '

Lemme call a cab now, like a good dear'--but I can call my own cabs, dontcha fool yourself--and I know what I'm a-doin', you bet!

Say, my fren', whatcha say--willye come home an' see me, an' hassome supper? Come `long like a good feller-- don't be haughty!

You're up against it, same as me, an' you can unerstan' a feller; your heart's in the right place, by Harry--come `long, ole chappie, an' we'll light up the house,

an' have some fizz, an' we'll raise hell , we will--whoop-la! S'long's I'm inside the house I can do as I please--the guv`ner's own very orders, b`God!

Jurgis was trying to think what to do--he (God) knew he (God) could not pass any crowded place with his (God) new acquaintance without attracting attention and being stopped.

Hip! hip! '' (the youngster)

They had started down the street, arm in arm, the young man pushing Jurgis along, half dazed. It was only because of the falling snow that people who passed here did not notice anything wrong.

Suddenly, therefore, Jurgis stopped. '' Is it very far? '' he (man) inquired. '' Not very,'' said the other,

``Tired, are you, though?

Well, we'll ride--whatcha say? Good! Call a cab! '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

And then, gripping Jurgis tight with one hand, the young fellow began searching his (man) pockets with the other.

'' You call, ole sport, an' I'll pay,'' he (man) suggested. '' How's that , hey? '' And he (man) pulled out from somewhere a big roll of bills.

It was more money than Jurgis had ever seen in his (man) life before, and he (man) stared at it with startled eyes.

'' Looks like a lot, hey?'' said Master Freddie, fumbling with it. '' Fool you, though, ole chappie-- they're all little ones!

I'll be busted in one week more, sure thing--word of honor. An' not a cent more till the first--hic-- guv`ner's orders--hic--not a cent, by Harry!

Nuff to set a feller crazy, it is. I sent him (feller) a cable, this af`noon--thass one reason more why I'm goin' home. '

Hangin' on the verge of starvation,' I says--`for the honor of the family--hic--sen' me some bread. Hunger will compel me to join you--Freddie.'

Thass what I wired him (Freddie), by Harry, an' I mean it--I'll run away from school, b`God, if he (God) don't sen' me some.

He (God) might grab that wad of bills and be out of sight in the darkness before the other could collect his (God) wits.

'' After this fashion the young gentleman continued to prattle on--and meantime Jurgis was trembling with excitement. Should he (gentleman) do it?

What better had he (gentleman) to hope for, if he (gentleman) waited longer? But Jurgis had never committed a crime in his (gentleman) life, and now he (gentleman) hesitated half a second too long.

'' Freddie'' got one bill loose, and then stuffed the rest back into his (Freddie) trousers' pocket. '' Here, ole man,'' he (man) said,

``you take it.

They were in front of a saloon; and by the light of the window Jurgis saw that it was a hundred-dollar bill!

'' (he)

He (man) held it out fluttering. '' You take it,'' the other repeated.
``Pay the cabbie an' keep the change--I've got--hic--no head for business!

Guv`ner says so hisself, an' the guv`ner knows--the guv`ner's got a head for business, you bet! ' All right, guv`ner,' I told him (guv), `you run the show, and I'll take the tickets!'

An' so he (guv) set Aunt Polly to watch me--hic-- an' now Polly's off in the hospital havin' twins, an' me out raisin' Cain!

Hello, there! Hey! Call him (Cain)!'' (unknown)

A cab was driving by; and Jurgis sprang and called, and it swung round to the curb.

Master Freddie clambered in with some difficulty, and Jurgis had started to follow, when the driver shouted:

``Hi, there! Get out--you!'' (the driver)

Jurgis hesitated, and was half obeying; but his (driver) companion broke out:

``Whuzzat? Whuzzamatter wiz you, hey? '' (companion)
And the cabbie subsided, and Jurgis climbed in.

The youngster leaned back and snuggled up to Jurgis, murmuring contentedly; in half a minute he (youngster) was sound asleep, Jurgis sat shivering, speculating as to whether he (youngster) might not still be able to get hold of the roll of bills.

He (youngster) was afraid to try to go through his (youngster) companion's pockets, however; and besides the cabbie might be on the watch.

Then Freddie gave a number on the Lake Shore Drive, and the carriage started away. He (Freddie) had the hundred safe, and he (Freddie) would have to be content with that.

At the end of half an hour or so the cab stopped. They were out on the waterfront, and from the east a freezing gale was blowing off the ice-bound lake.

'' Here we are,'' called the cabbie, and Jurgis awakened his (cabbie) companion. Master Freddie sat up with a start. '' Hello!'' he (Freddie) said.

'' Where are we? Whuzzis? Who are you, hey? Oh, yes, sure nuff! Mos' forgot you--hic--ole chappie! Home, are we? Lessee!

Br-r-r--it's cold! Yes--come `long-- we're home-- it ever so--hic--humble!'' Before them there loomed an enormous granite pile, set far back from the street, and occupying a whole block.

By the light of the driveway lamps Jurgis could see that it had towers and huge gables, like a medieval castle.

He (you) thought that the young fellow must have made a mistake--it was inconceivable to him (you) that any person could have a home like a hotel or the city hall.

But he (you) followed in silence, and they went up the long flight of steps, arm in arm. '' There's a button here, ole sport,'' said Master Freddie.

'' Hole my arm while I find her (Master)! Steady, now--oh, yes, here she (Master) is! Saved! '' A bell rang, and in a few seconds the door was opened.

A man in blue livery stood holding it, and gazing before him (man), silent as a statue. They stood for a moment blinking in the light.

Jurgis's heart was beating wildly; it was a bold thing for him (man) to do--into what strange unearthly place he (man) was venturing he (man) had no idea.

Then Jurgis felt his (man) companion pulling, and he (man) stepped in, and the blue automaton closed the door. Aladdin entering his (man) cave could not have been more excited.

The place where he (man) stood was dimly lighted; but he (man) could see a vast hall, with pillars fading into the darkness above, and a great staircase opening at the far end of it.

The floor was of tesselated marble, smooth as glass, and from the walls strange shapes loomed out, woven into huge portieres in rich, harmonious colors, or gleaming from paintings, wonderful and mysterious-looking in the half-light, purple and red and golden, like sunset glimmers in a shadowy forest.

The man in livery had moved silently toward them; Master Freddie took off his (Freddie) hat and handed it to him (Freddie), and then, letting go of Jurgis' arm, tried to get out of his (Freddie) overcoat.

After two or three attempts he (Freddie) accomplished this, with the lackey's help, and meantime a second man had approached, a tall and portly personage, solemn as an executioner.

He (executioner) bore straight down upon Jurgis, who shrank away nervously; he (executioner) seized him (executioner) by the arm without a word, and started toward the door with him (executioner).

Then suddenly came Master Freddie's voice,

``Hamilton! My fren' will remain wiz me. '' (Master Freddie)
The man paused and half released Jurgis.

'' Come `long ole chappie,'' said the other, and Jurgis started toward him (man).

``Master Frederick!'' (the man)
exclaimed the man. '' See that the cabbie--hic--is paid,'' was the other's response; and he (cabbie) linked his (cabbie) arm in Jurgis'.

The stout man in uniform signaled to the other, who went out to the cab, while he (man) followed Jurgis and his (man) young master.

Jurgis was about to say,

``I have the money for him (man),'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
but he (man) restrained himself. They went down the great hall, and then turned.

Before them were two huge doors.

``Hamilton,'' (Master)
said Master Freddie. '' Well, sir?'' said the other. '' Whuzzamatter wizze dinin'-room doors?''

'' Nothing is the matter, sir.'' '' Then why dontcha openum? '' The man rolled them back; another vista lost itself in the darkness.

Lights,'' commanded Master Freddie; and the butler pressed a button, and a flood of brilliant incandescence streamed from above, half-blinding Jurgis.

He (Master) stared; and little by little he (Master) made out the great apartment, with a domed ceiling from which the light poured, and walls that were one enormous painting--nymphs and dryads dancing in a flower-strewn glade--Diana with her (Diana) hounds and horses, dashing headlong through a mountain streamlet--a group of maidens bathing in a forest pool--all life-size, and so real that Jurgis thought that it was some work of enchantment, that he (Master) was in a dream palace.

Then his (Master) eye passed to the long table in the center of the hall, a table black as ebony, and gleaming with wrought silver and gold.

In the center of it was a huge carven bowl, with the glistening gleam of ferns and the red and purple of rare orchids, glowing from a light hidden somewhere in their midst.

'' '' This's the dinin' room,'' observed Master Freddie. '' How you like it, hey, ole sport? '' He (Master) always insisted on having an answer to his (Master) remarks, leaning over Jurgis and smiling into his (Master) face.

Jurgis liked it. '' Rummy ole place to feed in all `lone, though,'' was Freddie's comment--

``rummy's hell! Whuzya think, hey?'' (Freddie/Master Freddie)
Then another idea occurred to him (Freddie) and he (Freddie) went on, without waiting:

``Maybe you never saw anythin--hic--like this `fore? Hey, ole chappie?'' (he)
'' No,'' said Jurgis. '' Come from country, maybe--hey?'' '' Yes,'' said Jurgis.

``Aha! I thosso! Lossa folks from country never saw such a place. Guv`ner brings 'em--free show--hic--reg`lar circus! Go home tell folks about it.

Ole man Jones's place--Jones the packer--beef-trust man. Made it all out of hogs, too, damn ole scoundrel. Now we see where our pennies go--rebates, an' private car lines--hic--by Harry!

Bully place, though--worth seein'! Ever hear of Jones the packer, hey, ole chappie?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Jurgis had started involuntarily; the other, whose sharp eyes missed nothing, demanded:
``Whuzzamatter, hey?

Heard of him (Heard)? '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

And Jurgis managed to stammer out:
``I have worked for him (Heard) in the yards.'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
``What!'' (Master)
cried Master Freddie, with a yell.

'' You! In the yards? Ho, ho! Why, say, thass good! Shake hands on it, ole man--by Harry! Guv`ner ought to be here--glad to see you.

Great fren's with the men, guv`ner--labor an' capital, commun'ty 'f int`rests, an' all that--hic! Funny things happen in this world, don't they, ole man?

Hamilton, lemme interduce you--fren' the family--ole fren' the guv`ner's--works in the yards. Come to spend the night wiz me, Hamilton--have a hot time.

The stately butler bowed his (butler) head, but made not a sound; and suddenly Master Freddie pointed an eager finger at him (Freddie).

Me fren', Mr.--whuzya name, ole chappie? Tell us your name.''

``Rudkus--Jurgis Rudkus.'' (fren)
'' My fren', Mr. Rednose, Hamilton--shake han's. '' ''

I know whuzzamatter wiz you, Hamilton--lay you a dollar I know! You think--hic--you think I'm drunk! Hey, now?'' And the butler again bowed his (butler) head.

'' Yes, sir,'' he (butler) said, at which Master Freddie hung tightly upon Jurgis's neck and went into a fit of laughter.

'' Hamilton, you damn ole scoundrel,'' he (Hamilton) roared,

``I'll `scharge you for impudence, you see 'f I don't! Ho, ho, ho!

I'm drunk! Ho, ho! '' (he)

The two waited until his (Ho) fit had spent itself, to see what new whim would seize him (Ho).

'' Whatcha wanta do? '' he (Ho) queried suddenly. '' Wanta see the place, ole chappie? Wamme play the guv`ner--show you roun'?

State parlors-- Looee Cans-- Looee Sez--chairs cost three thousand apiece. Tea room Maryanntnet--picture of shepherds dancing--Ruysdael--twenty-three thousan'! Ballroom--balc`ny pillars--hic--imported--special ship--sixty-eight thousan'!

Ceilin' painted in Rome--whuzzat feller's name, Hamilton--Mattatoni? Macaroni? Then this place--silver bowl--Benvenuto Cellini--rummy ole Dago! An' the organ--thirty thousan' dollars, sir--starter up, Hamilton, let Mr. Rednose hear it.

No--never mind--clean forgot--says he (Rednose)'s hungry, Hamilton--less have some supper. Only--hic--don't less have it here--come up to my place, ole sport--nice an' cosy.

This way--steady now, don't slip on the floor. Hamilton, we'll have a cole spread, an' some fizz--don't leave out the fizz, by Harry.

We'll have some of the eighteen-thirty Madeira. Hear me, sir?'' '' Yes, sir,'' said the butler,

``but, Master Frederick, your father left orders--

'' (the butler Frederick Frederick)

And Master Frederick drew himself up to a stately height. '' My father's orders were left to me--hic--an' not to you,'' he (father) said.

Then, clasping Jurgis tightly by the neck, he (father) staggered out of the room; on the way another idea occurred to him (father), and he (father) asked:

``Any--hic--cable message for me, Hamilton?'' (he)

'' No, sir,'' said the butler. '' Guv`ner must be travelin'. An' how's the twins, Hamilton?'' '' They are doing well, sir.''

They went up the great staircase, one step at a time; at the top of it there gleamed at them out of the shadows the figure of a nymph crouching by a fountain, a figure ravishingly beautiful, the flesh warm and glowing with the hues of life.

``Good!'' (Master)
said Master Freddie; and added fervently:
``God bless 'em, the little lambs! '' (Master Freddie)
Above was a huge court, with domed roof, the various apartments opening into it.

The butler had paused below but a few minutes to give orders, and then followed them; now he (butler) pressed a button, and the hall blazed with light.

He (butler) opened a door before them, and then pressed another button, as they staggered into the apartment. It was fitted up as a study.

In the center was a mahogany table, covered with books, and smokers' implements; the walls were decorated with college trophies and colors--flags, posters, photographs and knickknacks--tennis rackets, canoe paddles, golf clubs, and polo sticks.

An enormous moose head, with horns six feet across, faced a buffalo head on the opposite wall, while bear and tiger skins covered the polished floor.

There were lounging chairs and sofas, window seats covered with soft cushions of fantastic designs; there was one corner fitted in Persian fashion, with a huge canopy and a jeweled lamp beneath.

Beyond, a door opened upon a bedroom, and beyond that was a swimming pool of the purest marble, that had cost about forty thousand dollars.

Master Freddie stood for a moment or two, gazing about him (Freddie); then out of the next room a dog emerged, a monstrous bulldog, the most hideous object that Jurgis had ever laid eyes upon.

He (Freddie) yawned, opening a mouth like a dragon's; and he (Freddie) came toward the young man, wagging his (Freddie) tail. '' Hello, Dewey!'' cried his (Dewey) master.

'' Been havin' a snooze, ole boy? Well, well--hello there, whuzzamatter? '' -LRB-The dog was snarling at Jurgis.-RRB- '' Why, Dewey--this' my fren', Mr. Rednose--ole fren' the guv`ner's!

Mr. Rednose, Admiral Dewey; shake han's--hic. Ain't he (Dewey) a daisy, though--blue ribbon at the New York show--eighty-five hundred at a clip!

The speaker sank into one of the big armchairs, and Admiral Dewey crouched beneath it; he (Dewey) did not snarl again, but he (Dewey) never took his (Dewey) eyes off Jurgis.

How's that , hey? '' He (Dewey) was perfectly sober, was the Admiral. The butler had closed the door, and he (butler) stood by it, watching Jurgis every second.

Now there came footsteps outside, and, as he (butler) opened the door a man in livery entered, carrying a folding table, and behind him (butler) two men with covered trays.

There were cold pates, and thin slices of meat, tiny bread and butter sandwiches with the crust cut off, a bowl of sliced peaches and cream -LRB-in January-RRB-, little fancy cakes, pink and green and yellow and white, and half a dozen ice-cold bottles of wine.

They stood like statues while the first spread the table and set out the contents of the trays upon it. ''

Thass the stuff for you!'' cried Master Freddie, exultantly, as he (Freddie) spied them. '' Come `long, ole chappie, move up. ''

And he (Freddie) seated himself at the table; the waiter pulled a cork, and he (waiter) took the bottle and poured three glasses of its contents in succession down his (waiter) throat.

The butler held the chair at the opposite side of the table, and Jurgis thought it was to keep him (waiter) out of it; but finally he (waiter) understand that it was the other's intention to put it under him (waiter), and so he (waiter) sat down, cautiously and mistrustingly.

Then he (waiter) gave a long-drawn sigh, and cried again to Jurgis to seat himself. Master Freddie perceived that the attendants embarrassed him (Freddie), and he (Freddie) remarked with a nod to them,

``You may go.

'' (he)

They went, all save the butler. '' You may go too, Hamilton,'' he (Hamilton) said. '' Master Frederick--'' the man began.

The man went out and closed the door; Jurgis, who was as sharp as he (man), observed that he (man) took the key out of the lock, in order that he (man) might peer through the keyhole.

``Go! '' (the youngster)
cried the youngster, angrily. '' Damn you, don't you hear me? '' Master Frederick turned to the table again.

'' Now,'' he (Frederick) said,

``go for it. '' (he)
Jurgis gazed at him (Frederick) doubtingly.
``Eat! '' (unknown)
cried the other. '' Pile in, ole chappie!''

``Don't you want anything?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis asked. '' Ain't hungry,'' was the reply--
``only thirsty. Kitty and me had some candy--you go on.

He (Frederick) ate as with two shovels, his (Frederick) fork in one hand and his (Frederick) knife in the other; when he (Frederick) once got started his (Frederick) wolf-hunger got the better of him (Frederick), and he (Frederick) did not stop for breath until he (Frederick) had cleared every plate.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

So Jurgis began, without further parley. '' Gee whiz! '' said the other, who had been watching him (Frederick) in wonder.

Lessee you drink now,'' he (Frederick) said; and Jurgis took the bottle and turned it up to his (Frederick) mouth, and a wonderfully unearthly liquid ecstasy poured down his (Frederick) throat, tickling every nerve of him (Frederick), thrilling him (Frederick) with joy.

Then he (Frederick) held Jurgis the bottle. '' He (Frederick) drank the very last drop of it, and then he (Frederick) gave vent to a long-drawn

``Ah!

'' (he)

said Freddie, sympathetically; he (Freddie) had leaned back in the big chair, putting his (Freddie) arm behind his (Freddie) head and gazing at Jurgis.

'' ``Good stuff, hey? And Jurgis gazed back at him (Freddie). He (Freddie) was clad in spotless evening dress, was Freddie, and looked very handsome

--he (Freddie) was a beautiful boy, with light golden hair and the head of an Antinous. He (Freddie) smiled at Jurgis confidingly, and then started talking again, with his (Freddie) blissful insouciance.

This time he (Freddie) talked for ten minutes at a stretch, and in the course of the speech he (Freddie) told Jurgis all of his (Freddie) family history.

His (Freddie) big brother Charlie was in love with the guileless maiden who played the part of

``Little Bright-Eyes'' (the maiden)
in ``The Kaliph of Kamskatka.

He (Charlie) had been on the verge of marrying her (Freddie) once, only

``the guv`ner'' (He)
had sworn to disinherit him (guv), and had presented him (guv) with a sum that would stagger the imagination, and that had staggered the virtue of
``Little Bright-Eyes.

Now Charlie had got leave from college, and had gone away in his (Charlie) automobile on the next best thing to a honeymoon.

The guv`ner'' (him)

had made threats to disinherit another of his (Charlie) children also, sister Gwendolen, who had married an Italian marquis with a string of titles and a dueling record.

They lived in his (Charlie) chateau, or rather had, until he (Charlie) had taken to firing the breakfast dishes at her (sister); then she (sister) had cabled for help, and the old gentleman had gone over to find out what were his (gentleman) Grace's terms.

'' '' '' So they had left Freddie all alone, and he (Freddie) with less than two thousand dollars in his (Freddie) pocket.

Freddie was up in arms and meant serious business, as they would find in the end--if there was no other way of bringing them to terms he (Freddie) would have his (Freddie)

``Kittens'' (he)
wire that she (Grace) was about to marry him (Freddie), and see what happened then.

So the cheerful youngster rattled on, until he (youngster) was tired out. He (youngster) smiled his (youngster) sweetest smile at Jurgis, and then he (youngster) closed his (youngster) eyes, sleepily.

Then he (youngster) opened them again, and smiled once more, and finally closed them and forgot to open them. For several minutes Jurgis sat perfectly motionless, watching him (youngster), and reveling in the strange sensation of the champagne.

Once he (youngster) stirred, and the dog growled; after that he (youngster) sat almost holding his (youngster) breath--until after a while the door of the room opened softly, and the butler came in.

He (butler) walked toward Jurgis upon tiptoe, scowling at him (butler); and Jurgis rose up, and retreated, scowling back. So until he (butler) was against the wall, and then the butler came close, and pointed toward the door.

If you do, you son of a--'' hissed the butler,

``I'll mash in your face for you before you get out of here!'' (the butler)

``Get out of here!'' (he)
he (butler) whispered. Jurgis hesitated, giving a glance at Freddie, who was snoring softly. '' And Jurgis wavered but an instant more.

He (Freddie) saw

``Admiral Dewey'' (He)
coming up behind the man and growling softly, to back up his (Freddie) threats. Then he (Freddie) surrendered and started toward the door.

They went out without a sound, and down the great echoing staircase, and through the dark hall. At the front door he (Freddie) paused, and the butler strode close to him (butler).

'' he (butler) cried; and then understanding that the fellow proposed to search him (butler), he (butler) answered,

``I'll see you in hell first.'' (he)

'' Hold up your hands,'' he (butler) snarled. Jurgis took a step back, clinching his (butler) one well fist. '' What for?

``Do you want to go to jail?

'' (the butler)

demanded the butler, menacingly. '' I'll have the police-- ''
``Have 'em! '' (the police)
roared Jurgis, with fierce passion. '' But you won't put your hands on me till you do!

I haven't touched anything in your damned house, and I'll not have you touch me!'' So the butler, who was terrified lest his (butler) young master should waken, stepped suddenly to the door, and opened it.

he (butler) said; and then as Jurgis passed through the opening, he (butler) gave him (butler) a ferocious kick that sent him (butler) down the great stone steps at a run, and landed him (butler) sprawling in the snow at the bottom.

Chapter 25 Jurgis got up, wild with rage, but the door was shut and the great castle was dark and impregnable.

``Get out of here!'' (him)
Then the icy teeth of the blast bit into him (butler), and he (butler) turned and went away at a run.

When he (butler) stopped again it was because he (butler) was coming to frequented streets and did not wish to attract attention. In spite of that last humiliation, his (butler) heart was thumping fast with triumph.

He (butler) put his (butler) hand into his (butler) trousers' pocket every now and then, to make sure that the precious hundred-dollar bill was still there.

He (butler) had come out ahead on that deal! Yet he (butler) was in a plight--a curious and even dreadful plight, when he (butler) came to realize it.

He (butler) had not a single cent but that one bill! And he (butler) had to find some shelter that night he (butler) had to change it!

Jurgis spent half an hour walking and debating the problem. There was no one he (butler) could go to for help--he (butler) had to manage it all alone.

To get it changed in a lodging-house would be to take his (butler) life in his (butler) hands--he (butler) would almost certainly be robbed, and perhaps murdered, before morning.

He (butler) might go to some hotel or railroad depot and ask to have it changed; but what would they think, seeing a

``bum'' (He)
like him (bum) with a hundred dollars?

On the morrow Freddie Jones would discover his (Jones) loss, and there would be a hunt for him (Jones), and he (Jones) would lose his (Jones) money.

He (Jones) would probably be arrested if he (Jones) tried it; and what story could he (Jones) tell? The only other plan he (Jones) could think of was to try in a saloon.

He (Jones) began peering into places as he (Jones) walked; he (Jones) passed several as being too crowded--then finally, chancing upon one where the bartender was all alone, he (bartender) gripped his (bartender) hands in sudden resolution and went in.

He (bartender) might pay them to change it, if it could not be done otherwise. '' Can you change me a hundred-dollar bill?

The bartender was a big, husky fellow, with the jaw of a prize fighter, and a three weeks' stubble of hair upon it.

'' he (fighter) demanded. He (fighter) stared at Jurgis. '' What's that youse say? '' he (fighter) demanded. '' I said, could you change me a hundred-dollar bill?''

``Where'd youse get it? '' (he)
he (fighter) inquired incredulously. '' Never mind,'' said Jurgis;
``I've got it, and I want it changed.

I'll pay you if you'll do it. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

The other stared at him (fighter) hard. '' Lemme see it,'' he (Lem) said. ''

Will you change it?'' Jurgis demanded, gripping it tightly in his (Lem) pocket. '' How the hell can I know if it's good or not?

Then Jurgis slowly and warily approached him (Lem); he (Lem) took out the bill, and fumbled it for a moment, while the man stared at him (man) with hostile eyes across the counter.

The other took it, and began to examine it; he (man) smoothed it between his (man) fingers, and held it up to the light; he (man) turned it over, and upside down, and edgeways.

'' retorted the bartender. '' Whatcher take me for, hey? '' Then finally he (bartender) handed it over. It was new and rather stiff, and that made him (bartender) dubious.

Humph,'' he (bartender) said, finally, and gazed at the stranger, sizing him (bartender) up--a ragged, ill-smelling tramp, with no overcoat and one arm in a sling--and a hundred-dollar bill! ''

Jurgis was watching him (tramp) like a cat all the time. '' Want to buy anything? '' he (tramp) demanded. '' Yes,'' said Jurgis,

``I'll take a glass of beer.

And he (tramp) put the bill in his (tramp) pocket, and poured Jurgis out a glass of beer, and set it on the counter.

Then he (tramp) turned to the cash register, and punched up five cents, and began to pull money out of the drawer.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

'' All right,'' said the other,
``I'll change it. '' (he)
Finally, he (tramp) faced Jurgis, counting it out--two dimes, a quarter, and fifty cents.

'' There,'' he (tramp) said. For a second Jurgis waited, expecting to see him (tramp) turn again. '' My ninety-nine dollars,'' he (tramp) said.

'' What ninety-nine dollars?'' demanded the bartender. '' My change! '' he (bartender) cried--

``the rest of my hundred!'' (he)
``Go on,'' (the bartender)
said the bartender,
``you're nutty!'' (the bartender)

For an instant horror reigned in him (bartender)--black, paralyzing, awful horror, clutching him (bartender) at the heart; and then came rage, in surging, blinding floods--he (bartender) screamed aloud, and seized the glass and hurled it at the other's head.

The man ducked, and it missed him (man) by half an inch; he (man) rose again and faced Jurgis, who was vaulting over the bar with his (man) one well arm, and dealt him (man) a smashing blow in the face, hurling him (man) backward upon the floor.

Then, as Jurgis scrambled to his (man) feet again and started round the counter after him (man), he (man) shouted at the top of his (man) voice,

``Help! help!'' (he)

Jurgis seized a bottle off the counter as he (man) ran; and as the bartender made a leap he (man) hurled the missile at him (man) with all his (man) force.

And Jurgis stared at him (man) with wild eyes. It just grazed his (man) head, and shivered into a thousand pieces against the post of the door.

This time, in his (man) blind frenzy, he (man) came without a bottle, and that was all the bartender wanted--he (bartender) met him (bartender) halfway and floored him (bartender) with a sledgehammer drive between the eyes.

An instant later the screen doors flew open, and two men rushed in--just as Jurgis was getting to his (bartender) feet again, foaming at the mouth with rage, and trying to tear his (bartender) broken arm out of its bandages.

Then Jurgis started back, rushing at the man again in the middle of the room.

``Look out!'' (the bartender)
shouted the bartender. ''

Then, seeing that the two were disposed to join the fray, he (bartender) made another rush at Jurgis, and knocked aside his (bartender) feeble defense and sent him (bartender) tumbling again; and the three flung themselves upon him (bartender), rolling and kicking about the place.

He (bartender)'s got a knife!'' A second later a policeman dashed in, and the bartender yelled once more--

``Look out for his (bartender) knife!'' (the bartender)

Jurgis had fought himself half to his (bartender) knees, when the policeman made a leap at him (bartender), and cracked him (bartender) across the face with his (bartender) club.

Though the blow staggered him (bartender), the wild-beast frenzy still blazed in him (bartender), and he (bartender) got to his (bartender) feet, lunging into the air.

The policeman crouched over him (policeman), clutching his (policeman) stick, waiting for him (policeman) to try to rise again; and meantime the barkeeper got up, and put his (policeman) hand to his (policeman) head.

Then again the club descended, full upon his (policeman) head, and he (policeman) dropped like a log to the floor. '' Christ! ''

he (Christ) said,

``I thought I was done for that time. Did he (Christ) cut me?'' (he)
``Don't see anything, Jake,'' (the policeman)
said the policeman.

'' What's the matter with him (policeman)?''

``Just crazy drunk,'' (unknown)
said the other. '' A lame duck, too--but he (policeman) `most got me under the bar.

Youse had better call the wagon, Billy.'' '' No,'' said the officer. '' He (officer)'s got no more fight in him (officer), I guess--and he (officer)'s only got a block to go.

But Jurgis did not move, and the bartender went behind the bar, and after stowing the hundred-dollar bill away in a safe hiding place, came and poured a glass of water over Jurgis.

Then, as the latter began to moan feebly, the policeman got him (policeman) to his (policeman) feet and dragged him (policeman) out of the place.

'' He (policeman) twisted his (policeman) hand in Jurgis's collar and jerked at him (policeman). '' Git up here, you!'' he (policeman) commanded. The station house was just around the corner, and so in a few minutes Jurgis was in a cell.

He (policeman) spent half the night lying unconscious, and the balance moaning in torment, with a blinding headache and a racking thirst.

There were others in that same station house with split heads and a fever; there were hundreds of them in the great city, and tens of thousands of them in the great land, and there was no one to hear any of them.

In the morning Jurgis was given a cup of water and a piece of bread, and then hustled into a patrol wagon and driven to the nearest police court.

Now and then he (others) cried aloud for a drink of water, but there was no one to hear him (others). He (others) sat in the pen with a score of others until his (others) turn came.

The prisoner had come into his (prisoner) saloon after midnight, fighting drunk, and had ordered a glass of beer and tendered a dollar bill in payment.

He (prisoner) had been given ninety-five cents' change, and had demanded ninety-nine dollars more, and before the plaintiff could even answer had hurled the glass at him (plaintiff) and then attacked him (plaintiff) with a bottle of bitters, and nearly wrecked the place.

Then the prisoner was sworn--a forlorn object, haggard and unshorn, with an arm done up in a filthy bandage, a cheek and head cut, and bloody, and one eye purplish black and entirely closed.

The bartender--who proved to be a well-known bruiser--was called to the stand. He (bartender) took the oath and told his (bartender) story. ''

Your Honor,'' said Jurgis,

``I went into his (bartender) place and asked the man if he (bartender) could change me a hundred-dollar bill.

What have you to say for yourself?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

queried the magistrate. '' And he (magistrate) said he (magistrate) would if I bought a drink.

I gave him (magistrate) the bill and then he (magistrate) wouldn't give me the change. '' The magistrate was staring at him (magistrate) in perplexity.

'' You gave him (magistrate) a hundred-dollar bill!'' he (magistrate) exclaimed. '' Yes, your Honor,'' said Jurgis. '' Where did you get it?''

'' A man gave it to me, your Honor. ''

``A man? What man, and what for?'' (unknown)
``A young man I met upon the street, your Honor.

There was a titter in the courtroom; the officer who was holding Jurgis put up his (officer) hand to hide a smile, and the magistrate smiled without trying to hide it.

I had been begging. '' (unknown)

'' It's true, your Honor!'' cried Jurgis, passionately. '' You had been drinking as well as begging last night, had you not?

'' inquired the magistrate. '' No, your Honor--'' protested Jurgis.

``I--'' (unknown)
'' You had not had anything to drink?''
``Why, yes, your Honor, I had--'' (unknown)

'' What did you have?''

``I had a bottle of something--I don't know what it was--something that burned-- '' (the magistrate)
There was again a laugh round the courtroom, stopping suddenly as the magistrate looked up and frowned.

'' Have you ever been arrested before? '' he (magistrate) asked abruptly. The question took Jurgis aback. '' I-- I--'' he (magistrate) stammered.

``Tell me the truth, now!'' (unknown)
commanded the other, sternly. '' Yes, your Honor,'' said Jurgis. '' How often?'' '' Only once, your Honor.

''

``What for?'' (boss)
'' For knocking down my boss, your Honor. I was working in the stockyards, and he (boss)-- ''
``I see,'' (he)
said his (boss) Honor;

``I guess that will do. You ought to stop drinking if you can't control yourself. Ten days and costs. Next case.

'' (he)

Jurgis gave vent to a cry of dismay, cut off suddenly by the policeman, who seized him (policeman) by the collar.

He (policeman) was jerked out of the way, into a room with the convicted prisoners, where he (policeman) sat and wept like a child in his (policeman) impotent rage.

It seemed monstrous to him (policeman) that policemen and judges should esteem his (policeman) word as nothing in comparison with the bartender's--poor Jurgis could not know that the owner of the saloon paid five dollars each week to the policeman alone for Sunday privileges and general favors--nor that the pugilist bartender was one of the most trusted henchmen of the Democratic leader of the district, and had helped only a few months before to hustle out a record-breaking vote as a testimonial to the magistrate, who had been made the target of odious kid-gloved reformers.

In his (magistrate) tumbling around he (magistrate) had hurt his (magistrate) arm again, and so could not work, but had to be attended by the physician.

Jurgis was driven out to the Bridewell for the second time. Also his (physician) head and his (physician) eye had to be tied up--and so he (physician) was a pretty-looking object

when, the second day after his (physician) arrival, he (physician) went out into the exercise court and encountered--Jack Duane! The young fellow was so glad to see Jurgis that he (fellow) almost hugged him (fellow).

'' By God, if it isn't `the Stinker'!'' he (God) cried. '' And what is it--have you been through a sausage machine?''

And then, while some of the other prisoners gathered round he (God) told his (God) wild story; most of them were incredulous, but Duane knew that Jurgis could never have made up such a yarn as that.

'' No,'' said Jurgis,

``but I've been in a railroad wreck and a fight. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
'' Hard luck, old man,'' he (man) said, when they were alone;
``but maybe it's taught you a lesson.'' (he)

``I've learned some things since I saw you last,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis mournfully. Then he (man) explained how he (man) had spent the last summer,
``hoboing it,'' (he)
as the phrase was.

'' And you? '' he (man) asked finally. '' Have you been here ever since?''

``Lord, no! '' (I)
said the other. ''

I only came in the day before yesterday. It's the second time they've sent me up on a trumped-up charge-- I've had hard luck and can't pay them what they want.

Why don't you quit Chicago with me, Jurgis?'' '' I've no place to go,'' said Jurgis, sadly. '' Neither have I,'' replied the other, laughing lightly.

In the Bridewell Jurgis met few who had been there the last time, but he (Lord) met scores of others, old and young, of exactly the same sort.

'' But we'll wait till we get out and see. '' It was like breakers upon a beach; there was new water, but the wave looked just the same.

He (Lord) strolled about and talked with them, and the biggest of them told tales of their prowess, while those who were weaker, or younger and inexperienced, gathered round and listened in admiring silence.

The last time he (Lord) was there, Jurgis had thought of little but his (Lord) family; but now he (Lord) was free to listen to these men, and to realize that he (Lord) was one of them--that their point of view was his (Lord) point of view, and that the way they kept themselves alive in the world was the way he (Lord) meant to do it in the future.

And so, when he (Lord) was turned out of prison again, without a penny in his (Lord) pocket, he (Lord) went straight to Jack Duane.

He (Duane) went full of humility and gratitude; for Duane was a gentleman, and a man with a profession--and it was remarkable that he (Duane) should be willing to throw in his (Duane) lot with a humble workingman, one who had even been a beggar and a tramp.

Jurgis could not see what help he (tramp) could be to him (tramp); but he (tramp) did not understand that a man like himself--who could be trusted to stand by any one who was kind to him (man)--was as rare among criminals as among any other class of men.

The address Jurgis had was a garret room in the Ghetto district, the home of a pretty little French girl, Duane's mistress, who sewed all day, and eked out her (mistress) living by prostitution.

The new address was a cellar dive, whose proprietor said that he (proprietor) had never heard of Duane; but after he (Duane) had put Jurgis through a catechism he (Duane) showed him (Duane) a back stairs which led to a

``fence'' (him)
in the rear of a pawnbroker's shop, and thence to a number of assignation rooms, in one of which Duane was hiding.

Duane was glad to see him (Duane); he (Duane) was without a cent of money, he (Duane) said, and had been waiting for Jurgis to help him (Duane) get some.
