He (Duane) explained his (Duane) plan--in fact he (Duane) spent the day in laying bare to his (Duane) friend the criminal world of the city, and in showing him (Duane) how he (Duane) might earn himself a living in it.

That winter he (Duane) would have a hard time, on account of his (Duane) arm, and because of an unwonted fit of activity of the police; but so long as he (Duane) was unknown to them he (Duane) would be safe if he (Duane) were careful.

Here at

``Papa'' (Hanson)
Hanson's -LRB-so they called the old man who kept the dive-RRB- he (man) might rest at ease, for
``Papa'' (he)
Hanson was
``square'' (Hanson)
--would stand by him (Hanson) so long as he (Hanson) paid, and gave him (Hanson) an hour's notice if there were to be a police raid.

Also Rosensteg, the pawnbroker, would buy anything he (Hanson) had for a third of its value, and guarantee to keep it hidden for a year.

There was an oil stove in the little cupboard of a room, and they had some supper; and then about eleven o'clock at night they sallied forth together, by a rear entrance to the place, Duane armed with a slingshot.

They came to a residence district, and he (Duane) sprang up a lamppost and blew out the light, and then the two dodged into the shelter of an area step and hid in silence.

He (Duane) had gone elsewhere, she (it) told Jurgis--he (Duane) was afraid to stay there now, on account of the police. Pretty soon a man came by, a workingman--and they let him (man) go.

Then after a long interval came the heavy tread of a policeman, and they held their breath till he (policeman) was gone.

Though half-frozen, they waited a full quarter of an hour after that--and then again came footsteps, walking briskly. Duane nudged Jurgis, and the instant the man had passed they rose up.

He (Duane) was only a couple of feet behind, and he (Duane) leaped to stop the man's mouth, while Duane held him (Duane) fast by the arms, as they had agreed.

But the man was limp and showed a tendency to fall, and so Jurgis had only to hold him (man) by the collar, while the other, with swift fingers, went through his (man) pockets--ripping open, first his (man) overcoat, and then his (man) coat, and then his (man) vest, searching inside and outside, and transferring the contents into his (man) own pockets.

Duane stole out as silently as a shadow, and a second later Jurgis heard a thud and a stifled cry. At last, after feeling of the man's fingers and in his (man) necktie, Duane whispered,

``That's all!'' (Duane/Jack Duane/Jack)

and they dragged him (Duane) to the area and dropped him (Duane) in. Then Jurgis went one way and his (Duane) friend the other, walking briskly.

There was a gold watch, for one thing, with a chain and locket; there was a silver pencil, and a matchbox, and a handful of small change, and finally a card-case.

This last Duane opened feverishly--there were letters and checks, and two theater-tickets, and at last, in the back part, a wad of bills.

The latter arrived first, and Jurgis found him (Duane) examining the

``swag. '' (him)
He (Duane) counted them--there was a twenty, five tens, four fives, and three ones.

After further examination, they burned the card-case and its contents, all but the bills, and likewise the picture of a little girl in the locket.

Duane drew a long breath. '' That lets us out! '' he (Duane) said. Then Duane took the watch and trinkets downstairs, and came back with sixteen dollars.

'' The old scoundrel said the case was filled,'' he (scoundrel) said. '' It's a lie, but he (scoundrel) knows I want the money.

'' They divided up the spoils, and Jurgis got as his (scoundrel) share fifty-five dollars and some change. He (scoundrel) protested that it was too much, but the other had agreed to divide even.

When they got up in the morning, Jurgis was sent out to buy a paper; one of the pleasures of committing a crime was the reading about it afterward.

I had a pal that always did it,'' Duane remarked, laughing--

``until one day he (Duane) read that he (Duane) had left three thousand dollars in a lower inside pocket of his (Duane) party's vest!'' (Duane/Jack Duane/Jack)

There was a half-column account of the robbery--it was evident that a gang was operating in the neighborhood, said the paper, for it was the third within a week, and the police were apparently powerless.

The victim was an insurance agent, and he (victim) had lost a hundred and ten dollars that did not belong to him (victim).

That was a good haul, he (victim) said, better than average. '' He (victim) had chanced to have his (victim) name marked on his (victim) shirt, otherwise he (victim) would not have been identified yet.

His (victim) assailant had hit him (victim) too hard, and he (victim) was suffering from concussion of the brain; and also he (victim) had been half-frozen when found, and would lose three fingers on his (victim) right hand.

Since it was Jurgis's first experience, these details naturally caused him (victim) some worriment; but the other laughed coolly--it was the way of the game, and there was no helping it.

The enterprising newspaper reporter had taken all this information to his (reporter) family, and told how they had received it. Before long Jurgis would think no more of it than they did in the yards of knocking out a bullock.

'' It's a case of us or the other fellow, and I say the other fellow, every time,'' he (fellow) observed. ''

Still,'' said Jurgis, reflectively,

``he (fellow) never did us any harm. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
'' He (fellow) was doing it to somebody as hard as he (fellow) could, you can be sure of that,'' said his (fellow) friend.

Duane had already explained to Jurgis that if a man of their trade were known he (Duane) would have to work all the time to satisfy the demands of the police.

Therefore it would be better for Jurgis to stay in hiding and never be seen in public with his (Duane) pal. But Jurgis soon got very tired of staying in hiding.

In a couple of weeks he (Duane) was feeling strong and beginning to use his (Duane) arm, and then he (Duane) could not stand it any longer.

Duane, who had done a job of some sort by himself, and made a truce with the powers, brought over Marie, his (Duane) little French girl, to share with him (Duane); but even that did not avail for long, and in the end he (Duane) had to give up arguing, and take Jurgis out and introduce him (Duane) to the saloons and

``sporting houses'' (him)
where the big crooks and
``holdup men'' (the crooks men)
hung out.

The city, which was owned by an oligarchy of business men, being nominally ruled by the people, a huge army of graft was necessary for the purpose of effecting the transfer of power.

Twice a year, in the spring and fall elections, millions of dollars were furnished by the business men and expended by this army; meetings were held and clever speakers were hired, bands played and rockets sizzled, tons of documents and reservoirs of drinks were distributed, and tens of thousands of votes were bought for cash.

And so Jurgis got a glimpse of the high-class criminal world of Chicago. And this army of graft had, of course, to be maintained the year round.

The leaders and organizers were maintained by the business men directly--aldermen and legislators by means of bribes, party officials out of the campaign funds, lobbyists and corporation lawyers in the form of salaries, contractors by means of jobs, labor union leaders by subsidies, and newspaper proprietors and editors by advertisements.

There was the police department, and the fire and water departments, and the whole balance of the civil list, from the meanest office boy to the head of a city department; and for the horde who could find no room in these, there was the world of vice and crime, there was license to seduce, to swindle and plunder and prey.

The law forbade Sunday drinking; and this had delivered the saloon-keepers into the hands of the police, and made an alliance between them necessary.

The rank and file, however, were either foisted upon the city, or else lived off the population directly. The law forbade prostitution; and this had brought the

``madames'' (unknown)
into the combination.

It was the same with the gambling-house keeper and the poolroom man, and the same with any other man or woman who had a means of getting

``graft,'' (woman)
and was willing to pay over a share of it: the green-goods man and the highwayman, the pickpocket and the sneak thief, and the receiver of stolen goods, the seller of adulterated milk, of stale fruit and diseased meat, the proprietor of unsanitary tenements, the fake doctor and the usurer, the beggar and the
``pushcart man,'' (the beggar)
the prize fighter and the professional slugger, the race-track
``tout,'' (the slugger)
the procurer, the white-slave agent, and the expert seducer of young girls.

All of these agencies of corruption were banded together, and leagued in blood brotherhood with the politician and the police; more often than not they were one and the same person,--the police captain would own the brothel he (captain) pretended to raid, the politician would open his (politician) headquarters in his (politician) saloon.

Hinkydink'' or

``Bathhouse John,'' (others)
or others of that ilk, were proprietors of the most notorious dives in Chicago, and also the
``gray wolves'' (Hinkydink proprietors wolves gamblers burglars)
of the city council, who gave away the streets of the city to the business men; and those who patronized their places were the gamblers and prize fighters who set the law at defiance, and the burglars and holdup men who kept the whole city in terror.

On election day all these powers of vice and crime were one power; they could tell within one per cent what the vote of their district would be, and they could change it at an hour's notice.

A month ago Jurgis had all but perished of starvation upon the streets; and now suddenly, as by the gift of a magic key, he (they) had entered into a world where money and all the good things of life came freely.

He (they) was introduced by his (they) friend to an Irishman named

``Buck'' (an Irishman)
Halloran, who was a political
``worker'' (Halloran)
and on the inside of things.

This man talked with Jurgis for a while, and then told him (man) that he (man) had a little plan by which a man who looked like a workingman might make some easy money; but it was a private affair, and had to be kept quiet.

Jurgis expressed himself as agreeable, and the other took him (man) that afternoon -LRB-it was Saturday-RRB- to a place where city laborers were being paid off.

Jurgis went, according to directions, and gave the name of

``Michael O'Flaherty,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
and received an envelope, which he (Michael) took around the corner and delivered to Halloran, who was waiting for him (Halloran) in a saloon.

Then he (Halloran) went again; and gave the name of

``Johann Schmidt,'' (he)
and a third time, and give the name of
``Serge Reminitsky.

'' (he)

The paymaster sat in a little booth, with a pile of envelopes before him (Serge), and two policemen standing by. ''

For this work he (Serge) received five dollars, and was told that he (Serge) might have it every week, so long as he (Serge) kept quiet.

As Jurgis was excellent at keeping quiet, he (Serge) soon won the trust of

``Buck'' (he)
Halloran, and was introduced to others as a man who could be depended upon.

This acquaintance was useful to him (acquaintance) in another way, also before long Jurgis made his (acquaintance) discovery of the meaning of

``pull,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
and just why his (acquaintance) boss, Connor, and also the pugilist bartender, had been able to send him (acquaintance) to jail.

One night there was given a ball, the

``benefit'' (a man)
of
``One-eyed Larry,'' (a man)
a lame man who played the violin in one of the big
``high-class'' (a man)
houses of prostitution on Clark Street, and was a wag and a popular character on the ``Levee.

This ball was held in a big dance hall, and was one of the occasions when the city's powers of debauchery gave themselves up to madness.

Jurgis attended and got half insane with drink, and began quarreling over a girl; his (character) arm was pretty strong by then, and he (character) set to work to clean out the place, and ended in a cell in the police station.

The police station being crowded to the doors, and stinking with

``bums,'' (police)
Jurgis did not relish staying there to sleep off his (character) liquor, and sent for Halloran, who called up the district leader and had Jurgis bailed out by telephone at four o'clock in the morning.

When he (Halloran) was arraigned that same morning, the district leader had already seen the clerk of the court and explained that Jurgis Rudkus was a decent fellow, who had been indiscreet; and so Jurgis was fined ten dollars and the fine was

``suspended'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
--which meant that he (fellow) did not have to pay for it, and never would have to pay it, unless somebody chose to bring it up against him (fellow) in the future.

Among the people Jurgis lived with now money was valued according to an entirely different standard from that of the people of Packingtown; yet, strange as it may seem, he (fellow) did a great deal less drinking than he (fellow) had as a workingman.

Halloran had quite a list of imaginary workingmen, and Jurgis got an envelope for each one. '' He (Halloran) had not the same provocations of exhaustion and hopelessness; he (Halloran) had now something to work for, to struggle for.

He (Halloran) soon found that if he (Halloran) kept his (Halloran) wits about him (Halloran), he (Halloran) would come upon new opportunities; and being naturally an active man, he (man) not only kept sober himself, but helped to steady his (man) friend, who was a good deal fonder of both wine and women than he (man).

'' Halloran he (Halloran) was sitting late one night with Duane, when a

``country customer'' (Duane/Jack Duane/Jack)
-LRB-a buyer for an out-of-town merchant-RRB- came in, a little more than half ``piped.

There was no one else in the place but the bartender, and as the man went out again Jurgis and Duane followed him (Duane); he (Duane) went round the corner, and in a dark place made by a combination of the elevated railroad and an unrented building, Jurgis leaped forward and shoved a revolver under his (Duane) nose, while Duane, with his (Duane) hat pulled over his (Duane) eyes, went through the man's pockets with lightning fingers.

They got his (Duane) watch and his (Duane)

``wad,'' (he)
and were round the corner again and into the saloon before he (Duane) could shout more than once.

The bartender, to whom they had tipped the wink, had the cellar door open for them, and they vanished, making their way by a secret entrance to a brothel next door.

One thing led to another. In the saloon where Jurgis met

``Buck '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
From the roof of this there was access to three similar places beyond.

By means of these passages the customers of any one place could be gotten out of the way, in case a falling out with the police chanced to lead to a raid; and also it was necessary to have a way of getting a girl out of reach in case of an emergency.

Thousands of them came to Chicago answering advertisements for

``servants'' (Thousands)
and
``factory hands,'' (Thousands)
and found themselves trapped by fake employment agencies, and locked up in a bawdy-house.

It was generally enough to take all their clothes away from them; but sometimes they would have to be

``doped'' (prisoners)
and kept prisoners for weeks; and meantime their parents might be telegraphing the police, and even coming on to see why nothing was done.

Occasionally there was no way of satisfying them but to let them search the place to which the girl had been traced.

For his (them) help in this little job, the bartender received twenty out of the hundred and thirty odd dollars that the pair secured; and naturally this put them on friendly terms with him (bartender), and a few days later he (bartender) introduced them to a little

``sheeny'' (he)
named Goldberger, one of the
``runners'' (Goldberger)
of the
``sporting house'' (Goldberger)
where they had been hidden.

After a few drinks Goldberger began, with some hesitation, to narrate how he (Goldberger) had had a quarrel over his (Goldberger) best girl with a professional

``cardsharp,'' (girl)
who had hit him (Goldberger) in the jaw.

The fellow was a stranger in Chicago, and if he (fellow) was found some night with his (fellow) head cracked there would be no one to care very much.

Jurgis, who by this time would cheerfully have cracked the heads of all the gamblers in Chicago, inquired what would be coming to him (fellow); at which the Jew became still more confidential, and said that he (Jew) had some tips on the New Orleans races, which he (Jew) got direct from the police captain of the district, whom he (Jew) had got out of a bad scrape, and who

``stood in'' (he)
with a big syndicate of horse owners.

Duane took all this in at once, but Jurgis had to have the whole race-track situation explained to him (Duane) before he (Duane) realized the importance of such an opportunity.

It owned the legislatures in every state in which it did business; it even owned some of the big newspapers, and made public opinion--there was no power in the land that could oppose it unless, perhaps, it were the Poolroom Trust.

It built magnificent racing parks all over the country, and by means of enormous purses it lured the people to come, and then it organized a gigantic shell game, whereby it plundered them of hundreds of millions of dollars every year.

Horse racing had once been a sport, but nowadays it was a business; a horse could be

``doped'' (the spectators)
and doctored, undertrained or overtrained; it could be made to fall at any moment--or its gait could be broken by lashing it with the whip, which all the spectators would take to be a desperate effort to keep it in the lead.

There was the gigantic Racing Trust. There were scores of such tricks; and sometimes it was the owners who played them and made fortunes

, sometimes it was the jockeys and trainers, sometimes it was outsiders, who bribed them--but most of the time it was the chiefs of the trust.

Now for instance, they were having winter racing in New Orleans and a syndicate was laying out each day's program in advance, and its agents in all the Northern cities were

``milking'' (agents)
the poolrooms.

The word came by long-distance telephone in a cipher code, just a little while before each race; and any man who could get the secret had as good as a fortune.

If Jurgis did not believe it, he (man) could try it, said the little Jew--let them meet at a certain house on the morrow and make a test.

Jurgis was willing, and so was Duane, and so they went to one of the high-class poolrooms where brokers and merchants gambled -LRB-with society women in a private room-RRB-, and they put up ten dollars each upon a horse called

``Black Beldame,'' (society women)
a six to one shot, and won.

For a secret like that they would have done a good many sluggings--but the next day Goldberger informed them that the offending gambler had got wind of what was coming to him (Goldberger), and had skipped the town.

There were ups and downs at the business; but there was always a living, inside of a jail, if not out of it.

Jurgis, hanging round in dives and gambling houses and brothels, met with the heelers of both parties, and from their conversation he (Goldberger) came to understand all the ins and outs of the game, and to hear of a number of ways in which he (Goldberger) could make himself useful about election time.

'' Halloran was a

``Democrat,'' (Halloran)
and so Jurgis became a Democrat also; but he (Democrat) was not a bitter one--the Republicans were good fellows, too, and were to have a pile of money in this next campaign.

At the last election the Republicans had paid four dollars a vote to the Democrats' three; and

``Buck'' (the Democrats)
Halloran sat one night playing cards with Jurgis and another man, who told how Halloran had been charged with the job voting a
``bunch'' (Halloran)
of thirty-seven newly landed Italians, and how he (Halloran), the narrator, had met the Republican worker who was after the very same gang, and how the three had effected a bargain, whereby the Italians were to vote half and half, for a glass of beer apiece, while the balance of the fund went to the conspirators!

Not long after this, Jurgis, wearying of the risks and vicissitudes of miscellaneous crime, was moved to give up the career for that of a politician.

Early in April the city elections were due, and that meant prosperity for all the powers of graft. '' Buck Just at this time there was a tremendous uproar being raised concerning the alliance between the criminals and the police.

For the criminal graft was one in which the business men had no direct part--it was what is called a

``side line,'' (the business men)
carried by the police.

One night it chanced that while Jack Duane was drilling a safe in a clothing store he (Duane) was caught red-handed by the night watchman, and turned over to a policeman, who chanced to know him (policeman) well, and who took the responsibility of letting him (policeman) make his (policeman) escape.

Such a howl from the newspapers followed this that Duane was slated for sacrifice, and barely got out of town in time.

And just at that juncture it happened that Jurgis was introduced to a man named Harper whom he (Harper) recognized as the night watchman at Brown's, who had been instrumental in making him (Brown) an American citizen, the first year of his (Brown) arrival at the yards.

The other was interested in the coincidence, but did not remember Jurgis--he (Brown) had handled too many

``green ones'' (he)
in his (Brown) time, he (Brown) said.

'' Wide open'' gambling and debauchery made the city pleasing to

``trade,'' (He)
but burglaries and holdups did not. He (Brown) sat in a dance hall with Jurgis and Halloran until one or two in the morning, exchanging experiences.

He (Halloran) had a long story to tell of his (Halloran) quarrel with the superintendent of his (Halloran) department, and how he (Halloran) was now a plain workingman, and a good union man as well.

It was not until some months afterward that Jurgis understood that the quarrel with the superintendent had been prearranged, and that Harper was in reality drawing a salary of twenty dollars a week from the packers for an inside report of his (Harper) union's secret proceedings.

The people of Packingtown had borne about all that they would bear, and it looked as if a strike might begin any week.

After this talk the man made inquiries concerning Jurgis, and a couple of days later he (man) came to him (man) with an interesting proposition.

He (man) was not absolutely certain, he (man) said, but he (man) thought that he (man) could get him (man) a regular salary if he (man) would come to Packingtown and do as he (man) was told, and keep his (man) mouth shut.

Harper--

``Bush'' (Harper)
Harper, he (Harper) was called--was a right-hand man of Mike Scully, the Democratic boss of the stockyards; and in the coming election there was a peculiar situation.

There had come to Scully a proposition to nominate a certain rich brewer who lived upon a swell boulevard that skirted the district, and who coveted the big badge and the

``honorable'' (a brewer)
of an alderman.

The brewer was a Jew, and had no brains, but he (brewer) was harmless, and would put up a rare campaign fund.

The yards were seething with agitation just then, said the man, speaking as a unionist. Scully had accepted the offer, and then gone to the Republicans with a proposition.

He (Scully) was not sure that he (Scully) could manage the

``sheeny,'' (he)
and he (Scully) did not mean to take any chances with his (Scully) district; let the Republicans nominate a certain obscure but amiable friend of Scully's, who was now setting tenpins in the cellar of an Ashland Avenue saloon, and he (Scully), Scully, would elect him (Scully) with the
``sheeny's'' (him)
money, and the Republicans might have the glory, which was more than they would get otherwise.

In return for this the Republicans would agree to put up no candidate the following year, when Scully himself came up for reelection as the other alderman from the ward.

To this the Republicans had assented at once; but the hell of it was--so Harper explained--that the Republicans were all of them fools--a man had to be a fool to be a Republican in the stockyards, where Scully was king.

And they didn't know how to work, and of course it would not do for the Democratic workers, the noble redskins of the War Whoop League, to support the Republican openly.

The difficulty would not have been so great except for another fact--there had been a curious development in stockyards politics in the last year or two, a new party having leaped into being.

The one image which the word

``Socialist'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
brought to Jurgis was of poor little Tamoszius Kuszleika, who had called himself one, and would go out with a couple of other men and a soap-box, and shout himself hoarse on a street corner Saturday nights.

Tamoszius had tried to explain to Jurgis what it was all about, but Jurgis, who was not of an imaginative turn, had never quite got it straight; at present he (Socialist) was content with his (Socialist) companion's explanation that the Socialists were the enemies of American institutions--could not be bought, and would not combine or make any sort of a ``dicker.

Mike Scully was very much worried over the opportunity which his (Scully) last deal gave to them--the stockyards Democrats were furious at the idea of a rich capitalist for their candidate, and while they were changing they might possibly conclude that a Socialist firebrand was preferable to a Republican bum.

And so right here was a chance for Jurgis to make himself a place in the world, explained

``Bush'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Harper; he (Harper) had been a union man, and he (Harper) was known in the yards as a workingman; he (Harper) must have hundreds of acquaintances, and as he (Harper) had never talked politics with them he (Harper) might come out as a Republican now without exciting the least suspicion.

There were barrels of money for the use of those who could deliver the goods; and Jurgis might count upon Mike Scully, who had never yet gone back on a friend.

They were the Socialists; and it was a devil of a mess, said

``Bush'' (a devil Harper)
Harper. '' Just what could he (Harper) do?

To begin with, he (Harper) would have to go to the yards and work, and he (Harper) mightn't relish that; but he (Harper) would have what he (Harper) earned, as well as the rest that came to him (Harper).

He (Harper) would get active in the union again, and perhaps try to get an office, as he (Harper), Harper, had; he (Harper) would tell all his (Harper) friends the good points of Doyle, the Republican nominee, and the bad ones of the

``sheeny'' (the ones)
; and then Scully would furnish a meeting place, and he (Scully) would start the
``Young Men's Republican Association,'' (he)
or something of that sort, and have the rich brewer's best beer by the hogshead, and fireworks and speeches, just like the War Whoop League.

Surely Jurgis must know hundreds of men who would like that sort of fun; and there would be the regular Republican leaders and workers to help him (Republican) out, and they would deliver a big enough majority on election day.

Jurgis asked, in some perplexity, and the other explained in detail. When he (Republican) had heard all this explanation to the end, Jurgis demanded:

``But how can I get a job in Packingtown? I'm blacklisted. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
At which
``Bush'' (Harper)
Harper laughed. '' I'll attend to that all right,'' he (Harper) said.

So Jurgis went out to the stockyards again, and was introduced to the political lord of the district, the boss of Chicago's mayor.

And the other replied,

``It's a go, then; I'm your man. '' (Scully/Mike Scully)
It was Scully who owned the brick-yards and the dump and the ice pond--though Jurgis did not know it.

It was Scully who was to blame for the unpaved street in which Jurgis's child had been drowned; it was Scully who had put into office the magistrate who had first sent Jurgis to jail; it was Scully who was principal stockholder in the company which had sold him (Scully) the ramshackle tenement, and then robbed him (Scully) of it.

But Jurgis knew none of these things--any more than he (Scully) knew that Scully was but a tool and puppet of the packers.

To him (Scully) Scully was a mighty power, the

``biggest'' (Scully/Mike Scully)
man he (Scully) had ever met. He (Scully) was a little, dried-up Irishman, whose hands shook.

He (Irishman) had a brief talk with his (Irishman) visitor, watching him (Irishman) with his (Irishman) ratlike eyes, and making up his (Irishman) mind about him (Irishman); and then he (Irishman) gave him (Irishman) a note to Mr. Harmon, one of the head managers of Durham's--

``The bearer, Jurgis Rudkus, is a particular friend of mine, and I would like you to find him (friend) a good place, for important reasons.

He (friend) was once indiscreet, but you will perhaps be so good as to overlook that. '' (the head managers)

Mr. Harmon looked up inquiringly when he (Harmon) read this.

'' What does he (Harmon) mean by `indiscreet'? '' he (Harmon) asked. '' I was blacklisted, sir,'' said Jurgis. At which the other frowned.

'' Blacklisted?'' he (Harmon) said. '' How do you mean? '' And Jurgis turned red with embarrassment. He (Harmon) had forgotten that a blacklist did not exist.

'' I--that is--I had difficulty in getting a place,'' he (Harmon) stammered. '' What was the matter?''

``I got into a quarrel with a foreman--not my own boss, sir--and struck him (boss).'' (unknown)

``I see,'' (unknown)
said the other, and meditated for a few moments. '' What do you wish to do? '' he (boss) asked.

'' Anything, sir,'' said Jurgis--

``only I had a broken arm this winter, and so I have to be careful.'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
``How would it suit you to be a night watchman?'' (unknown)

'' That wouldn't do, sir. I have to be among the men at night. ''

``I see--politics. Well, would it suit you to trim hogs?'' (Mr. Harmon)

And Mr. Harmon called a timekeeper and said, ``Take this man to Pat Murphy and tell him (Murphy) to find room for him (Murphy) somehow.

And so Jurgis marched into the hog-killing room, a place where, in the days gone by, he (Murphy) had come begging for a job.

Now he (Murphy) walked jauntily, and smiled to himself, seeing the frown that came to the boss's face as the timekeeper said, ``Mr. Harmon says to put this man on.

It would overcrowd his (Harmon) department and spoil the record he (Harmon) was trying to make--but he (Harmon) said not a word except ``All right.

And so Jurgis became a workingman once more; and straightway he (Harmon) sought out his (Harmon) old friends, and joined the union, and began to

``root'' (friends)
for
``Scotty'' (friends)
Doyle.

Doyle had done him (Doyle) a good turn once, he (Doyle) explained, and was really a bully chap; Doyle was a workingman himself, and would represent the workingmen--why did they want to vote for a millionaire

``sheeny,'' (the workingmen)
and what the hell had Mike Scully ever done for them that they should back his (Scully) candidates all the time?

And meantime Scully had given Jurgis a note to the Republican leader of the ward, and he (Scully) had gone there and met the crowd he (Scully) was to work with.

Already they had hired a big hall, with some of the brewer's money, and every night Jurgis brought in a dozen new members of the

``Doyle Republican Association.

Pretty soon they had a grand opening night; and there was a brass band, which marched through the streets, and fireworks and bombs and red lights in front of the hall; and there was an enormous crowd, with two overflow meetings--so that the pale and trembling candidate had to recite three times over the little speech which one of Scully's henchmen had written, and which he (Scully) had been a month learning by heart.

Best of all, the famous and eloquent Senator Spareshanks, presidential candidate, rode out in an automobile to discuss the sacred privileges of American citizenship, and protection and prosperity for the American workingman.

His (Senator) inspiriting address was quoted to the extent of half a column in all the morning newspapers, which also said that it could be stated upon excellent authority that the unexpected popularity developed by Doyle, the Republican candidate for alderman, was giving great anxiety to Mr. Scully, the chairman of the Democratic City Committee.

The chairman was still more worried when the monster torchlight procession came off, with the members of the Doyle Republican Association all in red capes and hats, and free beer for every voter in the ward--the best beer ever given away in a political campaign, as the whole electorate testified.

'' (a dozen members)

Yes, sir,'' said Jurgis. '' '' '' '' During this parade, and at innumerable cart-tail meetings as well, Jurgis labored tirelessly.

He (voter) did not make any speeches--there were lawyers and other experts for that--but he (voter) helped to manage things; distributing notices and posting placards and bringing out the crowds; and when the show was on he (voter) attended to the fireworks and the beer.

Thus in the course of the campaign he (voter) handled many hundreds of dollars of the Hebrew brewer's money, administering it with naive and touching fidelity.

Toward the end, however, he (voter) learned that he (voter) was regarded with hatred by the rest of the

``boys,'' (he)
because he (voter) compelled them either to make a poorer showing than he (voter) or to do without their share of the pie.

After that Jurgis did his (voter) best to please them, and to make up for the time he (voter) had lost before he (voter) discovered the extra bungholes of the campaign barrel.

On election morning he (voter) was out at four o'clock,

``getting out the vote'' (he)
; he (voter) had a two-horse carriage to ride in, and he (voter) went from house to house for his (voter) friends, and escorted them in triumph to the polls.

He (voter) voted half a dozen times himself, and voted some of his (voter) friends as often; he (voter) brought bunch after bunch of the newest foreigners--Lithuanians, Poles, Bohemians, Slovaks--and when he (voter) had put them through the mill he (voter) turned them over to another man to take to the next polling place.

When Jurgis first set out, the captain of the precinct gave him (captain) a hundred dollars, and three times in the course of the day he (captain) came for another hundred, and not more than twenty-five out of each lot got stuck in his (captain) own pocket.

The balance all went for actual votes, and on a day of Democratic landslides they elected

``Scotty'' (Doyle/Doyle Republican Association)
Doyle, the ex-tenpin setter, by nearly a thousand plurality--and beginning at five o'clock in the afternoon, and ending at three the next morning, Jurgis treated himself to a most unholy and horrible ``jag.

Nearly every one else in Packingtown did the same, however, for there was universal exultation over this triumph of popular government, this crushing defeat of an arrogant plutocrat by the power of the common people.

The agitation to break up the police protection of criminals was continuing, and it seemed to him (Doyle) best to

``lay low'' (him)
for the present.

He (Doyle) had nearly three hundred dollars in the bank, and might have considered himself entitled to a vacation; but he (Doyle) had an easy job, and force of habit kept him (Doyle) at it.

He (Doyle) pleased Mike Scully, also. '' Chapter 26 After the elections Jurgis stayed on in Packingtown and kept his (Doyle) job. Besides, Mike Scully, whom he (Scully) consulted, advised him (Scully) that something might

``turn up'' (him)
before long.

He (Scully) had already inquired of Aniele, and learned that Elzbieta and her (Elzbieta) family had gone downtown, and so he (Scully) gave no further thought to them.

Jurgis got himself a place in a boardinghouse with some congenial friends. He (Scully) went with a new set, now, young unmarried fellows who were

``sporty.'' (fellows)

Jurgis had long ago cast off his (Scully) fertilizer clothing, and since going into politics he (Scully) had donned a linen collar and a greasy red necktie.

He (Scully) had some reason for thinking of his (Scully) dress, for he (Scully) was making about eleven dollars a week, and two-thirds of it he (Scully) might spend upon his (Scully) pleasures without ever touching his (Scully) savings.

Sometimes he (Scully) would ride down-town with a party of friends to the cheap theaters and the music halls and other haunts with which they were familiar.

Many of the saloons in Packingtown had pool tables, and some of them bowling alleys, by means of which he (Scully) could spend his (Scully) evenings in petty gambling.

One time Jurgis got into a game on a Saturday night and won prodigiously, and because he (Scully) was a man of spirit he (Scully) stayed in with the rest and the game continued until late Sunday afternoon, and by that time he (Scully) was

``out'' (he)
over twenty dollars.

On Saturday nights, also, a number of balls were generally given in Packingtown; each man would bring his (man)

``girl'' (each man)
with him (man), paying half a dollar for a ticket, and several dollars additional for drinks in the course of the festivities, which continued until three or four o'clock in the morning, unless broken up by fighting.

Also, there were cards and dice. During all this time the same man and woman would dance together, half-stupefied with sensuality and drink.

Before long Jurgis discovered what Scully had meant by something

``turning up. '' (Scully/Mike Scully)
In May the agreement between the packers and the unions expired, and a new agreement had to be signed.

The old scale had dealt with the wages of the skilled men only; and of the members of the Meat Workers' Union about two-thirds were unskilled men.

In Chicago these latter were receiving, for the most part, eighteen and a half cents an hour, and the unions wished to make this the general wage for the next year.

It was not nearly so large a wage as it seemed--in the course of the negotiations the union officers examined time checks to the amount of ten thousand dollars, and they found that the highest wages paid had been fourteen dollars a week, and the lowest two dollars and five cents, and the average of the whole, six dollars and sixty-five cents.

And six dollars and sixty-five cents was hardly too much for a man to keep a family on, considering the fact that the price of dressed meat had increased nearly fifty per cent in the last five years, while the price of

``beef on the hoof'' (a family)
had decreased as much, it would have seemed that the packers ought to be able to pay it; but the packers were unwilling to pay it--they rejected the union demand, and to show what their purpose was, a week or two after the agreement expired they put down the wages of about a thousand men to sixteen and a half cents, and it was said that old man Jones had vowed he (Jones) would put them to fifteen before he (Jones) got through.

There were a million and a half of men in the country looking for work, a hundred thousand of them right in Chicago; and were the packers to let the union stewards march into their places and bind them to a contract that would lose them several thousand dollars a day for a year?

All this was in June; and before long the question was submitted to a referendum in the unions, and the decision was for a strike.

It was the same in all the packing house cities; and suddenly the newspapers and public woke up to face the gruesome spectacle of a meat famine.

All sorts of pleas for a reconsideration were made, but the packers were obdurate; and all the while they were reducing wages, and heading off shipments of cattle, and rushing in wagon-loads of mattresses and cots.

So the men boiled over, and one night telegrams went out from the union headquarters to all the big packing centers--to St. Paul, South Omaha, Sioux City, St. Joseph, Kansas City, East St. Louis, and New York--and the next day at noon between fifty and sixty thousand men drew off their working clothes and marched out of the factories, and the great

``Beef Strike'' (men)
was on.

Jurgis went to his (Louis) dinner, and afterward he (Louis) walked over to see Mike Scully, who lived in a fine house, upon a street which had been decently paved and lighted for his (Louis) especial benefit.

Negotiations were going on, and the yards were full of talk of a strike. Not much! Scully had gone into semi-retirement, and looked nervous and worried.

'' What do you want? '' he (Scully) demanded, when he (Scully) saw Jurgis. '' I came to see if maybe you could get me a place during the strike,'' the other replied.

In that morning's papers Jurgis had read a fierce denunciation of the packers by Scully, who had declared that if they did not treat their people better the city authorities would end the matter by tearing down their plants.

Now, therefore, Jurgis was not a little taken aback when the other demanded suddenly,

``See here, Rudkus, why don't you stick by your job?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

And Scully knit his (Scully) brows and eyed him (Scully) narrowly. Jurgis started.

``Work as a scab? '' (he)
he (Scully) cried. '' Why not?

'' demanded Scully. '' What's that to you?'' '' But--but--'' stammered Jurgis. He (Scully) had somehow taken it for granted that he (Scully) should go out with his (Scully) union.

The packers need good men, and need them bad,'' continued the other,

``and they'll treat a man right that stands by them.

'' (men)

Why don't you take your chance and fix yourself?'' '' But,'' said Jurgis,
``how could I ever be of any use to you--in politics?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

``You couldn't be it anyhow,'' (Scully/Mike Scully)
said Scully, abruptly. '' Why not?'' asked Jurgis. '' Hell, man!'' cried the other. '' Don't you know you're a Republican?

And do you think I'm always going to elect Republicans? My brewer has found out already how we served him (brewer), and there is the deuce to pay.''

Jurgis looked dumfounded. He (brewer) had never thought of that aspect of it before. '' I could be a Democrat,'' he (Democrat) said.

'' Yes,'' responded the other,

``but not right away; a man can't change his (man) politics every day. And besides, I don't need you--

there'd be nothing for you to do. And it's a long time to election day, anyhow; and what are you going to do meantime?'' (unknown)

``I thought I could count on you,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
began Jurgis. '' Yes,'' responded Scully,
``so you could--I never yet went back on a friend.

But is it fair to leave the job I got you and come to me for another? I have had a hundred fellows after me today, and what can I do?

I've put seventeen men on the city payroll to clean streets this one week, and do you think I can keep that up forever?

It wouldn't do for me to tell other men what I tell you, but you've been on the inside, and you ought to have sense enough to see for yourself.

Take my word for it, the strike will be over in a few days, and the men will be beaten; and meantime what you can get out of it will belong to you.

What have you to gain by a strike?'' (Scully/Mike Scully)

``I hadn't thought,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis. '' Exactly,'' said Scully,
``but you'd better. Do you see?'' (Scully/Mike Scully)

The men had left a long line of hogs in various stages of preparation, and the foreman was directing the feeble efforts of a score or two of clerks and stenographers and office boys to finish up the job and get them into the chilling rooms.

And Jurgis saw. He (foreman) went back to the yards, and into the workroom. Jurgis went straight up to him (foreman) and announced,

``I have come back to work, Mr. Murphy.

'' (him)

The boss's face lighted up. '' Good man! '' he (man) cried.
``Come ahead!'' (unknown)
``Just a moment,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis, checking his (man) enthusiasm.

'' I think I ought to get a little more wages. ''

``Yes,'' (unknown)
replied the other,
``of course. What do you want?

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

Jurgis had debated on the way. His (man) nerve almost failed him (man) now, but he (man) clenched his (man) hands. '' I think I ought to have' three dollars a day,'' he (man) said.

All right,'' said the other, promptly; and before the day was out our friend discovered that the clerks and stenographers and office boys were getting five dollars a day, and then he (friend) could have kicked himself!

So Jurgis became one of the new

``American heroes,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
a man whose virtues merited comparison with those of the martyrs of Lexington and Valley Forge.

The resemblance was not complete, of course, for Jurgis was generously paid and comfortably clad, and was provided with a spring cot and a mattress and three substantial meals a day; also he (man) was perfectly at ease, and safe from all peril of life and limb, save only in the case that a desire for beer should lead him (man) to venture outside of the stockyards gates.

And even in the exercise of this privilege he (man) was not left unprotected; a good part of the inadequate police force of Chicago was suddenly diverted from its work of hunting criminals, and rushed out to serve him (man).

The police, and the strikers also, were determined that there should be no violence; but there was another party interested which was minded to the contrary--and that was the press.

Jurgis quit work early, and in a spirit of bravado he (man) challenged three men of his (man) acquaintance to go outside and get a drink.

They accepted, and went through the big Halsted Street gate, where several policemen were watching, and also some union pickets, scanning sharply those who passed in and out.

Jurgis and his (man) companions went south on Halsted Street; past the hotel, and then suddenly half a dozen men started across the street toward them and proceeded to argue with them concerning the error of their ways.

As the arguments were not taken in the proper spirit, they went on to threats; and suddenly one of them jerked off the hat of one of the four and flung it over the fence.

The man started after it, and then, as a cry of

``Scab!'' (The man)
was raised and a dozen people came running out of saloons and doorways, a second man's heart failed him (man) and he (man) followed.

Jurgis and the fourth stayed long enough to give themselves the satisfaction of a quick exchange of blows, and then they, too, took to their heels and fled back of the hotel and into the yards again.

Meantime, of course, policemen were coming on a run, and as a crowd gathered other police got excited and sent in a riot call.

Jurgis knew nothing of this, but went back to

``Packers' Avenue,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
and in front of the
``Central Time Station'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
he (man) saw one of his (man) companions, breathless and wild with excitement, narrating to an ever growing throng how the four had been attacked and surrounded by a howling mob, and had been nearly torn to pieces.

While he (man) stood listening, smiling cynically, several dapper young men stood by that Jurgis saw newsboys running about with armfuls of newspapers, printed in red and black letters six inches high:

If he (man) had been able to buy all of the newspapers of the United States the next morning, he (man) might have discovered that his (man) beer-hunting exploit was being perused by some two score millions of people, and had served as a text for editorials in half the staid and solemn business-men's newspapers in the land.

'' On the first day of his (man) life as a strikebreaker VIOLENCE IN THE YARDS! STRIKEBREAKERS SURROUNDED BY FRENZIED MOB! Jurgis was to see more of this as time passed.

For the present, his (man) work being over, he (man) was free to ride into the city, by a railroad direct from the yards, or else to spend the night in a room where cots had been laid in rows.

As very few of the better class of workingmen could be got for such work, these specimens of the new American hero contained an assortment of the criminals and thugs of the city, besides Negroes and the lowest foreigners--Greeks, Roumanians, Sicilians, and Slovaks.

They had been attracted more by the prospect of disorder than by the big wages; and they made the night hideous with singing and carousing, and only went to sleep when the time came for them to get up to work.

In the morning before Jurgis had finished his (hero) breakfast,

``Pat'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Murphy ordered him (Murphy) to one of the superintendents, who questioned him (Murphy) as to his (Murphy) experience in the work of the killing room.

His (Murphy) heart began to thump with excitement, for he (Murphy) divined instantly that his (Murphy) hour had come--that he (Murphy) was to be a boss!

He (Murphy) chose the latter, but to his (Murphy) regret, for all night long gangs of strikebreakers kept arriving. Some of the foremen were union members, and many who were not had gone out with the men.

It was in the killing department that the packers had been left most in the lurch, and precisely here that they could least afford it; the smoking and canning and salting of meat might wait, and all the by-products might be wasted--but fresh meats must be had, or the restaurants and hotels and brownstone houses would feel the pinch, and then

``public opinion'' (the packers)
would take a startling turn.

An opportunity such as this would not come twice to a man; and Jurgis seized it. Yes, he (man) knew the work, the whole of it, and he (man) could teach it to others.

But if he (man) took the job and gave satisfaction he (man) would expect to keep it--they would not turn him (man) off at the end of the strike?

To which the superintendent replied that he (superintendent) might safely trust Durham's for that--they proposed to teach these unions a lesson, and most of all those foremen who had gone back on them.

Jurgis would receive five dollars a day during the strike, and twenty-five a week after it was settled. So our friend got a pair of

``slaughter pen'' (friend)
boots and
``jeans,'' (friend)
and flung himself at his (friend) task.

It was a weird sight, there on the killing beds--a throng of stupid black Negroes, and foreigners who could not understand a word that was said to them, mixed with pale-faced, hollow-chested bookkeepers and clerks, half-fainting for the tropical heat and the sickening stench of fresh blood--and all struggling to dress a dozen or two cattle in the same place where, twenty-four hours ago, the old killing gang had been speeding, with their marvelous precision, turning out four hundred carcasses every hour!

The Negroes and the

``toughs'' (The Negroes toughs)
from the Levee did not want to work, and every few minutes some of them would feel obliged to retire and recuperate.

In a couple of days Durham and Company had electric fans up to cool off the rooms for them, and even couches for them to rest on; and meantime they could go out and find a shady corner and take a

``snooze,'' (fans)
and

as there was no place for any one in particular, and no system, it might be hours before their boss discovered them.

As for the poor office employees, they did their best, moved to it by terror; thirty of them had been

``fired'' (the office employees)
in a bunch that first morning for refusing to serve, besides a number of women clerks and typewriters who had declined to act as waitresses.

He (boss) did his (boss) best, flying here and there, placing them in rows and showing them the tricks; he (boss) had never given an order in his (boss) life before, but he (boss) had taken enough of them to know, and he (boss) soon fell into the spirit of it, and roared and stormed like any old stager.

It was such a force as this that Jurgis had to organize. He (boss) had not the most tractable pupils, however.

``See hyar, boss,'' (unknown)
a big black
``buck'' (unknown)
would begin,
``ef you doan' like de way

Ah does dis job, you kin get somebody else to do it. '' (unknown)

Then a crowd would gather and listen, muttering threats.

After the first meal nearly all the steel knives had been missing, and now every Negro had one, ground to a fine point, hidden in his (Negro) boots.

There was no bringing order out of such a chaos, Jurgis soon discovered; and he (Negro) fell in with the spirit of the thing--there was no reason why he (Negro) should wear himself out with shouting.

If hides and guts were slashed and rendered useless there was no way of tracing it to any one; and if a man lay off and forgot to come back there was nothing to be gained by seeking him (man), for all the rest would quit in the meantime.

Before long Jurgis found that the custom of resting had suggested to some alert minds the possibility of registering at more than one place and earning more than one five dollars a day.

When he (man) caught a man at this he (man)

``fired'' (he)
him (man), but it chanced to be in a quiet corner, and the man tendered him (man) a ten-dollar bill and a wink, and he (man) took them.

Everything went, during the strike, and the packers paid. Of course, before long this custom spread, and Jurgis was soon making quite a good income from it.

In the face of handicaps such as these the packers counted themselves lucky if they could kill off the cattle that had been crippled in transit and the hogs that had developed disease.

Frequently, in the course of a two or three days' trip, in hot weather and without water, some hog would develop cholera, and die; and the rest would attack him (themselves) before he (themselves) had ceased kicking, and when the car was opened there would be nothing of him (themselves) left but the bones.

If all the hogs in this carload were not killed at once, they would soon be down with the dread disease, and there would be nothing to do but make them into lard.

It was the same with cattle that were gored and dying, or were limping with broken bones stuck through their flesh--they must be killed, even if brokers and buyers and superintendents had to take off their coats and help drive and cut and skin them.

And meantime, agents of the packers were gathering gangs of Negroes in the country districts of the far South, promising them five dollars a day and board, and being careful not to mention there was a strike; already carloads of them were on the way, with special rates from the railroads, and all traffic ordered out of the way.

Many towns and cities were taking advantage of the chance to clear out their jails and workhouses--in Detroit the magistrates would release every man who agreed to leave town within twenty-four hours, and agents of the packers were in the courtrooms to ship them right.

And meantime trainloads of supplies were coming in for their accommodation, including beer and whisky, so that they might not be tempted to go outside.

They hired thirty young girls in Cincinnati to

``pack fruit,'' (girls)
and when they arrived put them at work canning corned beef, and put cots for them to sleep in a public hallway, through which the men passed.

As the gangs came in day and night, under the escort of squads of police, they stowed away in unused workrooms and storerooms, and in the car sheds, crowded so closely together that the cots touched.

In some places they would use the same room for eating and sleeping, and at night the men would put their cots upon the tables, to keep away from the swarms of rats.

Ninety per cent of the men had walked out; and they faced the task of completely remaking their labor force--and with the price of meat up thirty per cent, and the public clamoring for a settlement.

They made an offer to submit the whole question at issue to arbitration; and at the end of ten days the unions accepted it, and the strike was called off.

It was agreed that all the men were to be re-employed within forty-five days, and that there was to be

``no discrimination against union men.

But with all their best efforts, the packers were demoralized. '' (the men)

This was an anxious time for Jurgis. If the men were taken back
``without discrimination,'' (the men)
he (packers) would lose his (packers) present place.

He (packers) sought out the superintendent, who smiled grimly and bade him (packers)

``wait and see. '' (him)
Durham's strikebreakers were few of them leaving.

Whether or not the

``settlement'' (the packers)
was simply a trick of the packers to gain time, or whether they really expected to break the strike and cripple the unions by the plan, cannot be said; but that night there went out from the office of Durham and Company a telegram to all the big packing centers,
``Employ no union leaders.

And in the morning, when the twenty thousand men thronged into the yards, with their dinner pails and working clothes, Jurgis stood near the door of the hog-trimming room, where he (they) had worked before the strike, and saw a throng of eager men, with a score or two of policemen watching them; and he (they) saw a superintendent come out and walk down the line, and pick out man after man that pleased him (man); and one after another came, and there were some men up near the head of the line who were never picked--they being the union stewards and delegates, and the men Jurgis had heard making speeches at the meetings.

'' (the packers)

Each time, of course, there were louder murmurings and angrier looks. Over where the cattle butchers were waiting, Jurgis heard shouts and saw a crowd, and he (man) hurried there.

One big butcher, who was president of the Packing Trades Council, had been passed over five times, and the men were wild with rage; they had appointed a committee of three to go in and see the superintendent, and the committee had made three attempts, and each time the police had clubbed them back from the door.

Then there were yells and hoots, continuing until at last the superintendent came to the door. '' We all go back or none of us do!

And the other shook his (superintendent) fist at them, and shouted,

``You went out of here like cattle, and like cattle you'll come back!'' (unknown)

'' cried a hundred voices. Then suddenly the big butcher president leaped upon a pile of stones and yelled: ``It's off, boys.

And so the cattle butchers declared a new strike on the spot; and gathering their members from the other plants, where the same trick had been played, they marched down Packers' Avenue, which was thronged with a dense mass of workers, cheering wildly.

Men who had already got to work on the killing beds dropped their tools and joined them; some galloped here and there on horseback, shouting the tidings, and within half an hour the whole of Packingtown was on strike again, and beside itself with fury.

There was quite a different tone in Packingtown after this--the place was a seething caldron of passion, and the

``scab'' (unknown)
who ventured into it fared badly.

There were one or two of these incidents each day, the newspapers detailing them, and always blaming them upon the unions.

Yet ten years before, when there were no unions in Packingtown, there was a strike, and national troops had to be called, and there were pitched battles fought at night, by the light of blazing freight trains.

Packingtown was always a center of violence; in

``Whisky Point,'' (unknown)
where there were a hundred saloons and one glue factory, there was always fighting, and always more of it in hot weather.

Any one who had taken the trouble to consult the station house blotter would have found that there was less violence that summer than ever before--and this while twenty thousand men were out of work, and with nothing to do all day but brood upon bitter wrongs.

There was no one to picture the battle the union leaders were fighting--to hold this huge army in rank, to keep it from straggling and pillaging, to cheer and encourage and guide a hundred thousand people, of a dozen different tongues, through six long weeks of hunger and disappointment and despair.

We'll all of us quit again! '' Meantime the packers had set themselves definitely to the task of making a new labor force.

Some of them were experienced workers,--butchers, salesmen, and managers from the packers' branch stores, and a few union men who had deserted from other cities; but the vast majority were

``green'' (the majority)
Negroes from the cotton districts of the far South, and they were herded into the packing plants like sheep.

There was a law forbidding the use of buildings as lodging-houses unless they were licensed for the purpose, and provided with proper windows, stairways, and fire escapes; but here, in a

``paint room,'' (a men)
reached only by an enclosed
``chute,'' (a men)
a room without a single window and only one door, a hundred men were crowded upon mattresses on the floor.

Up on the third story of the

``hog house'' (Jones)
of Jones's was a storeroom, without a window, into which they crowded seven hundred men, sleeping upon the bare springs of cots, and with a second shift to use them by day.

And when the clamor of the public led to an investigation into these conditions, and the mayor of the city was forced to order the enforcement of the law, the packers got a judge to issue an injunction forbidding him (judge) to do it!

Just at this time the mayor was boasting that he (mayor) had put an end to gambling and prize fighting in the city; but here a swarm of professional gamblers had leagued themselves with the police to fleece the strikebreakers; and any night, in the big open space in front of Brown's, one might see brawny Negroes stripped to the waist and pounding each other for money, while a howling throng of three or four thousand surged about, men and women, young white girls from the country rubbing elbows with big buck Negroes with daggers in their boots, while rows of woolly heads peered down from every window of the surrounding factories.

The ancestors of these black people had been savages in Africa; and since then they had been chattel slaves, or had been held down by a community ruled by the traditions of slavery.

A thousand or two of strikebreakers were brought in every night, and distributed among the various plants. Now for the first time they were free--free to gratify every passion, free to wreck themselves.

They were wanted to break a strike, and when it was broken they would be shipped away, and their present masters would never see them again; and so whisky and women were brought in by the carload and sold to them, and hell was let loose in the yards.

Every night there were stabbings and shootings; it was said that the packers had blank permits, which enabled them to ship dead bodies from the city without troubling the authorities.

They lodged men and women on the same floor; and with the night there began a saturnalia of debauchery--scenes such as never before had been witnessed in America.

And as the women were the dregs from the brothels of Chicago, and the men were for the most part ignorant country Negroes, the nameless diseases of vice were soon rife; and this where food was being handled which was sent out to every corner of the civilized world.

The

``Union Stockyards'' (unknown)
were never a pleasant place; but now they were not only a collection of slaughterhouses, but also the camping place of an army of fifteen or twenty thousand human beasts.

All day long the blazing midsummer sun beat down upon that square mile of abominations: upon tens of thousands of cattle crowded into pens whose wooden floors stank and steamed contagion; upon bare, blistering, cinder-strewn railroad tracks, and huge blocks of dingy meat factories, whose labyrinthine passages defied a breath of fresh air to penetrate them; and there were not merely rivers of hot blood, and car-loads of moist flesh, and rendering vats and soap caldrons, glue factories and fertilizer tanks, that smelt like the craters of hell

--there were also tons of garbage festering in the sun, and the greasy laundry of the workers hung out to dry, and dining rooms littered with food and black with flies, and toilet rooms that were open sewers.

And then at night, when this throng poured out into the streets to play--fighting, gambling, drinking and carousing, cursing and screaming, laughing and singing, playing banjoes and dancing!

They were worked in the yards all the seven days of the week, and they had their prize fights and crap games on Sunday nights as well; but then around the corner one might see a bonfire blazing, and an old, gray-headed Negress, lean and witchlike, her (their) hair flying wild and her (their) eyes blazing, yelling and chanting of the fires of perdition and the blood of the

``Lamb,'' (an Negress hair)
while men and women lay down upon the ground and moaned and screamed in convulsions of terror and remorse.

Such were the stockyards during the strike; while the unions watched in sullen despair, and the country clamored like a greedy child for its food, and the packers went grimly on their way.

Each day they added new workers, and could be more stern with the old ones--could put them on piecework, and dismiss them if they did not keep up the pace.

Jurgis was now one of their agents in this process; and he (agents) could feel the change day by day, like the slow starting up of a huge machine.

He (agents) had gotten used to being a master of men; and because of the stifling heat and the stench, and the fact that he (agents) was a

``scab'' (he)
and knew it and despised himself.

He (agents) was drinking, and developing a villainous temper, and he (agents) stormed and cursed and raged at his (agents) men, and drove them until they were ready to drop with exhaustion.

Then one day late in August, a superintendent ran into the place and shouted to Jurgis and his (superintendent) gang to drop their work and come.

They followed him (superintendent) outside, to where, in the midst of a dense throng, they saw several two-horse trucks waiting, and three patrol-wagon loads of police.

Jurgis and his (superintendent) men sprang upon one of the trucks, and the driver yelled to the crowd, and they went thundering away at a gallop.

Some steers had just escaped from the yards, and the strikers had got hold of them, and there would be the chance of a scrap!

There was a yell as soon as they were sighted, men and women rushing out of houses and saloons as they galloped by.

There were eight or ten policemen on the truck, however, and there was no disturbance until they came to a place where the street was blocked with a dense throng.

Those on the flying truck yelled a warning and the crowd scattered pell-mell, disclosing one of the steers lying in its blood.

There were a good many cattle butchers about just then, with nothing much to do, and hungry children at home; and so some one had knocked out the steer--and as a first-class man can kill and dress one in a couple of minutes, there were a good many steaks and roasts already missing.

This called for punishment, of course; and the police proceeded to administer it by leaping from the truck and cracking at every head they saw.

There were yells of rage and pain, and the terrified people fled into houses and stores, or scattered helter-skelter down the street.

Jurgis and his (man) gang joined in the sport, every man singling out his (man) victim, and striving to bring him (man) to bay and punch him (man).

If he (man) fled into a house his (man) pursuer would smash in the flimsy door and follow him (man) up the stairs, hitting every one who came within reach, and finally dragging his (man) squealing quarry from under a bed or a pile of old clothes in a closet.

They went out at the Ashland Avenue gate, and over in the direction of the

``dump. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis and two policemen chased some men into a bar-room.

One of them took shelter behind the bar, where a policeman cornered him (policeman) and proceeded to whack him (policeman) over the back and shoulders, until he (policeman) lay down and gave a chance at his (policeman) head.

The others leaped a fence in the rear, balking the second policeman, who was fat; and as he (policeman) came back, furious and cursing, a big Polish woman, the owner of the saloon, rushed in screaming, and received a poke in the stomach that doubled her (woman) up on the floor.

Meantime Jurgis, who was of a practical temper, was helping himself at the bar; and the first policeman, who had laid out his (policeman) man, joined him (policeman), handing out several more bottles, and filling his (policeman) pockets besides, and then, as he (policeman) started to leave, cleaning off all the balance with a sweep of his (policeman) club.

The din of the glass crashing to the floor brought the fat Polish woman to her (woman) feet again, but another policeman came up behind her (woman) and put his (policeman) knee into her (woman) back and his (policeman) hands over her (woman) eyes--and then called to his (policeman) companion, who went back and broke open the cash drawer and filled his (policeman) pockets with the contents.

Then the three went outside, and the man who was holding the woman gave her (woman) a shove and dashed out himself.

The gang having already got the carcass on to the truck, the party set out at a trot, followed by screams and curses, and a shower of bricks and stones from unseen enemies.

These bricks and stones would figure in the accounts of the

``riot'' (unknown)
which would be sent out to a few thousand newspapers within an hour or two; but the episode of the cash drawer would never be mentioned again, save only in the heartbreaking legends of Packingtown.

It was late in the afternoon when they got back, and they dressed out the remainder of the steer, and a couple of others that had been killed, and then knocked off for the day.

Jurgis went downtown to supper, with three friends who had been on the other trucks, and they exchanged reminiscences on the way.

To console himself he (they) had to drink a good deal, and he (they) went back to Packingtown about two o'clock in the morning, very much the worse for his (they) excursion, and, it must be confessed, entirely deserving the calamity that was in store for him (they).

As he (they) was going to the place where he (they) slept, he (they) met a painted-cheeked woman in a greasy

``kimono,'' (a woman)
and she (woman) put her (woman) arm about his (they) waist to steady him (they); they turned into a dark room they were passing--but scarcely had they taken two steps before suddenly a door swung open, and a man entered, carrying a lantern.

Afterward they drifted into a roulette parlor, and Jurgis, who was never lucky at gambling, dropped about fifteen dollars. '' Who's there?

And Jurgis started to mutter some reply; but at the same instant the man raised his (man) light, which flashed in his (man) face, so that it was possible to recognize him (man).

'' he (man) called sharply. Jurgis stood stricken dumb, and his (man) heart gave a leap like a mad thing. The man was Connor!

Connor, the boss of the loading gang! The man who had seduced his (man) wife--who had sent him (man) to prison, and wrecked his (man) home, ruined his (man) life!

Jurgis had often thought of Connor since coming back to Packingtown, but it had been as of something far off, that no longer concerned him (Connor).

Now, however, when he (Connor) saw him (Connor), alive and in the flesh, the same thing happened to him (Connor) that had happened before--a flood of rage boiled up in him (Connor), a blind frenzy seized him (Connor).

And he (Connor) flung himself at the man, and smote him (Connor) between the eyes--and then, as he (Connor) fell, seized him (Connor) by the throat and began to pound his (Connor) head upon the stones.

The lantern had been upset and extinguished, and it was so dark they could not see a thing; but they could hear Jurgis panting, and hear the thumping of his (Connor) victim's skull, and they rushed there and tried to pull him (Connor) off.

Precisely as before, Jurgis came away with a piece of his (Connor) enemy's flesh between his (Connor) teeth; and, as before, he (Connor) went on fighting with those who had interfered with him (Connor), until a policeman had come and beaten him (policeman) into insensibility.

He (policeman) stood there, staring, with the light shining full upon him (policeman). The woman began screaming, and people came rushing in. And so Jurgis spent the balance of the night in the stockyards station house.

This time, however, he (policeman) had money in his (policeman) pocket, and when he (policeman) came to his (policeman) senses he (policeman) could get something to drink, and also a messenger to take word of his (policeman) plight to

``Bush'' (a messenger)
Harper.

Harper did not appear, however, until after the prisoner, feeling very weak and ill, had been hailed into court and remanded at five hundred dollars' bail to await the result of his (Harper) victim's injuries.

Jurgis was wild about this, because a different magistrate had chanced to be on the bench, and he (magistrate) had stated that he (magistrate) had never been arrested before, and also that he (magistrate) had been attacked first--and if only someone had been there to speak a good word for him (magistrate), he (magistrate) could have been let off at once.

But Harper explained that he (Harper) had been downtown, and had not got the message. '' What's happened to you? '' he (Harper) asked.

'' I've been doing a fellow up,'' said Jurgis,

``and I've got to get five hundred dollars' bail. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
``I can arrange that all right,'' (unknown)
said the other--
``though it may cost you a few dollars, of course.

But what was the trouble?'' (a man)

'' It was a man that did me a mean trick once,'' answered Jurgis. '' Who is he (man)?''

'' He (man)'s a foreman in Brown's or used to be. His (man) name's Connor. '' And the other gave a start.

``Connor!

'' (he)

he (Connor) cried. '' Not Phil Connor!'' '' Yes,'' said Jurgis,
``that's the fellow. Why?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
``Good God!'' (man)
exclaimed the other, ``then you're in for it, old man!

``Why, he (man)'s one of Scully's biggest men--he (man)'s a member of the War-Whoop League, and they talked of sending him (man) to the legislature!

I can't help you!'' (unknown)

``Not help me! Why not?'' (Connor/Phil Connor)
Phil Connor! Great heavens!'' Jurgis sat dumb with dismay. '' Why, he (Connor) can send you to Joliet, if he (Connor) wants to!'' declared the other.

'' Can't I have Scully get me off before he (Scully) finds out about it? '' asked Jurgis, at length. '' But Scully's out of town,'' the other answered.

'' I don't even know where he (Scully) is--he (Scully)'s run away to dodge the strike. '' That was a pretty mess, indeed.

Poor Jurgis sat half-dazed. His (Scully) pull had run up against a bigger pull, and he (Scully) was down and out! '' But what am I going to do?

'' he (Scully) asked, weakly. '' How should I know?'' said the other. '' I shouldn't even dare to get bail for you--why, I might ruin myself for life!''

Again there was silence. '' Can't you do it for me,'' Jurgis asked,

``and pretend that you didn't know who I'd hit?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

'' But what good would that do you when you came to stand trial?'' asked Harper. Then he (Harper) sat buried in thought for a minute or two.

'' There's nothing--unless it's this,'' he (Harper) said. '' I could have your bail reduced; and then if you had the money you could pay it and skip.

''

``How much will it be?'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Jurgis asked, after he (Harper) had had this explained more in detail. '' I don't know,'' said the other.

'' How much do you own?''

``I've got about three hundred dollars,'' (unknown)
was the answer. '' Well,'' was Harper's reply, ``I'm not sure, but I'll try and get you off for that.

I'll take the risk for friendship's sake-- for I'd hate to see you sent to state's prison for a year or two.

And so finally Jurgis ripped out his (Harper) bankbook--which was sewed up in his (Harper) trousers--and signed an order, which

``Bush'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
Harper wrote, for all the money to be paid out.

Then the latter went and got it, and hurried to the court, and explained to the magistrate that Jurgis was a decent fellow and a friend of Scully's, who had been attacked by a strike-breaker.

So the bail was reduced to three hundred dollars, and Harper went on it himself; he (Harper) did not tell this to Jurgis, however--nor did he (Harper) tell him (Harper) that when the time for trial came it would be an easy matter for him (Harper) to avoid the forfeiting of the bail, and pocket the three hundred dollars as his (Harper) reward for the risk of offending Mike Scully!

All that he (Scully) told Jurgis was that he (Scully) was now free, and that the best thing he (Scully) could do was to clear out as quickly as possible; and so Jurgis overwhelmed with gratitude and relief, took the dollar and fourteen cents that was left him (Scully) out of all his (Scully) bank account, and put it with the two dollars and quarter that was left from his (Scully) last night's celebration, and boarded a streetcar and got off at the other end of Chicago.

He (Scully) was crippled--he (Scully) was as literally crippled as any wild animal which has lost its claws, or been torn out of its shell.

He (Scully) had been shorn, at one cut, of all those mysterious weapons whereby he (Scully) had been able to make a living easily and to escape the consequences of his (Scully) actions.

He (Scully) could no longer command a job when he (Scully) wanted it; he (Scully) could no longer steal with impunity--he (Scully) must take his (Scully) chances with the common herd.

'' Chapter 27 Poor Jurgis was now an outcast and a tramp once more. Nay worse, he (tramp) dared not mingle with the herd--he (tramp) must hide himself, for he (tramp) was one marked out for destruction.

His (tramp) old companions would betray him (tramp), for the sake of the influence they would gain thereby; and he (tramp) would be made to suffer, not merely for the offense he (tramp) had committed, but for others which would be laid at his (tramp) door, just as had been done for some poor devil on the occasion of that assault upon the

``country customer'' (some devil)
by him (devil) and Duane.

And also he (Duane) labored under another handicap now. He (Duane) had acquired new standards of living, which were not easily to be altered.

When he (Duane) had been out of work before, he (Duane) had been content if he (Duane) could sleep in a doorway or under a truck out of the rain, and if he (Duane) could get fifteen cents a day for saloon lunches.

He (Duane) must have a drink now and then, a drink for its own sake, and apart from the food that came with it.
