The craving for it was strong enough to master every other consideration--he (Duane) would have it, though it were his (Duane) last nickel and he (Duane) had to starve the balance of the day in consequence.

But now he (Duane) desired all sorts of other things, and suffered because he (Duane) had to do without them. Jurgis became once more a besieger of factory gates.

For one thing, there was the economic crisis, the million or two of men who had been out of work in the spring and summer, and were not yet all back, by any means.

And then there was the strike, with seventy thousand men and women all over the country idle for a couple of months--twenty thousand in Chicago, and many of them now seeking work throughout the city.

It did not remedy matters that a few days later the strike was given up and about half the strikers went back to work; for every one taken on, there was a

``scab'' (the strikers)
who gave up and fled.

But never since he (women) had been in Chicago had he (women) stood less chance of getting a job than just then. The ten or fifteen thousand

``green'' (The Negroes foreigners criminals)
Negroes, foreigners, and criminals were now being turned loose to shift for themselves.

Everywhere Jurgis went he (women) kept meeting them, and he (women) was in an agony of fear lest some one of them should know that he (women) was

``wanted.

He (women) would have left Chicago, only by the time he (women) had realized his (women) danger he (women) was almost penniless; and it would be better to go to jail than to be caught out in the country in the winter time.

At the end of about ten days Jurgis had only a few pennies left; and he (women) had not yet found a job--not even a day's work at anything, not a chance to carry a satchel.

Once again, as when he (women) had come out of the hospital, he (women) was bound hand and foot, and facing the grisly phantom of starvation.

Raw, naked terror possessed him (women), a maddening passion that would never leave him (women), and that wore him (women) down more quickly than the actual want of food.

The fiend reached out its scaly arms for him (fiend)--it touched him (fiend), its breath came into his (fiend) face; and he (fiend) would cry out for the awfulness of it, he (fiend) would wake up in the night, shuddering, and bathed in perspiration, and start up and flee.

He (fiend) would walk, begging for work, until he (fiend) was exhausted; he (fiend) could not remain still--he (fiend) would wander on, gaunt and haggard, gazing about him (fiend) with restless eyes.

Everywhere he (fiend) went, from one end of the vast city to the other, there were hundreds of others like him (fiend); everywhere was the sight of plenty and the merciless hand of authority waving them away.

There is one kind of prison where the man is behind bars, and everything that he (man) desires is outside; and there is another kind where the things are behind the bars, and the man is outside.

When he (man) was down to his (man) last quarter, Jurgis learned that before the bakeshops closed at night they sold out what was left at half price, and after that he (man) would go and get two loaves of stale bread for a nickel, and break them up and stuff his (man) pockets with them, munching a bit from time to time.

He (man) would not spend a penny save for this; and, after two or three days more, he (man) even became sparing of the bread, and would stop and peer into the ash barrels as he (man) walked along the streets, and now and then rake out a bit of something, shake it free from dust, and count himself just so many minutes further from the end.

So for several days he (man) had been going about, ravenous all the time, and growing weaker and weaker, and then one morning he (man) had a hideous experience, that almost broke his (man) heart.

He (man) was passing down a street lined with warehouses, and a boss offered him (boss) a job, and then, after he (boss) had started to work, turned him (boss) off because he (boss) was not strong enough.

And he (boss) stood by and saw another man put into his (boss) place, and then picked up his (boss) coat, and walked off, doing all that he (boss) could to keep from breaking down and crying like a baby.

'' (he)

He (boss) was going to die of hunger! He (boss) was lost! He (boss) was doomed! There was no hope for him (boss)! But then, with a sudden rush, his (boss) fear gave place to rage.

He (boss) would come back there after dark, and he (boss) would show that scoundrel whether he (boss) was good for anything or not!

He (boss) was still muttering this when suddenly, at the corner, he (boss) came upon a green-grocery, with a tray full of cabbages in front of it.

Jurgis, after one swift glance about him (boss), stooped and seized the biggest of them, and darted round the corner with it.

There was a hue and cry, and a score of men and boys started in chase of him (boss); but he (boss) came to an alley, and then to another branching off from it and leading him (boss) into another street, where he (boss) fell into a walk, and slipped his (boss) cabbage under his (boss) coat and went off unsuspected in the crowd.

When he (boss) had gotten a safe distance away he (boss) sat down and devoured half the cabbage raw, stowing the balance away in his (boss) pockets till the next day.

Just about this time one of the Chicago newspapers, which made much of the

``common people,'' (unknown)
opened a
``free-soup kitchen'' (unknown)
for the benefit of the unemployed.

Some people said that they did this for the sake of the advertising it gave them, and some others said that their motive was a fear lest all their readers should be starved off; but whatever the reason, the soup was thick and hot, and there was a bowl for every man, all night long.

When Jurgis heard of this, from a fellow

``hobo,'' (a fellow)
he (fellow) vowed that he (fellow) would have half a dozen bowls before morning; but, as it proved, he (fellow) was lucky to get one, for there was a line of men two blocks long before the stand, and there was just as long a line when the place was finally closed up.

This depot was within the danger line for Jurgis--in the

``Levee'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
district, where he (fellow) was known; but he (fellow) went there, all the same, for he (fellow) was desperate, and beginning to think of even the Bridewell as a place of refuge.

So far the weather had been fair, and he (fellow) had slept out every night in a vacant lot; but now there fell suddenly a shadow of the advancing winter, a chill wind from the north and a driving storm of rain.

That day Jurgis bought two drinks for the sake of the shelter, and at night he (fellow) spent his (fellow) last two pennies in a ``stale-beer dive.

This was a place kept by a Negro, who went out and drew off the old dregs of beer that lay in barrels set outside of the saloons; and after he (Negro) had doctored it with chemicals to make it

``fizz,'' (he)
he (Negro) sold it for two cents a can, the purchase of a can including the privilege of sleeping the night through upon the floor, with a mass of degraded outcasts, men and women.

All these horrors afflicted Jurgis all the more cruelly, because he (Negro) was always contrasting them with the opportunities he (Negro) had lost.

For instance, just now it was election time again--within five or six weeks the voters of the country would select a President; and he (President) heard the wretches with whom he (President) associated discussing it, and saw the streets of the city decorated with placards and banners--and what words could describe the pangs of grief and despair that shot through him (President)?

He (President) had begged all day, for his (President) very life, and found not a soul to heed him (President), until toward evening he (President) saw an old lady getting off a streetcar and helped her (lady) down with her (lady) umbrellas and bundles and then told her (lady) his (President)

``hard-luck story,'' (an lady)
and after answering all her (lady) suspicious questions satisfactorily, was taken to a restaurant and saw a quarter paid down for a meal.

And so he (President) had soup and bread, and boiled beef and potatoes and beans, and pie and coffee, and came out with his (President) skin stuffed tight as a football.

And then, through the rain and the darkness, far down the street he (President) saw red lights flaring and heard the thumping of a bass drum; and his (President) heart gave a leap, and he (President) made for the place on the run--knowing without the asking that it meant a political meeting.

He (President) fell to cursing. '' For instance, there was a night during this cold spell. The campaign had so far been characterized by what the newspapers termed ``apathy.

For some reason the people refused to get excited over the struggle, and it was almost impossible to get them to come to meetings, or to make any noise when they did come.

Those which had been held in Chicago so far had proven most dismal failures, and tonight, the speaker being no less a personage than a candidate for the vice-presidency of the nation, the political managers had been trembling with anxiety.

But a merciful providence had sent this storm of cold rain--and now all it was necessary to do was to set off a few fireworks, and thump awhile on a drum, and all the homeless wretches from a mile around would pour in and fill the hall!

And then on the morrow the newspapers would have a chance to report the tremendous ovation, and to add that it had been no

``silk-stocking'' (no audience)
audience, either, proving clearly that the high tariff sentiments of the distinguished candidate were pleasing to the wage-earners of the nation.

So Jurgis found himself in a large hall, elaborately decorated with flags and bunting; and after the chairman had made his (chairman) little speech, and the orator of the evening rose up, amid an uproar from the band--only fancy the emotions of Jurgis upon making the discovery that the personage was none other than the famous and eloquent Senator Spareshanks, who had addressed the

``Doyle Republican Association'' (Spareshanks)
at the stockyards, and helped to elect Mike Scully's tenpin setter to the Chicago Board of Aldermen!

What agony it was to him (Scully) to look back upon those golden hours, when he (Scully), too, had a place beneath the shadow of the plum tree!

When he (Scully), too, had been of the elect, through whom the country is governed--when he (Scully) had had a bung in the campaign barrel for his (Scully) own!

And this was another election in which the Republicans had all the money; and but for that one hideous accident he (Scully) might have had a share of it, instead of being where he (Scully) was!

The eloquent senator was explaining the system of protection; an ingenious device whereby the workingman permitted the manufacturer to charge him (senator) higher prices, in order that he (senator) might receive higher wages; thus taking his (senator) money out of his (senator) pocket with one hand, and putting a part of it back with the other.

'' In truth, the sight of the senator almost brought the tears into Jurgis's eyes. To the senator this unique arrangement had somehow become identified with the higher verities of the universe.

It was because of it that Columbia was the gem of the ocean; and all her (senator) future triumphs, her (senator) power and good repute among the nations, depended upon the zeal and fidelity with which each citizen held up the hands of those who were toiling to maintain it.

The name of this heroic company was

``the Grand Old Party'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
-- And here the band began to play, and Jurgis sat up with a violent start.

Singular as it may seem, Jurgis was making a desperate effort to understand what the senator was saying--to comprehend the extent of American prosperity, the enormous expansion of American commerce, and the Republic's future in the Pacific and in South America, and wherever else the oppressed were groaning.

He (senator) knew that if he (senator) allowed himself to fall asleep he (senator) would begin to snore loudly; and so he (senator) must listen--he (senator) must be interested!

But he (senator) had eaten such a big dinner, and he (senator) was so exhausted, and the hall was so warm, and his (senator) seat was so comfortable!

The senator's gaunt form began to grow dim and hazy, to tower before him (senator) and dance about, with figures of exports and imports.

Once his (senator) neighbor gave him (senator) a savage poke in the ribs, and he (senator) sat up with a start and tried to look innocent; but then he (senator) was at it again, and men began to stare at him (senator) with annoyance, and to call out in vexation.

Finally one of them called a policeman, who came and grabbed Jurgis by the collar, and jerked him (policeman) to his (policeman) feet, bewildered and terrified.

Some of the audience turned to see the commotion, and Senator Spareshanks faltered in his (Senator) speech; but a voice shouted cheerily:

``We're just firing a bum!

And so the crowd roared, and the senator smiled genially, and went on; and in a few seconds poor Jurgis found himself landed out in the rain, with a kick and a string of curses.

The reason for it was that he (senator) wanted to keep awake. Go ahead, old sport! '' (Spareshanks)

He (senator) got into the shelter of a doorway and took stock of himself.

He (senator) was not hurt, and he (senator) was not arrested--more than he (senator) had any right to expect. He (senator) swore at himself and his (senator) luck for a while, and then turned his (senator) thoughts to practical matters.

He (senator) had no money, and no place to sleep; he (senator) must begin begging again. He (senator) went out, hunching his (senator) shoulders together and shivering at the touch of the icy rain.

Coming down the street toward him (senator) was a lady, well dressed, and protected by an umbrella; and he (senator) turned and walked beside her (lady).

'' Please, ma'am,'' he (senator) began,

``could you lend me the price of a night's lodging? I'm a poor working-man-- '' (he)
Then, suddenly, he (senator) stopped short.

By the light of a street lamp he (senator) had caught sight of the lady's face. He (senator) knew her (lady). It was Alena Jasaityte, who had been the belle of his (senator) wedding feast!

Jurgis had only seen her (Jasaityte) once or twice afterward, for Juozas had thrown her (Jasaityte) over for another girl, and Alena had gone away from Packingtown, no one knew where.

Alena Jasaityte, who had looked so beautiful, and danced with such a queenly air, with Juozas Raczius, the teamster! And now he (teamster) met her (Jasaityte) here!

She (Jasaityte) was as much surprised as he (teamster) was. '' Jurgis Rudkus! '' she (Jasaityte) gasped. '' And what in the world is the matter with you?''

``I--I've had hard luck,'' (he)
he (teamster) stammered. '' I'm out of work, and I've no home and no money. And you, Alena--are you married?''

'' No,'' she (Alena) answered,

``I'm not married, but I've got a good place. '' (she)
They stood staring at each other for a few moments longer.

it happens that I've come out without my purse, and I honestly haven't a penny with me: I can do something better for you, though--I can tell you how to get help.

Finally Alena spoke again. '' Jurgis,'' she (Alena) said,

``I'd help you if I could, upon my word I would, but I can tell you where Marija is.'' (she)

Jurgis gave a start.

``Marija!'' (he)
he (it) exclaimed. '' Yes,'' said Alena;
``and she (Alena)'ll help you. She (Alena)'s got a place, and she (Alena)'s doing well

It was not much more than a year since Jurgis had left Packingtown, feeling like one escaped from jail; and it had been from Marija and Elzbieta that he (it) was escaping.

; she (Elzbieta)'ll be glad to see you. '' (Alena/Alena Jasaityte/Jasaityte)

But now, at the mere mention of them, his (it) whole being cried out with joy.

He (it) wanted to see them; he (it) wanted to go home! They would help him (it)--they would be kind to him (it). In a flash he (it) had thought over the situation.

He (it) had a good excuse for running away--his (it) grief at the death of his (it) son; and also he (it) had a good excuse for not returning--the fact that they had left Packingtown.

So she (Elzbieta) gave him (it) a number on Clark Street, adding,

``There's no need to give you my address, because Marija knows it.

'' (Clark)

All right,'' he (Clark) said,
``I'll go. '' (he)
'' And Jurgis set out, without further ado. He (Clark) found a large brownstone house of aristocratic appearance, and rang the basement bell.

A young colored girl came to the door, opening it about an inch, and gazing at him (Clark) suspiciously. '' What do you want?

'' she (girl) demanded. '' Does Marija Berczynskas live here? '' he (Clark) inquired. '' I dunno,'' said the girl. '' What you want wid her (girl)?''

``I want to see her (girl),'' (he)
said he (Clark);
``she (girl)'s a relative of mine. '' (he)
The girl hesitated a moment. Then she (girl) opened the door and said,
``Come in.'' (she)

Jurgis came and stood in the hall, and she (girl) continued:

``I'll go see. What's yo' name?'' (she)
``Tell her (girl) it's Jurgis,'' (he)
he (yo) answered, and the girl went upstairs.

She (girl) came back at the end of a minute or two, and replied,

``Dey ain't no sich person here. '' (She)
Jurgis's heart went down into his (yo) boots.

'' I was told this was where she (girl) lived! '' he (yo) cried. But the girl only shook her (girl) head. '' De lady says dey ain't no sich person here,'' she (girl) said.

And he (yo) stood for a moment, hesitating, helpless with dismay. Then he (yo) turned to go to the door. At the same instant, however, there came a knock upon it, and the girl went to open it.

Jurgis heard the shuffling of feet, and then heard her (girl) give a cry; and the next moment she (girl) sprang back, and past him (yo), her (girl) eyes shining white with terror, and bounded up the stairway, screaming at the top of her (girl) lungs:

``Police! Police! We're pinched!'' (him)
Jurgis stood for a second, bewildered. Then, seeing blue-coated forms rushing upon him (yo), he (yo) sprang after the Negress.

Her (girl) cries had been the signal for a wild uproar above; the house was full of people, and as he (yo) entered the hallway he (yo) saw them rushing hither and thither, crying and screaming with alarm.

There were men and women, the latter clad for the most part in wrappers, the former in all stages of dishabille.

At one side Jurgis caught a glimpse of a big apartment with plush-covered chairs, and tables covered with trays and glasses.

There were playing cards scattered all over the floor--one of the tables had been upset, and bottles of wine were rolling about, their contents running out upon the carpet.

There was a young girl who had fainted, and two men who were supporting her (girl); and there were a dozen others crowding toward the front door.

At the same instant a stout woman, with painted cheeks and diamonds in her (woman) ears, came running down the stairs, panting breathlessly:

``To the rear!

She (woman) led the way to a back staircase, Jurgis following; in the kitchen she (woman) pressed a spring, and a cupboard gave way and opened, disclosing a dark passageway.

Suddenly, however, there came a series of resounding blows upon it, causing the crowd to give back. Quick! '' (a stout woman)

``Go in!'' (unknown)

Scarcely had the last one disappeared, however, before there were cries from in front, and then the panic-stricken throng poured out again, exclaiming:

``They're there too!

she (woman) cried to the crowd, which now amounted to twenty or thirty, and they began to pass through. We're trapped!'' (unknown)

``Upstairs!

'' (the woman)

cried the woman, and there was another rush of the mob, women and men cursing and screaming and fighting to be first.

One flight, two, three--and then there was a ladder to the roof, with a crowd packed at the foot of it, and one man at the top, straining and struggling to lift the trap door.

It was not to be stirred, however, and when the woman shouted up to unhook it, he (man) answered:

``It's already unhooked.

There's somebody sitting on it! '' (he)

And a moment later came a voice from downstairs: ``You might as well quit, you people.

So the crowd subsided; and a few moments later several policemen came up, staring here and there, and leering at their victims.

The women took it as a joke, as if they were used to it--though if they had been pale, one could not have told, for the paint on their cheeks.

One black-eyed young girl perched herself upon the top of the balustrade, and began to kick with her (girl) slippered foot at the helmets of the policemen, until one of them caught her (girl) by the ankle and pulled her (girl) down.

On the floor below four or five other girls sat upon trunks in the hall, making fun of the procession which filed by them.

They were noisy and hilarious, and had evidently been drinking; one of them, who wore a bright red kimono, shouted and screamed in a voice that drowned out all the other sounds in the hall--and Jurgis took a glance at her (girl), and then gave a start, and a cry,

``Marija!'' (her)

We mean business, this time. '' Of the latter the men were for the most part frightened and sheepish-looking. She (girl) heard him (them), and glanced around; then she (girl) shrank back and half sprang to her (girl) feet in amazement.

'' Jurgis! '' she (girl) gasped. For a second or two they stood staring at each other. '' How did you come here?''

Marija exclaimed. '' I came to see you,'' he (them) answered.

``When?'' (unknown)
``Just now. '' (I)
'' But how did you know--who told you I was here?''

``Alena Jasaityte. I met her (Jasaityte) on the street. '' (unknown)
Again there was a silence, while they gazed at each other. The rest of the crowd was watching them, and so Marija got up and came closer to him (them).

'' And you?'' Jurgis asked. '' You live here?'' '' Yes,'' said Marija,

``I live here. '' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
Then suddenly came a hail from below:

``Get your clothes on now, girls, and come along. You'd best begin, or you'll be sorry --it's raining outside.'' (unknown)
``Br-r-r! '' (the women)
shivered some one, and the women got up and entered the various doors which lined the hallway.

``Come,'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
said Marija, and took Jurgis into her (You) room, which was a tiny place about eight by six, with a cot and a chair and a dressing stand and some dresses hanging behind the door.

There were clothes scattered about on the floor, and hopeless confusion everywhere--boxes of rouge and bottles of perfume mixed with hats and soiled dishes on the dresser, and a pair of slippers and a clock and a whisky bottle on a chair.

Marija had nothing on but a kimono and a pair of stockings; yet she (You) proceeded to dress before Jurgis, and without even taking the trouble to close the door.

He (Jurgis) had by this time divined what sort of a place he (Jurgis) was in; and he (Jurgis) had seen a great deal of the world since he (Jurgis) had left home, and was not easy to shock--and yet it gave him (Jurgis) a painful start that Marija should do this.

They had always been decent people at home, and it seemed to him (Jurgis) that the memory of old times ought to have ruled her (You).

But then he (Jurgis) laughed at himself for a fool. What was he (Jurgis), to be pretending to decency! '' How long have you been living here?

'' he (Jurgis) asked. '' Nearly a year,'' she (You) answered. '' Why did you come?''

``I had to live,'' (she)
she (You) said;
``and I couldn't see the children starve.

'' (she)

He (Jurgis) paused for a moment, watching her (You). '' You were out of work? '' he (Jurgis) asked, finally. '' I got sick,'' she (You) replied,
``and after that I had no money.

And then Stanislovas died--'' (she)

``Stanislovas dead!'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
'' Yes,'' said Marija,
``I forgot. You didn't know about it. '' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
``How did he (Jurgis) die?'' (unknown)

``Rats killed him (Jurgis),'' (she)
she (You) answered. Jurgis gave a gasp. '' Rats killed him (Jurgis)!''
``Yes,'' (she)
said the other; she (You) was bending over, lacing her (You) shoes as she (You) spoke.

He (Jurgis) used to carry cans on a long pole; and he (Jurgis)'d drink a little out of each can, and one day he (Jurgis) drank too much, and fell asleep in a corner, and got locked up in the place all night.

'' He (Jurgis) was working in an oil factory--at least he (Jurgis) was hired by the men to get their beer. When they found him (Jurgis) the rats had killed him (Jurgis) and eaten him (Jurgis) nearly all up.

'' Jurgis sat, frozen with horror. Marija went on lacing up her (You) shoes. There was a long silence. Suddenly a big policeman came to the door.

'' Hurry up, there,'' he (policeman) said. '' As quick as I can,'' said Marija, and she (You) stood up and began putting on her (You) corsets with feverish haste.

'' Are the rest of the people alive? '' asked Jurgis, finally. '' Yes,'' she (You) said. '' Where are they?'' ''

They live not far from here. They're all right now. '' '' They are working? '' he (policeman) inquired. '' Elzbieta is,'' said Marija,

``when she (Elzbieta) can.

I take care of them most of the time--I'm making plenty of money now. '' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)

Jurgis was silent for a moment.

'' Do they know you live here--how you live? '' he (policeman) asked. '' Elzbieta knows,'' answered Marija. '' I couldn't lie to her (Elzbieta).

And maybe the children have found out by this time. It's nothing to be ashamed of--we can't help it.''

``And Tamoszius?

'' (he)

he (policeman) asked. '' Does he (policeman) know? '' Marija shrugged her (Elzbieta) shoulders. '' How do I know? '' she (Elzbieta) said. ''

I haven't seen him (policeman) for over a year. He (policeman) got blood poisoning and lost one finger, and couldn't play the violin any more; and then he (policeman) went away.

He (policeman) could hardly believe that she (Elzbieta) was the same woman he (policeman) had known in the old days; she (Elzbieta) was so quiet--so hard!

'' Marija was standing in front of the glass fastening her (Elzbieta) dress. Jurgis sat staring at her (Elzbieta). It struck fear to his (policeman) heart to watch her (Elzbieta).

Then suddenly she (Elzbieta) gave a glance at him (policeman). '' You look as if you had been having a rough time of it yourself,'' she (Elzbieta) said.

'' I have,'' he (policeman) answered. '' I haven't a cent in my pockets, and nothing to do. ''

``Where have you been?'' (unknown)

'' All over. I've been hoboing it. Then I went back to the yards--just before the strike. '' He (policeman) paused for a moment, hesitating.

'' I asked for you,'' he (policeman) added. '' I found you had gone away, no one knew where. Perhaps you think I did you a dirty trick running away as I did, Marija--

'' '' No,'' she (I) answered,

``I don't blame you. We never have--any of us. You did your best--the job was too much for us.

'' (she)

She (I) paused a moment, then added:
``We were too ignorant--that was the trouble. We didn't stand any chance. If I'd known what I know

now we'd have won out. '' (She)

'' You'd have come here?'' said Jurgis. '' Yes,'' she (I) answered;
``but that's not what I meant.

I meant you--how differently you would have behaved--about Ona. '' (she)

Jurgis was silent; he (You) had never thought of that aspect of it.

When people are starving,'' the other continued,

``and they have anything with a price, they ought to sell it, I say.

'' (people)

I guess you realize it now when it's too late. Ona could have taken care of us all, in the beginning.

'' Marija spoke without emotion, as one who had come to regard things from the business point of view. '' I--

All right,'' said Marija, reaching for her (Ona) hat, which was big enough to be a drum major's, and full of ostrich feathers.

``Come on, now,'' (he)
he (policeman) said. '' Lively!'' '' '' What's going to come of this?'' Jurgis asked, as they started down the steps.

The madame's having some sort of time with the police; I don't know what it is, but maybe they'll come to terms before morning.

'' The raid, you mean? Oh, nothing--it happens to us every now and then. Anyhow, they won't do anything to you.

They always let the men off.'' '' Maybe so,'' he (policeman) responded,

``but not me-- I'm afraid I'm in for it. '' (he)

``How do you mean?'' (I)
'' I'm wanted by the police,'' he (policeman) said, lowering his (policeman) voice, though of course their conversation was in Lithuanian.

'' They'll send me up for a year or two, I'm afraid.''

``Hell!'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
said Marija. '' That's too bad. I'll see if I can't get you off.

Downstairs, where the greater part of the prisoners were now massed, she (policeman) sought out the stout personage with the diamond earrings, and had a few whispered words with her (policeman).

'' The latter then approached the police sergeant who was in charge of the raid. '' Billy,'' she (policeman) said, pointing to Jurgis,

``there's a fellow who came in to see his (fellow) sister.

He (fellow)'d just got in the door when you knocked. You aren't taking hoboes, are you? '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

The sergeant laughed as he (sergeant) looked at Jurgis.

So Jurgis slunk in among the rest of the men, who kept dodging behind each other like sheep that have smelled a wolf.

There were old men and young men, college boys and gray-beards old enough to be their grandfathers; some of them wore evening dress--there was no one among them save Jurgis who showed any signs of poverty.

'' Sorry,'' he (wolf) said,

``but the orders are every one but the servants. '' (he)
When the roundup was completed, the doors were opened and the party marched out.

Three patrol wagons were drawn up at the curb, and the whole neighborhood had turned out to see the sport; there was much chaffing, and a universal craning of necks.

The women stared about them with defiant eyes, or laughed and joked, while the men kept their heads bowed, and their hats pulled over their faces.

They were crowded into the patrol wagons as if into streetcars, and then off they went amid a din of cheers.

At the station house Jurgis gave a Polish name and was put into a cell with half a dozen others; and while these sat and talked in whispers, he (men) lay down in a corner and gave himself up to his (men) thoughts.

Yet when he (men) had thought of all humanity as vile and hideous, he (men) had somehow always excepted his (men) own family that he (men) had loved; and now this sudden horrible discovery--Marija a whore, and Elzbieta and the children living off her (Elzbieta) shame!

Jurgis might argue with himself all he (men) chose, that he (men) had done worse, and was a fool for caring--but still he (men) could not get over the shock of that sudden unveiling, he (men) could not help being sunk in grief because of it.

The depths of him (men) were troubled and shaken, memories were stirred in him (men) that had been sleeping so long he (men) had counted them dead.

Jurgis had looked into the deepest reaches of the social pit, and grown used to the sights in them. Memories of the old life--his (men) old hopes and his (men) old yearnings, his (men) old dreams of decency and independence!

He (men) saw Ona again, he (men) heard her (Ona) gentle voice pleading with him (men). He (men) saw little Antanas, whom he (men) had meant to make a man.

He (men) lived again through that day of horror when he (men) had discovered Ona's shame--God, how he (God) had suffered, what a madman he (God) had been!

How dreadful it had all seemed to him (God); and now, today, he (God) had sat and listened, and half agreed when Marija told him (God) he (God) had been a fool!

He (God) saw his (God) trembling old father, who had blessed them all with his (God) wonderful love. Yes--told him (God) that he (God) ought to have sold his (God) wife's honor and lived by it!--And

The poor little fellow, with his (fellow) frostbitten fingers and his (fellow) terror of the snow--his (fellow) wailing voice rang in Jurgis's ears, as he (fellow) lay there in the darkness, until the sweat started on his (fellow) forehead.

Now and then he (fellow) would quiver with a sudden spasm of horror, at the picture of little Stanislovas shut up in the deserted building and fighting for his (fellow) life with the rats!

All these emotions had become strangers to the soul of Jurgis; it was so long since they had troubled him (fellow) that he (fellow) had ceased to think they might ever trouble him (fellow) again.

then there was Stanislovas and his (fellow) awful fate--that brief story which Marija had narrated so calmly, with such dull indifference! Helpless, trapped, as he (fellow) was, what good did they do him (fellow)

It had been the task of his (fellow) recent life to fight them down, to crush them out of him (fellow); never in his (fellow) life would he (fellow) have suffered from them again, save that they had caught him (fellow) unawares, and overwhelmed him (fellow) before he (fellow) could protect himself.

He (fellow) heard the old voices of his (fellow) soul, he (fellow) saw its old ghosts beckoning to him (fellow), stretching out their arms to him (fellow)!

But they were far-off and shadowy, and the gulf between them was black and bottomless; they would fade away into the mists of the past once more.

Their voices would die, and never again would he (fellow) hear them--and so the last faint spark of manhood in his (fellow) soul would flicker out.

After breakfast Jurgis was driven to the court, which was crowded with the prisoners and those who had come out of curiosity or in the hope of recognizing one of the men and getting a case for blackmail.

The men were called up first, and reprimanded in a bunch, and then dismissed; but, Jurgis, to his (fellow) terror, was called separately, as being a suspicious-looking case.

It was in this very same court that he (fellow) had been tried, that time when his (fellow) sentence had been

``suspended'' (he)
; it was the same judge, and the same clerk.

The latter now stared at Jurgis, as if he (fellow) half thought that he (fellow) knew him (fellow); but the judge had no suspicions--just then his (judge) thoughts were upon a telephone message he (judge) was expecting from a friend of the police captain of the district, telling what disposition he (judge) should make of the case of

``Polly'' (he)
Simpson, as the
``madame'' (Polly Simpson)
of the house was known.

Meantime, he (Simpson) listened to the story of how Jurgis had been looking for his (Simpson) sister, and advised him (Simpson) dryly to keep his (Simpson) sister in a better place; then he (Simpson) let him (Simpson) go, and proceeded to fine each of the girls five dollars, which fines were paid in a bunch from a wad of bills which Madame Polly extracted from her (Polly) stocking.

The police had left the house, and already there were a few visitors; by evening the place would be running again, exactly as if nothing had happened.

--why should he (Simpson) ever have allowed them to torment him (Simpson)? Chapter 28 Jurgis waited outside and walked home with Marija. Meantime, Marija took Jurgis upstairs to her (Polly) room, and they sat and talked.

By daylight, Jurgis was able to observe that the color on her (Polly) cheeks was not the old natural one of abounding health; her (Polly) complexion was in reality a parchment yellow, and there were black rings under her (Polly) eyes.

'' Have you been sick? '' he (Simpson) asked. '' Sick? '' she (Polly) said. '' Hell!'' -LRB-Marija had learned to scatter her (Polly) conversation with as many oaths as a longshoreman or a mule driver.-RRB-

'' How can I ever be anything but sick, at this life? '' She (Polly) fell silent for a moment, staring ahead of her (Polly) gloomily.

'' It's morphine,'' she (Polly) said, at last. '' I seem to take more of it every day. '' '' What's that for?

'' he (driver) asked. '' It's the way of it; I don't know why. If it isn't that, it's drink. If the girls didn't booze they couldn't stand it any time at all.

And the madame always gives them dope when they first come, and they learn to like it; or else they take it for headaches and such things, and get the habit that way.

I've got it, I know ; I've tried to quit, but I never will while I'm here.''

``How long are you going to stay?

'' (he)

he (dope) asked. '' I don't know,'' she (they) said. '' Always, I guess. What else could I do?''
``Don't you save any money?'' (I)

I get a half share, two dollars and a half for each customer, and sometimes I make twenty-five or thirty dollars a night, and

``Save!'' (I)
said Marija. '' Good Lord, no! I get enough, I suppose, but it all goes. you'd think I ought to save something out of that!

But then I am charged for my room and my meals--and such prices as you never heard of; and then for extras, and drinks--for everything I get, and some I don't.

My laundry bill is nearly twenty dollars each week alone--think of that! Yet what can I do? I either have to stand it or quit, and it would be the same anywhere else.

It's all I can do to save the fifteen dollars I give Elzbieta each week, so the children can go to school.

'' Marija sat brooding in silence for a while; then, seeing that Jurgis was interested, she (Elzbieta) went on:

``That's the way they keep the girls--they let them run up debts, so they can't get away.

A young girl comes from abroad, and she (girl) doesn't know a word of English, and she (girl) gets into a place like this, and when she (girl) wants to go the madame shows her (girl) that she (girl) is a couple of hundred dollars in debt, and takes all her (girl) clothes away, and threatens to have her (girl) arrested if she (girl) doesn't stay and do as she (girl)'s told.

So she (girl) stays, and the longer she (girl) stays, the more in debt she (girl) gets. Often, too, they are girls that didn't know what they were coming to, that had hired out for housework.

Did you notice that little French girl with the yellow hair, that stood next to me in the court?'' (she)

Jurgis answered in the affirmative.

She (girl) was a store clerk, and she (girl) hired herself to a man to be sent here to work in a factory.

There were six of them, all together, and they were brought to a house just down the street from here, and this girl was put into a room alone, and they gave her (girl) some dope in her (girl) food, and when she (girl) came to she (girl) found that she (girl) had been ruined.

She (girl) cried, and screamed, and tore her (girl) hair, but she (girl) had nothing but a wrapper, and couldn't get away, and they kept her (girl) half insensible with drugs all the time, until she (girl) gave up.

'' Well, she (girl) came to America about a year ago. She (girl) never got outside of that place for ten months, and then they sent her (girl) away, because she (girl) didn't suit.

Only one of the girls that came out with her (girl) got away, and she (girl) jumped out of a second-story window one night.

I guess they'll put her (girl) out of here, too--she (girl)'s getting to have crazy fits, from drinking absinthe. There was a great fuss about that--maybe you heard of it.

''

``I did,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis,
``I heard of it afterward. '' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
-LRB-It had happened in the place where he (Jurgis) and Duane had taken refuge from their
``country customer.

There's lots of money in it,'' (Duane/Jack Duane/Jack)

said Marija--
``they get as much as forty dollars a head for girls, and they bring them from all over.

'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)

The girl had become insane, fortunately for the police.-RRB- '' There are seventeen in this place, and nine different countries among them.

In some places you might find even more. We have half a dozen French girls--I suppose it's because the madame speaks the language.

There's a place next door that's full of Japanese women, but I wouldn't live in the same house with one of them.

Marija paused for a moment or two, and then she (girl) added:

``Most of the women here are pretty decent--you'd be surprised.

I used to think they did it because they liked to; but fancy a woman selling herself to every kind of man that comes, old or young, black or white--and doing it because she (woman) likes to!'' (she)

French girls are bad, too, the worst of all, except for the Japanese. ''

``Some of them say they do,'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)
said Jurgis.

'' I know,'' said she (woman);

``they say anything. They're in, and they know they can't get out. But they didn't like it when they began--

There's a little Jewish girl here who used to run errands for a milliner, and got sick and lost her (girl) place; and she (girl) was four days on the streets without a mouthful of food, and then she (girl) went to a place just around the corner and offered herself, and they made her (girl) give up her (girl) clothes before they would give her (girl) a bite to eat!

you'd find out--it's always misery! '' (she)

Marija sat for a minute or two, brooding somberly.
``Tell me about yourself, Jurgis,'' (she)
she (girl) said, suddenly.

So he (girl) told her (girl) the long story of his (girl) adventures since his (girl) flight from home; his (girl) life as a tramp, and his (girl) work in the freight tunnels, and the accident; and then of Jack Duane, and of his (Duane) political career in the stockyards, and his (Duane) downfall and subsequent failures.

Marija listened with sympathy; it was easy to believe the tale of his (Duane) late starvation, for his (Duane) face showed it all.

'' Where have you been? '' '' You found me just in the nick of time,'' she (girl) said. '' I'll stand by you--

I'll help you till you can get some work. ''

``I don't like to let you--'' (he)
he (Duane) began. '' Why not?

Because I'm here?'' '' No, not that,'' he (Duane) said. '' But I went off and left you-- ''

``Nonsense!'' (I)
said Marija.

'' Don't think about it. I don't blame you.''

``You must be hungry,'' (she)
she (girl) said, after a minute or two. ''

You stay here to lunch--I'll have something up in the room. '' She (girl) pressed a button, and a colored woman came to the door and took her (woman) order.

It's nice to have somebody to wait on you,'' she (woman) observed, with a laugh, as she (woman) lay back on the bed.

As the prison breakfast had not been liberal, Jurgis had a good appetite, and they had a little feast together, talking meanwhile of Elzbieta and the children and old times.

Shortly before they were through, there came another colored girl, with the message that the

``madame'' (another girl)
wanted Marija--
``Lithuanian Mary,'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
as they called her (Mary) here.

So he (woman) got up, and she (Mary) gave him (woman) the new address of the family, a tenement over in the Ghetto district.

'' '' That means you have to go,'' she (Mary) said to Jurgis. '' You go there,'' she (Mary) said. '' They'll be glad to see you.

'' But Jurgis stood hesitating. '' I--I don't like to,'' he (woman) said. '' Honest, Marija, why don't you just give me a little money and let me look for work first?

''

``How do you need money? '' (unknown)
was her (Mary) reply. '' All you want is something to eat and a place to sleep, isn't it?''

Yes,'' he (woman) said;

``but then I don't like to go there after I left them--and while I have nothing to do, and while you--you--'' (he)

What are you talking?--I won't give you money,'' she (Mary) added, as she (Mary) followed him (woman) to the door,

``because you'll drink it up, and do yourself harm.

'' (him)

``Go on!'' (Marija/Marija Berczynskas)
said Marija, giving him (woman) a push. '' Here's a quarter for you now, and go along, and they'll be so glad to have you back

, you won't have time to feel ashamed. Good-by! '' So Jurgis went out, and walked down the street to think it over.

He (woman) decided that he (woman) would first try to get work, and so he (woman) put in the rest of the day wandering here and there among factories and warehouses without success.

Then, when it was nearly dark, he (woman) concluded to go home, and set out; but he (woman) came to a restaurant, and went in and spent his (woman) quarter for a meal; and when he (woman) came out he (woman) changed his (woman) mind--the night was pleasant, and he (woman) would sleep somewhere outside, and put in the morrow hunting, and so have one more chance of a job.

So he (woman) started away again, when suddenly he (woman) chanced to look about him (woman), and found that he (woman) was walking down the same street and past the same hall where he (woman) had listened to the political speech the night before.

There was no red fire and no band now, but there was a sign out, announcing a meeting, and a stream of people pouring in through the entrance.

In a flash Jurgis had decided that he (woman) would chance it once more, and sit down and rest while making up his (woman) mind what to do.

There were no decorations in the hall this time; but there was quite a crowd upon the platform, and almost every seat in the place was filled.

There was no one taking tickets, so it must be a free show again. He (woman) entered. He (woman) took one of the last, far in the rear, and straightway forgot all about his (woman) surroundings.

Would Elzbieta think that he (woman) had come to sponge off her (Elzbieta), or would she (Elzbieta) understand that he (woman) meant to get to work again and do his (woman) share?

If only he (woman) could get some sort of a job before he (woman) went--if that last boss had only been willing to try him (woman)!

A tremendous roar had burst from the throats of the crowd, which by this time had packed the hall to the very doors.

Would she (Elzbieta) be decent to him (woman), or would she (Elzbieta) scold him (woman)? --Then suddenly Jurgis looked up. Men and women were standing up, waving handkerchiefs, shouting, yelling.

Evidently the speaker had arrived, thought Jurgis; what fools they were making of themselves! What were they expecting to get out of it anyhow--what had they to do with elections, with governing the country?

Jurgis had been behind the scenes in politics. He (speaker) went back to his (speaker) thoughts, but with one further fact to reckon with--that he (speaker) was caught here.

The hall was now filled to the doors; and after the meeting it would be too late for him (speaker) to go home, so he (speaker) would have to make the best of it outside.

Perhaps it would be better to go home in the morning, anyway, for the children would be at school, and he (speaker) and Elzbieta could have a quiet explanation.

She (Elzbieta) always had been a reasonable person; and he (speaker) really did mean to do right. He (speaker) would manage to persuade her (Elzbieta) of it--and besides, Marija was willing, and Marija was furnishing the money.

So Jurgis went on meditating; until finally, when he (speaker) had been an hour or two in the hall, there began to prepare itself a repetition of the dismal catastrophe of the night before.

Speaking had been going on all the time, and the audience was clapping its hands and shouting, thrilling with excitement; and little by little the sounds were beginning to blur in Jurgis's ears, and his (speaker) thoughts were beginning to run together, and his (speaker) head to wobble and nod.

He (speaker) caught himself many times, as usual, and made desperate resolutions; but the hall was hot and close, and his (speaker) long walk and is dinner were too much for him (speaker)--in the end his (speaker) head sank forward and he (speaker) went off again.

If Elzbieta were ugly, he (speaker) would tell her (Elzbieta) that in so many words. And then again someone nudged him (speaker), and he (speaker) sat up with his (speaker) old terrified start!

He (speaker) fixed his (speaker) eyes ahead of him (speaker), with painful intensity, staring at the platform as if nothing else ever had interested him (speaker), or ever could interest him (speaker), all his (speaker) life.

He (speaker) had been snoring again, of course! And now what? He (speaker) imagined the angry exclamations, the hostile glances; he (speaker) imagined the policeman striding toward him (speaker)--reaching for his (speaker) neck.

Or was he (speaker) to have one more chance? Were they going to let him (speaker) alone this time? He (speaker) sat trembling; waiting--

And then suddenly came a voice in his (speaker) ear, a woman's voice, gentle and sweet,

``If you would try to listen, comrade, perhaps you would be interested.

'' (a woman)

Jurgis was more startled by that than he (comrade) would have been by the touch of a policeman. He (comrade) still kept his (comrade) eyes fixed ahead, and did not stir; but his (comrade) heart gave a great leap.

He (comrade) waited long, long; and at last, when he (comrade) was sure that he (comrade) was no longer watched, he (comrade) stole a glance out of the corner of his (comrade) eyes at the woman who sat beside him (comrade).

Comrade! Who was it that called him (comrade)

``comrade'' (him)
? She (woman) was young and beautiful; she (woman) wore fine clothes, and was what is called a
``lady.

'' (she)

And she (woman) called him (comrade)
``comrade'' (him)
! He (comrade) turned a little, carefully, so that he (comrade) could see her (woman) better; then he (comrade) began to watch her (woman), fascinated.

She (woman) had apparently forgotten all about him (comrade), and was looking toward the platform. A man was speaking there--Jurgis heard his (man) voice vaguely; but all his (man) thoughts were for this woman's face.

A feeling of alarm stole over him (man) as he (man) stared at her (woman). It made his (man) flesh creep. What was the matter with her (woman), what could be going on, to affect any one like that?

She (woman) sat as one turned to stone, her (woman) hands clenched tightly in her (woman) lap, so tightly that he (man) could see the cords standing out in her (woman) wrists.

There was a look of excitement upon her (woman) face, of tense effort, as of one struggling mightily, or witnessing a struggle.

Her (woman) bosom rose and fell as she (woman) breathed, and her (woman) excitement seemed to mount higher and higher, and then to sink away again, like a boat tossing upon ocean surges.

There was a faint quivering of her (woman) nostrils; and now and then she (woman) would moisten her (woman) lips with feverish haste. What was it?

What was the matter? It must be something that the man was saying, up there on the platform. What sort of a man was he (man)?

It was like coming suddenly upon some wild sight of nature--a mountain forest lashed by a tempest, a ship tossed about upon a stormy sea.

And what sort of thing was this, anyhow?--So all at once it occurred to Jurgis to look at the speaker. Jurgis had an unpleasant sensation, a sense of confusion, of disorder, of wild and meaningless uproar.

The man was tall and gaunt, as haggard as his (man) auditor himself; a thin black beard covered half of his (man) face, and one could see only two black hollows where the eyes were.

He (man) was speaking rapidly, in great excitement; he (man) used many gestures--as he (man) spoke he (man) moved here and there upon the stage, reaching with his (man) long arms as if to seize each person in his (man) audience.

His (man) voice was deep, like an organ; it was some time, however, before Jurgis thought of the voice--he (man) was too much occupied with his (man) eyes to think of what the man was saying.

But suddenly it seemed as if the speaker had begun pointing straight at him (speaker), as if he (speaker) had singled him (speaker) out particularly for his (speaker) remarks; and so Jurgis became suddenly aware of his (speaker) voice, trembling, vibrant with emotion, with pain and longing, with a burden of things unutterable, not to be compassed by words.

You listen to these things,'' the man was saying,

``and you say, `Yes, they are true, but they have been that way always.'

To hear it was to be suddenly arrested, to be gripped, transfixed. '' (the man)

Or you say, `Maybe it will come, but not in my time--it will not help me.'

And so you return to your daily round of toil, you go back to be ground up for profits in the world-wide mill of economic might!

To toil long hours for another's advantage; to live in mean and squalid homes, to work in dangerous and unhealthful places; to wrestle with the specters of hunger and privation, to take your chances of accident, disease, and death.

And each day the struggle becomes fiercer, the pace more cruel; each day you have to toil a little harder, and feel the iron hand of circumstance close upon you a little tighter.

Months pass, years maybe--and then you come again; and again I am here to plead with you, to know if want and misery have yet done their work with you, if injustice and oppression have yet opened your eyes!

There is no wilderness where I can hide from these things, there is no haven where I can escape them; though I travel to the ends of the earth, I find the same accursed system--I find that all the fair and noble impulses of humanity, the dreams of poets and the agonies of martyrs, are shackled and bound in the service of organized and predatory Greed!

, I cannot be silent; therefore I cast aside comfort and happiness, health and good repute--and go out into the world and cry out the pain of my spirit!

Therefore I am not to be silenced by poverty and sickness, not by hatred and obloquy, by threats and ridicule--not by prison and persecution, if they should come--not by any power that is upon the earth or above the earth, that was, or is, or ever can be created.

If I fail tonight, I can only try tomorrow; knowing that the fault must be mine--that if once the vision of my soul were spoken upon earth, if once the anguish of its defeat were uttered in human speech, it would break the stoutest barriers of prejudice, it would shake the most sluggish soul to action!

It would abash the most cynical, it would terrify the most selfish; and the voice of mockery would be silenced, and fraud and falsehood would slink back into their dens, and the truth would stand forth alone!

I shall still be waiting--there is nothing else that I can do. And therefore I cannot rest For I speak with the voice of the millions who are voiceless!

Of the disinherited of life, for whom there is no respite and no deliverance, to whom the world is a prison, a dungeon of torture, a tomb!

With the voice of the little child who toils tonight in a Southern cotton mill, staggering with exhaustion, numb with agony, and knowing no hope but the grave!

Of the mother who sews by candlelight in her (mother) tenement garret, weary and weeping, smitten with the mortal hunger of her (mother) babes!

Of the man who lies upon a bed of rags, wrestling in his (man) last sickness and leaving his (man) loved ones to perish!

Of the young girl who, somewhere at this moment, is walking the streets of this horrible city, beaten and starving, and making her (girl) choice between the brothel and the lake!

With the voice of those, whoever and wherever they may be, who are caught beneath the wheels of the Juggernaut of Greed!

Of the everlasting soul of Man, arising from the dust; breaking its way out of its prison--rending the bands of oppression and ignorance--groping its way to the light!''

There was an instant of silence, while men caught their breaths, and then like a single sound there came a cry from a thousand people.

Through it all Jurgis sat still, motionless and rigid, his (Man) eyes fixed upon the speaker; he (Man) was trembling, smitten with wonder.

Of them that are oppressed and have no comforter! With the voice of humanity, calling for deliverance! The speaker paused. Suddenly the man raised his (man) hands, and silence fell, and he (man) began again.

I plead with you,'' he (man) said,

``whoever you may be, provided that you care about the truth; but most of all I plead with working-man, with those to whom the evils I portray are not mere matters of sentiment, to be dallied and toyed with, and then perhaps put aside and forgotten--to whom they are the grim and relentless realities of the daily grind, the chains upon their limbs, the lash upon their backs, the iron in their souls.

To you, whose lot it is to sow that others may reap, to labor and obey, and ask no more than the wages of a beast of burden, the food and shelter to keep you alive from day to day.

'' (he)

To you, working-men! To you, the toilers, who have made this land, and have no voice in its councils! It is to you that I come with my message of salvation, it is to you that I appeal.

I know how much it is to ask of you--I know, for I have been in your place, I have lived your life, and there is no man before me here tonight who knows it better.

I have known what it is to be a street-waif, a bootblack, living upon a crust of bread and sleeping in cellar stairways and under empty wagons.

I have known what it is to dare and to aspire, to dream mighty dreams and to see them perish--to see all the fair flowers of my spirit trampled into the mire by the wild-beast powers of my life.

I know what is the price that a working-man pays for knowledge--I have paid for it with food and sleep, with agony of body and mind, with health, almost with life itself; and so, when I come to you with a story of hope and freedom, with the vision of a new earth to be created, of a new labor to be dared, I am not surprised that I find you sordid and material, sluggish and incredulous.

That I do not despair is because I know also the forces that are driving behind you--because I know the raging lash of poverty, the sting of contempt and mastership, `the insolence of office and the spurns.'

Because I feel sure that in the crowd that has come to me tonight, no matter how many may be dull and heedless, no matter how many may have come out of idle curiosity, or in order to ridicule--there will be some one man whom pain and suffering have made desperate, whom some chance vision of wrong and horror has startled and shocked into attention.

And to him (man) my words will come like a sudden flash of lightning to one who travels in darkness--revealing the way before him (man), the perils and the obstacles--solving all problems, making all difficulties clear!

The scales will fall from his (man) eyes, the shackles will be torn from his (man) limbs--he (man) will leap up with a cry of thankfulness, he (man) will stride forth a free man at last!

A man who will never more be trapped--whom no blandishments will cajole, whom no threats will frighten; who from tonight on will move forward, and not backward, who will study and understand, who will gird on his (man) sword and take his (man) place in the army of his (man) comrades and brothers.

Who will carry the good tidings to others, as I have carried them to him (man)--priceless gift of liberty and light that is neither mine nor his (man), but is the heritage of the soul of man!

You have lived so long in the toil and heat that your senses are dulled, your souls are numbed; but realize once in your lives this world in which you dwell--tear off the rags of its customs and conventions--behold it as it is, in all its hideous nakedness!

Realize that out upon the plains of Manchuria tonight two hostile armies are facing each other--that now, while we are seated here, a million human beings may be hurled at each other's throats, striving with the fury of maniacs to tear each other to pieces!

A man delivered from his (man) self-created slavery! Working-men, working-men--comrades! open your eyes and look about you! Realize it, realize it! And this in the twentieth century, nineteen hundred years since the Prince of Peace was born on earth!

Nineteen hundred years that his (Prince) words have been preached as divine, and here two armies of men are rending and tearing each other like the wild beasts of the forest!

We have schools and colleges, newspapers and books; we have searched the heavens and the earth, we have weighed and probed and reasoned--and all to equip men to destroy each other!

We call it War, and pass it by--but do not put me off with platitudes and conventions--come with me, come with me--realize it!

Philosophers have reasoned, prophets have denounced, poets have wept and pleaded--and still this hideous Monster roams at large! See the bodies of men pierced by bullets, blown into pieces by bursting shells!

Hear the crunching of the bayonet, plunged into human flesh; hear the groans and shrieks of agony, see the faces of men crazed by pain, turned into fiends by fury and hate!

Put your hand upon that piece of flesh--it is hot and quivering--just now it was a part of a man! This blood is still steaming--it was driven by a human heart!

And we know it, and read of it, and take it for granted; our papers tell of it, and the presses are not stopped--our churches know of it, and do not close their doors--the people behold it, and do not rise up in horror and revolution!

Almighty God! and this goes on--it is systematic, organized, premeditated! '' Or perhaps Manchuria is too far away for you--come home with me then, come here to Chicago.

Here in this city to-night ten thousand women are shut up in foul pens, and driven by hunger to sell their bodies to live.

And these women are made in the image of your mothers, they may be your sisters, your daughters; the child whom you left at home tonight, whose laughing eyes will greet you in the morning--that fate may be waiting for her (women)!

To-night in Chicago there are ten thousand men, homeless and wretched, willing to work and begging for a chance, yet starving, and fronting in terror the awful winter cold!

Tonight in Chicago there are a hundred thousand children wearing out their strength and blasting their lives in the effort to earn their bread!

There are a hundred thousand mothers who are living in misery and squalor, struggling to earn enough to feed their little ones!

And we know it, we make it a jest! There are a hundred thousand old people, cast off and helpless, waiting for death to take them from their torments!

There are a million people, men and women and children, who share the curse of the wage-slave; who toil every hour they can stand and see, for just enough to keep them alive; who are condemned till the end of their days to monotony and weariness, to hunger and misery, to heat and cold, to dirt and disease, to ignorance and drunkenness and vice!

And then turn over the page with me, and gaze upon the other side of the picture. There are a thousand--ten thousand, maybe--who are the masters of these slaves, who own their toil.

They do nothing to earn what they receive, they do not even have to ask for it--it comes to them of itself, their only care is to dispose of it.

They live in palaces, they riot in luxury and extravagance--such as no words can describe, as makes the imagination reel and stagger, makes the soul grow sick and faint.

They spend hundreds of dollars for a pair of shoes, a handkerchief, a garter; they spend millions for horses and automobiles and yachts, for palaces and banquets, for little shiny stones with which to deck their bodies.

Their life is a contest among themselves for supremacy in ostentation and recklessness, in the destroying of useful and necessary things, in the wasting of the labor and the lives of their fellow creatures, the toil and anguish of the nations, the sweat and tears and blood of the human race!

It is all theirs--it comes to them; just as all the springs pour into streamlets, and the streamlets into rivers, and the rivers into the oceans--so, automatically and inevitably, all the wealth of society comes to them.

The farmer tills the soil, the miner digs in the earth, the weaver tends the loom, the mason carves the stone; the clever man invents, the shrewd man directs, the wise man studies, the inspired man sings--and all the result, the products of the labor of brain and muscle, are gathered into one stupendous stream and poured into their laps!

The whole of society is in their grip, the whole labor of the world lies at their mercy--and like fierce wolves they rend and destroy, like ravening vultures they devour and tear!

The whole power of mankind belongs to them, forever and beyond recall--do what it can, strive as it will, humanity lives for them and dies for them!

They own not merely the labor of society, they have bought the governments; and everywhere they use their raped and stolen power to intrench themselves in their privileges, to dig wider and deeper the channels through which the river of profits flows to

You have been brought up to it, you plod on like beasts of burden, thinking only of the day and its pain--yet is there a man among you who can believe that such a system will continue forever--is there a man here in this audience tonight so hardened and debased that he (man) dare rise up before me and say that he (man) believes it can continue forever; that the product of the labor of society, the means of existence of the human race, will always belong to idlers and parasites, to be spent for the gratification of vanity and lust--to be spent for any purpose whatever, to be at the disposal of any individual will whatever--that somehow, somewhere, the labor of humanity will not belong to humanity, to be used for the purposes of humanity, to be controlled by the will of humanity?

them!--And you, workingmen, workingmen! And if this is ever to be, how is it to be--what power is there that will bring it about?

Will they forge you the sword of your deliverance, will they marshal you the army and lead it to the fray?

Will their wealth be spent for the purpose--will they build colleges and churches to teach you, will they print papers to herald your progress, and organize political parties to guide and carry on the struggle?

Will it be the task of your masters , do you think--will they write the charter of your liberties? Can you not see that the task is your task--yours to dream, yours to resolve, yours to execute?

That if ever it is carried out, it will be in the face of every obstacle that wealth and mastership can oppose--in the face of ridicule and slander, of hatred and persecution, of the bludgeon and the jail?

That it will be by the power of your naked bosoms, opposed to the rage of oppression! By the grim and bitter teaching of blind and merciless affliction!

By the sad and lonely hunger of the spirit; by seeking and striving and yearning, by heartache and despairing, by agony and sweat of blood!

It will be by money paid for with hunger, by knowledge stolen from sleep, by thoughts communicated under the shadow of the gallows!

It will be a movement beginning in the far-off past, a thing obscure and unhonored, a thing easy to ridicule, easy to despise; a thing unlovely, wearing the aspect of vengeance and hate--but to you, the working-man, the wage-slave, calling with a voice insistent, imperious--with a voice that you cannot escape, wherever upon the earth you may be!

With the voice of all your wrongs, with the voice of all your desires; with the voice of your duty and your hope--of everything in the world that is worth while to you!

By the painful gropings of the untutored mind, by the feeble stammerings of the uncultured voice! The voice of the poor, demanding that poverty shall cease!

The voice of power, wrought out of suffering--of resolution, crushed out of weakness--of joy and courage, born in the bottomless pit of anguish and despair!

The voice of Labor, despised and outraged; a mighty giant, lying prostrate--mountainous, colossal, but blinded, bound, and ignorant of his (you) strength.

And now a dream of resistance haunts him (you), hope battling with fear; until suddenly he (you) stirs, and a fetter snaps--and a thrill shoots through him (you), to the farthest ends of his (you) huge body, and in a flash the dream becomes an act!

He (you) starts, he (you) lifts himself; and the bands are shattered, the burdens roll off him (you)--he (you) rises--towering, gigantic; he (you) springs to his (you) feet, he (you) shouts in his (you) newborn exultation--

'' And the speaker's voice broke suddenly, with the stress of his (you) feelings; he (you) stood with his (you) arms stretched out above him (you), and the power of his (you) vision seemed to lift him (you) from the floor.

The voice of the oppressed, pronouncing the doom of oppression! The audience came to its feet with a yell; men waved their arms, laughing aloud in their excitement.

And Jurgis was with them, he (you) was shouting to tear his (you) throat; shouting because he (you) could not help it, because the stress of his (you) feeling was more than he (you) could bear.

It was his (you) presence, it was his (you) voice: a voice with strange intonations that rang through the chambers of the soul like the clanging of a bell--that gripped the listener like a mighty hand about his (listener) body, that shook him (listener) and startled him (listener) with sudden fright, with a sense of things not of earth, of mysteries never spoken before, of presences of awe and terror!

There was an unfolding of vistas before him (listener), a breaking of the ground beneath him (listener), an upheaving, a stirring, a trembling; he (listener) felt himself suddenly a mere man no longer--there were powers within him (listener) undreamed of, there were demon forces contending, age-long wonders struggling to be born; and he (listener) sat oppressed with pain and joy, while a tingling stole down into his (listener) finger tips, and his (listener) breath came hard and fast.

The sentences of this man were to Jurgis like the crashing of thunder in his (listener) soul; a flood of emotions surged up in him (listener)--all his (listener) old hopes and longings, his (listener) old griefs and rages and despairs.

All that he (listener) had ever felt in his (listener) whole life seemed to come back to him (listener) at once, and with one new emotion, hardly to be described.

That he (listener) should have suffered such oppressions and such horrors was bad enough; but that he (listener) should have been crushed and beaten by them, that he (listener) should have submitted, and forgotten, and lived in peace--ah, truly that was a thing not to be put into words, a thing not to be borne by a human creature, a thing of terror and madness!

``What,'' (the prophet)
asks the prophet,
``is the murder of them that kill the body, to the murder of them that kill the soul?

And Jurgis was a man whose soul had been murdered, who had ceased to hope and to struggle--who had made terms with degradation and despair; and now, suddenly, in one awful convulsion, the black and hideous fact was made plain to him (man)!

There was a falling in of all the pillars of his (man) soul, the sky seemed to split above him (man)--he (man) stood there, with his (man) clenched hands upraised, his (man) eyes bloodshot, and the veins standing out purple in his (man) face, roaring in the voice of a wild beast, frantic, incoherent, maniacal.

It was not merely the man's words, the torrent of his (man) eloquence. '' (the prophet)

And when he (man) could shout no more he (man) still stood there, gasping, and whispering hoarsely to himself:

``By God! By God! By God!'' (he)
Chapter 29 The man had gone back to a seat upon the platform, and Jurgis realized that his (man) speech was over.

The applause continued for several minutes; and then some one started a song, and the crowd took it up, and the place shook with it.

Jurgis had never heard it, and he (man) could not make out the words, but the wild and wonderful spirit of it seized upon him (man)--

it was the

``Marseillaise!'' (him)
As stanza after stanza of it thundered forth, he (man) sat with his (man) hands clasped, trembling in every nerve.

He (man) could not think at all, he (man) was stunned; yet he (man) knew that in the mighty upheaval that had taken place in his (man) soul, a new man had been born.

He (man) had been torn out of the jaws of destruction, he (man) had been delivered from the thraldom of despair; the whole world had been changed for him (man)--he (man) was free, he (man) was free!

Even if he (man) were to suffer as he (man) had before, even if he (man) were to beg and starve, nothing would be the same to him (man); he (man) would understand it, and bear it.

He (man) would no longer be the sport of circumstances, he (man) would be a man, with a will and a purpose; he (man) would have something to fight for, something to die for, if need be!

Here were men who would show him (man) and help him (man); and he (man) would have friends and allies, he (man) would dwell in the sight of justice, and walk arm in arm with power.

He (man) had never been so stirred in his (man) life--it was a miracle that had been wrought in him (man). The audience subsided again, and Jurgis sat back.

The chairman of the meeting came forward and began to speak. His (chairman) voice sounded thin and futile after the other's, and to Jurgis it seemed a profanation.

The chairman was explaining that a collection would now be taken up to defray the expenses of the meeting, and for the benefit of the campaign fund of the party.

Why should any one else speak, after that miraculous man--why should they not all sit in silence? Jurgis heard; but he (man) had not a penny to give, and so his (man) thoughts went elsewhere again.

He (man) kept his (man) eyes fixed on the orator, who sat in an armchair, his (man) head leaning on his (man) hand and his (man) attitude indicating exhaustion.

But suddenly he (man) stood up again, and Jurgis heard the chairman of the meeting saying that the speaker would now answer any questions which the audience might care to put to him (speaker).

The man came forward, and some one--a woman--arose and asked about some opinion the speaker had expressed concerning Tolstoy. Jurgis had never heard of Tolstoy, and did not care anything about him (Tolstoy).

The thing was not to talk, but to do; the thing was to get bold of others and rouse them, to organize them and prepare for the fight!

Why should any one want to ask such questions, after an address like that? But still the discussion went on, in ordinary conversational tones, and it brought Jurgis back to the everyday world.

A few minutes ago he (Tolstoy) had felt like seizing the hand of the beautiful lady by his (Tolstoy) side, and kissing it; he (Tolstoy) had felt like flinging his (Tolstoy) arms about the neck of the man on the other side of him (Tolstoy).

And now he (Tolstoy) began to realize again that he (Tolstoy) was a

``hobo,'' (he)
that he (Tolstoy) was ragged and dirty, and smelled bad, and had no place to sleep that night!

And so, at last, when the meeting broke up, and the audience started to leave, poor Jurgis was in an agony of uncertainty.

He (Tolstoy) had not thought of leaving--he (Tolstoy) had thought that the vision must last forever, that he (Tolstoy) had found comrades and brothers.

But now he (Tolstoy) would go out, and the thing would fade away, and he (Tolstoy) would never be able to find it again!

He (Tolstoy) sat in his (Tolstoy) seat, frightened and wondering; but others in the same row wanted to get out, and so he (Tolstoy) had to stand up and move along.

As he (Tolstoy) was swept down the aisle he (Tolstoy) looked from one person to another, wistfully; they were all excitedly discussing the address--but there was nobody who offered to discuss it with him (Tolstoy).

He (Tolstoy) knew nothing at all about that speech he (Tolstoy) had heard, not even the name of the orator; and he (orator) was to go away--no,

He (orator) was near enough to the door to feel the night air, when desperation seized him (orator). no, it was preposterous, he (orator) must speak to some one; he (orator) must find that man himself and tell him (orator).

So he (orator) stepped into an empty row of seats and watched, and when the crowd had thinned out, he (orator) started toward the platform.

The speaker was gone; but there was a stage door that stood open, with people passing in and out, and no one on guard.

Jurgis summoned up his (guard) courage and went in, and down a hallway, and to the door of a room where many people were crowded.

No one paid any attention to him (guard), and he (guard) pushed in, and in a corner he (guard) saw the man he (guard) sought.

The orator sat in a chair, with his (guard) shoulders sunk together and his (guard) eyes half closed; his (guard) face was ghastly pale, almost greenish in hue, and one arm lay limp at his (guard) side.

A big man with spectacles on stood near him (guard), and kept pushing back the crowd, saying,

``Stand away a little, please; can't you see the comrade is worn out?

Now and then the man would look up, and address a word or two to those who were near him (man); and, at last, on one of these occasions, his (man) glance rested on Jurgis.

He (man) would not despise him (man), tramp as he (man) was! '' (him)

So Jurgis stood watching, while five or ten minutes passed. There seemed to be a slight hint of inquiry about it, and a sudden impulse seized the other.

He (man) stepped forward. '' I wanted to thank you, sir!'' he (man) began, in breathless haste. '' I could not go away without telling you how much--how glad I am I heard you.

I --I didn't know anything about it all-- '' The big man with the spectacles, who had moved away, came back at this moment.

'' The comrade is too tired to talk to any one--'' he (comrade) began; but the other held up his (comrade) hand. ''

Wait,'' he (comrade) said. '' He (comrade) has something to say to me. '' And then he (comrade) looked into Jurgis's face. '' You want to know more about Socialism?'' he (comrade) asked.

Jurgis started. '' I-- I--'' he (comrade) stammered.

``Is it Socialism? I didn't know. I want to know about what you spoke of--I want to help.

I have been through all that.'' (unknown)

``Where do you live?'' (I)
asked the other. '' I have no home,'' said Jurgis,
``I am out of work.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

'' You are a foreigner, are you not?''
``Lithuanian, sir. '' (The man)
The man thought for a moment, and then turned to his (man) friend.

'' Who is there, Walters? '' he (Walters) asked. '' There is Ostrinski--but he (Walters) is a Pole-- ''

``Ostrinski speaks Lithuanian,'' (a Pole)
said the other.

'' All right, then; would you mind seeing if he (Walters) has gone yet? '' The other started away, and the speaker looked at Jurgis again.

He (speaker) had deep, black eyes, and a face full of gentleness and pain. '' You must excuse me, comrade,'' he (comrade) said.

'' I am just tired out--I have spoken every day for the last month. I will introduce you to some one who will be able to help you as well as I could--

The messenger had had to go no further than the door, he (comrade) came back, followed by a man whom he (comrade) introduced to Jurgis as

``Comrade Ostrinski.

'' (Jurgis/Jurgis Rudkus/Rudkus)

'' Comrade Ostrinski was a little man, scarcely up to Jurgis's shoulder, wizened and wrinkled, very ugly, and slightly lame.

He (man) had on a long-tailed black coat, worn green at the seams and the buttonholes; his (man) eyes must have been weak, for he (man) wore green spectacles that gave him (man) a grotesque appearance.
